aged 60, an inmate of the Yuba County-
Hospital, made a determined effort last
night to commit suicide, stabbing himself
with a pocket-knife forty-two times in
the breast, abdomen and left elbow. The
most dangerous wound is In the breast,
the blade penetratinK the pleural cavity
and lungs. Silsby, who was a black
smith, fell from a hayloft at Smartsville
last fall, sustaining injuries which caused
paralysis of the lower limbs. He told the
other patients in the hospital that he waa
tired of life. He may recover.
Woman Admitted to the Bar.
CARSON, April 9.â Mrs. O. H. Grey,
wife of ex-Secretary of State Grey, was
admitted to practice before the Supreme
Court here to-day. She is the second
woman admitted to the bar in Nevada.

PASSING Of AN OPPORTUNITY.
THE nearer comes the opening day of the Trans-
Mississippi Exposition the more evident is the
bet that in not having provided for an exhibit
there California has made a mistake. Perhaps it is
even now not too late. Much could be done between
this time and the Ist of June, when the doors are to
open. The exposition at Omaha is to be more ex
tensive than there has been held in this country,
with the single exception of the Columbian affair.
The buildings now approaching completion are large
and artistic and arc to house products of science, art
and industry from all over the world. It is worth re
mark that the affair ;vas originated at a Trans-
Mississippi Congress at which a California^ pre
sided, and that there was present a strong and en
thusiastic California;-. delegation.
In the preliminary work the people of Omaha and
Nebraska have shown remarkable rest and gener
osity, and their spirit has infected all the States with
the exception of the one capable of making the finest
display of any. There are two things to be consid
ered. It is as necessary to have a domestic market as
a foreign one. and visitors from ever)- part of the
country ariS be at Omaha by the thousands during
the six months the exposition is to be under way.
Furthermore; California intends soon to have an ex
position on a magnificent scale. The merest recog
nition of the benefits of reciprocity ought to cause
liberal treatment of Nebraska. The money expended
and the good will shown would bring rich returns.
The managers desire that if nothing more ! -. done
Commissioners be appointed from this State and
private exhibits be forwarded It certainly se-nis
strange thct among the States invited o participate
CaUiomta should be the only one to refuse.
THE JURY-BOX SCANDAL.
jj â I ROM the present outlook it appears improb-
I able that we shan ever discover the parties who
were responsible for putting the three bogus
slips into the jury-box in Judge Hunt's court. The
expert who examined the penmanship of the slips and
compared it with that of the various deputies who
copy the names furnished by the Judges for jurymen
has satisfied himself that none of them wrote the
fraudulent slips. For the present, therefore, the in
vestigation is blocked, and perhaps nothing but a for
tunate accident hardly to be expected will ever af
ford evidence, as to the criminal.
In this situation Judge Hunt proposes a new sys
tem of making up the lists and the establishment of a
check against a repetition of the onense. The plan
is a simple one. As stated by him to a representa
tive of The Call, it consists in a rule requiring that all
names for jurymen be copied by not more than two
deputies, and that each slip shall be signed by the
deputy who copied it. In that way. as the Judge
says, it anything goes wrong it will be easy to trace
the cause of it. There will be a personal'responsi
bility on the part of the deputies signing the slips,
and such responsibility nearly always results in mak
ing careless people careful and scheming people
honest.
We directed attention a few days acre to a plan pro
posed by Mr. Shannahan for accomplishing the same
purpose as that aimed at by Jcdge Hur.t. Which of
the two remedies will Kr>t <nit the need of the occa
sion is for the Judges to decide. The pabiic will be
satisfied with anything which secures honesty in the
future, bat will continue to hope that the court, its
officials and the detective force of the city will not
forget the offense already committed, but keep a
watch for some disclosures that will lead to the ar
rest and conviction of the criminal who. without the
knowledge of the court, the clerk or any of the dep
uties, managed to get at the jury-box and stuff the
lists according to his fancy.
A woman ha* been acquitted of the charge of
bigamy brosght by â  man who pretended to be her
husband. But if the acquittal miÂ« jatt. why iÂ« the.
man still out of jail?

the "Letter That Nerer Came.*" Apparently there
are ether letter* inclined to act in the cam* dilatory
fashion.

to move. It coÂ«ld be wi**Â»ed. almott, that Tom Re*d
had moire. of the ehaneterictiea.of-ft tiytag Â«^}tsjulre>s

SPANISH RETROGRESSION.
HP" HE reported remarks of the Spanish War Mm-
I ister introduce an opera bouflfe feature as a pre
* lade to the tragedy that is to follow-. He fer
vently wished that Spain had not a warship afloat,'
for then none would have to strike her flag to the
United State?. However, as she has some ships, he
suggests that they be blown up by their crews.
This morbid expression is the outcome ef cen
turies of folly and bad government. Europe to-day is
not the EttrofM of Phillip 11. Kvery advance in edu
cation and every extension ot popular freedom and
human rights thai has taken place in the last three
centuries rotn.ius in some form the sting of Spain's
opposition. She has stood fast by the old order.
Glutted with the spoils of America, her people at
home neglected the preservation of her industries and
her commerce, until, when her American Pactolus
ran dry. they had largely lost the capacity to thrive
by the industrial arts. Her forests had been wasted,
her streams lost their waters, her soils failed in 'fer
tility, and her enterprising tons were driven into
strange countries to seek the larger opportunities of
life which had failed at home.
Centuries of war for revenge, for dynastic ambition,
for the purpose of feeding a foolish military pride,
have left their mark on the Mature and strength of
her people. Neglectful of reinstatement of home in
dustries, wasteful in her financial methods, unwise in
taxation and prodigal in expenditure, she has for
years come to depend on the revenues wrung from
Cuba and the Philippines. With characteristic im
providence she has returned bad govf rnment and op
pression in those islands for the millions they have
yielded to her. Compared with her nile in her colo-
nies, that of Turkey in Egypt was benevolent. Roman
politicians who secured a province might oppress its
people and overtax their substance, but the oppressed
had a hearing before the Senate. Rome produced a
Verres. but raised also a Cicero to pursue him. Spain
has put her colonies under tyrants who added their
own to the exactions of the home Government, but
she has never questioned nor impeached them. In
her colonial possessions her policy left to the people
only the recourse of assassination or revolution.
Timely concessions were refused. A degree of par
ticipation in their affairs that would have confirmed
the loyalty of her colonists was scouted. They must
put their necks under the heel of the Governor-
General she sent and see him absorb their substance.
until, gorged like a condor, he took flight to make
room for another hungry bird of prey.
It is no wonder that such a policy has isolated her
in Europe, where modern progress looks upon her
as an enemy, and has turned against her the hands
of her own sons. Unwise and wasteful in her day of
power and prosperity, when her splendors dazzled
the world, and unable to support adversity with
philosophy and patience, atrursst the bloody and bril
liant background of her high and mighty past is
cast the shadow of her pitiful decay. It is a far cry
from the Cid Campeador to a War Minister who
prefers to blow up her ships rather than face an
enemy and fight.
A MARKET-STREET SEWER.
,*""! N esteemed morning contemporary, which has
\ resisted all our efforts to convince it that it
* is not good business policy to repave Market
street prior to the construction of a main sewer, now
launches the argument that if a new pavement is laid
it will be worn out long beiore the authorities get
around to the adoption of a sewer system. This
may be questioned. But even if admitted it does not
alter the force of the reasons we have given for im
proving Market street according to accepted j
business methods. A bituminous pavement on that
thoroughfare, if laid in defiance of burrowing corpor
ations and sewer builders, will never have a chance
to wear out. It will be destroyed by them long be
fore its time,
â¢ We think in assigning ten years as the life of â¢
bituminous pavements on business streets our con
temporary rr.akes a careless estimate. The concrete
base practically never wears out. Golden Gate
avcr.r.e was paved in ISSS and has since been sub
jected to the heaviest of traffic. Yet with scarcely
any repairs at all most of the blocks are still in pretty
<:ood order. Xor was the bitumen on this avenue
laid on concrete. The street was paved with mac
adam under an art of the Legislature, and the
bitumen was spread upon the bed of broken rock
prepared for that material. Experts at the time
declared that this foundation would "crawl" and
prove a delusion. Stili after thirteen years of wear
and tear the street is in fairly good order.
The truth of the matter is. if Market street is prop
erly paved and given careful attention afterward the
bitumen ought not to wear out at aIL A proper sys
tem of repairs should keep it in order indefinitely.
Bet no system of repairs can protect a highway from
the digging of the water, gas, telephone and side
sewer vandals. Even if it were possible to build a
main sewer m Market street without tearing it vp â
which is a Chinese dream of most incoherent char
acter â there would be no saving the pavement from
these individuals.
If a sewer is ever built in Market street it ought to
be a ten or twelve foot affair, capabie of carrying off
all the water flowing from the hills on the north and
the fiats on the south. Such a drain should also pro
vide a conduit for pipes and wires and dispose for
ever of the burrowing corporations. Our contempor
ary may think that the construction of an intercept
ing sewer such as this is a holiday affair or that it
would but slightiy disturb the serenity of the bitum
inous pavement for which it is now sighing. Bat
that thought is another Mongolian vision. Nothing
would be left of the street after such a Â»ewer was
completed.
There is but one businesslike way for improving
Market street, ar.d that iÂ« to build a sewer first and
then put down a permanent paveftent and ukÂ« care
of it afterward.

H E latcrt murderer, hanged in thU State wat

THE &A2T FRANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APBIL 10, 1898.
uncomfortable qualm, and In the mind the rlsien ef
a dead form bearing the marks ef riolence. 5e ser
row may be put en the programme as a regular thing.
A murderer devoid ef it could hardly contribute to
the smoothness of a first-class execution. And then
not to feel ill will is the proper course. There really
does not appear any good reason why an assassin
should cherish a disregard for society he had out
raged and which is simply meting cut to him the
penalty he deliberately incurred.
These stereotyped accounts of hangings should be
revised. They go into unnecessary detail. Let the
public take for granted the whole scheme of sorrow,
resignation and forgiveness. The story gets as fam
iliar as that of the suicide who performs a "rash"
not "while laboring under a fit of despo.idency," in
variably using "a cheap pattern of bulldog pistol of
38 caliber."
THE ICE-BOUND WHALERS.
NEWS brought from the Arctic by Third Mate
Tilton of the whaling steamer Belvedere 6trik-
Ingb/ confirms the wisdom of the Government
in dispatching a relief expedition as soon as the peril
ous condition of the whaling fleet was made known.
Thanks' to the promptness with which the expedition
was started, there is reason for the hope that it will
reach the whalers in time to save them from the
destitution and starvation that threaten.
Mr. Tilton states that after the fleet had become ice
bound an inventory of the supplies of all the ships
was taken and it was found that by allowing two
scant meals a day to each man the provisions might
be made to last up to July i. Unless relief was ob
tained before that time the result would be another
of those tragedies of the Arctic in which brave men,
exhausted by lack of food and numbed by the fear
ful cold of the imprisoning ice and snow, lie down
amid the frozen wastes to sleep the sleep that knows
no waking.
So certain was the impending danger, so sure the
doom of the crews, that it was determined to risk one
life in the hazardous attempt to force a way across
the desolation of the north to seek relief. Mr. Til
ton volunteered to make the journey and succeeded
in performing the unprecedented feat of crossing
from Point Barrow to civilization in midwinter. He
arrived to find that his venture had been forestalled;
that American humanity had already dispatched re
lief for the fleet. Xone the less, however, does he
deserve praise for his achievement. He performed
a dangerous duty for his fellow-men courageously
and well, and the worth of the fea. is not diminished
by the fact that the relief he sought had been dis
patched long before he arrived to ask it
With the coming of this news The Call finds a new
gratification in the fact that it was the first to direct
attention to the peril of the whaling fleet, and was not
cr.'.y :r.strumental in inducing the Government to
send a relief expedition, but contributed liberally and
largely in the way of supplies to make it a success.
This is clearly a case where needed help was given in
time. Unless some obstacle insuperable by human
energy stops the relieving expedition, the ice-bound
sailors will be saved ere long from the danger that
threatens, and their scant allowance of two poor
meals a day will be changed to the aburdance of
nourishing food needed to support life and strength
in the ordeal of the Arctic winter.
OPEN PORTS IN CHINA.
|~) ALFOUR'S speech in the Comr-.ons on Tues-
Dday night was the funest and clearest utterance
that has yet been given by the British Ministry
on the situation in China and the attitude taken by
Great Britain toward the recent aggressions of Rus
sia. As was to have been expected, Balfour claims a
complete victory for British diplomacy, and after
making every allowance for the inevitable exaggera
tion of a party leader defending party achievements,
it appears he has good reasons for his claim.
According to BaJfour Great Britain has obtained
'from China four important concessions. The Chinese
Government agrees that the vast and populous re
gion of the Yang-tse-Kiar.g shall never be alienated
to a foreign power, that the director of the Chinese
imperial customs shall be an Englishman, that access
to the inland waters of China shall be free on equal
terms to the ships of all nations, and that three new
treat)- ports â Funing, Yochau and Chin Wang â shall
be open to commerce. These concessions, if main
tained with firmness, will constitute an effective bar
rier against excessive Russian domination in China,
and Mr. Balfour justly pronounced them "'a consider
able harvest for two months' negotiations."
AH of these concessions, with the exception of that
granting the control of imperial customs to an Eng
lishman, are of as much value to other nations as to
Great Britain herself. They are certainly of value to the
United States, and particularly so to the Pacific Coast.
They secure to us a freedom of trade with China and
give us a chance to expand our commerce there on
the same terms with other peoples, and how impor
tant that commerce may be is now rapidly becoming
understood throughout the country.
In view of the fact that these concessions have
been obtained avowedly as an offset to Russian move
ments and may be regarded with hostility by that
country, it is interesting to consider the prospects of
their maintenance. It is one thing to gain advan
tages by diplomacy, but quite a different one to up
hold them at the risk and peril of war. Accordingly
the question arises at once: Will Great Britain stand
firm if Russia should continue to advance under a
threat of war and should be joined in the threat by
Germany?
Balfocr did not directly answer that question, but
certain portions of his speech show what the answer
will when the time comes to make it. He stated
that* the Russian Government having refused to ah-"
â¢tain from taking Port Arthur, Great Britain has de
cided to take the port of Wei-Hai-Wei and fortify it
at I a means cf preventing the Gulf of Pechili from
falling . under the maritime control of "one power."
Here, then, iÂ» an advanced position taken at the otrt- ;
â¢et, and the significance of it cannot fail to bY under
stood, The British flag once hoUted on strong for
tifications at Wei'Hai-Wci will not ; be hauled down
without battle, )â â ...â .â  '_ ; , ': :: â :"â  v. 'â '['__ ;;;..-- V; -
It is to be noted, moreover, that Balfeur does not
expect Great Britain will have to fight alone the war
for free ports In China. He declared an earnest con
vietien that the great commercial showers will Join' la
an alliance to prevent China failing a prey to aaÂ£e*= ;j
elusive influence; cad that by pursuing an unselfish
policy cad opening te jeII what she secures â¢ for. he*? !
self Great ; Britain; would build up both in Europe and
la Amcfi^a & bauy ef intematienal pub! ie Â©pin iea thai
would be EiifiWiemiy pswerf ul ta , support her ia the
suFÂ£Â« &ha has taken, . This view seems te be i&md^
Th* markets e{ Gilaa must be open en equa! terms te
ail. and 63 JeagÃS 6Â«at Britaia stands fer that peUej

WITH ENTIRE FRANKNESS.
Probablr the editor of the Tracy
Weekly Press meant all right when he
made his tyjw to the public unil.r
something he was pleased to term a
"Valedictory." There is. however, a
difference between a valedictory and a
salutatory; According to my dim recol
lection of Latin, 'vale" means about
the same as farewell, and the connec
tion It sustains with valedictory Is not
difficult to detect.
* â¢
It is painful to observe that two
women are quarreling over the body
of the late John S. Enos. It appears
that while animated by the spark c/f
life Enos had been married to onÂ« of
them and had loved the other, to the
scandal of the county of Sonoma,
where this sort of business is properly
frowned upon. The body haÂ« been
consigned to a tomb, but 1b liable to
being snatched out at any moment, an
unpleasant possibility from which
neither litigant can derive much Joy.
I would humbly BUgrgrest a compromise.
Let the coveted remains be cremated
in the presence of witnesses. Then,
with the assistance of a pair of scales,
the ashes may be equally drided.
Thereafter they may, duly urned, be
deck the whatnot in each of the be
reaved households, or, scattered at the
base of a rtoebush. prove efficacious in
enriching the soil or discouraging the
prevalent louse.
â¢ '* â¢
-I am forced to admit that while the
, HeaJdsburg lady who has written on
j the "Battle-ship Maine" is a patriot
: and fit to be the mother of patriots,
she is the author of the worst verse
, that has come to my notice. I would
; not, however, speak lightly of her ef
fort. The theme is one which touches
us all. It is given to few to write
poetry, and yet the impulse to say
; something has stirred the common
heart, and the inclination to say it in
rhyme simply indicates a desire to
say it in the most striking way. I even
refrain from quoting from the Healds
burg effort, and there is no method by
which I could better express esteem.
I would advise the lady not to try to
manufacture poetry. This is in all
kindness. In seeking revenge for the
wrecking of the Maine and the slaught
er of her men the usages of civilized
warfare do not permit the employment
of anything more deadly than cannon.
Once more a painful rumor reaches
me that two Hearstlings intend slap
ping me the first time the pair have
together the joy of opportunity. With
out any desire to evade hardship. I
would suggest that they change their
minds. I do not think either one of the
pair would make a good angel.
â¢ â¢
The merit of having descended from
somebody is doubtless great, but it
fails to impress me. The matter of pos
terity is really of more importance. No
. man can with justice be held respon
sible for his great-grandfather, and
there is no reason why he should
cherish a warm regard, or. indeed,
anything but the utmost indifference for
a gentleman, worthy enough erhaps
while living, but uninteresting when re
solved to a handful of dust. Of course
if the old gentleman accomplished
more than to- pave the way for having
a great-grandson, if he writ his name
large on the pages of history, if he
liberated a nation, formulated a benign
law. made a good book or invented a
way of utilizing steam, for the great
grandson to feel a pride, and to be
fired by an ambition to do a thing or
two himself, is natural. But in all
probability the great-grandfather was
an ordinary mortal, who plodded
through life in eager quest for money,
ar.d at last died with a keen sense of
disappointment at not having got more
of it. Whatever he did he never looked
forward to the glad time when a great
grandson of his would be prinking un
der the shadow of family tree, elate
at being alive, conscious that others of
the same name h&d been alive Lefore
him. I observe the formation of a
genealogical society here. To look back
over the path trodden by generations
which. have passed away is interesting.
It is a matter of history concerning the
individual, but I do not see what the
purpose of a society may be. If a man
has a family tree he can trace it out
himself. If he has none and wants one
he can buy it grafted to.fruitfulness by
stolen branches. If he happens to pos
sess one of which he is ashamed, or
concerning which he is doubtful,
he would object to having it peeped at
by the other members of the society.
Perhaps, however, by concerted Inves
tigation the research can- be extended
beyond the usual limit, and the student
of ancestry trace his line' to the monkey,
and even" learn whether that from
which he sprang was of the arÂ» ?al
variety, delighting to swing by pr hen-
Bile tall from the tropic limb; or the
more sedate sort, who " stayed * below
and garnered the cocoanuts their frolic
some associates - rattled oft In . their
glee, . .

trade for him a "straightforward, Inde
pendent, manly paper." He thinks he
would like that kind. His letter of ad
monition happened to drift this way in
token cf editorial recognition of my
capacity as a waste-basket. It strikes \
me, however, that a man who writes I
an anonymous letter lacks all the char
acteristics hÂ« prof esses * to : admire;
which is enough comment for ."Pioneer"
and nelly more than he merits.

PRINCETON, N. J.. Feb. 28. 1893.
To W, R. Hearst. New York Journal.
New York: I decline to allow my sorrow
for those who died on the Maine to be
perverted to an advertising srhtrac lor
the New York Journal.
GROVER CLEVELAND.
In these few words was Editor Hearst
Informed that the unspeakable effront
ery of making capital out of brave men
dead and eminent men living would be
denied the connivance of an ex-Presi
dent. I honor the citizen who sent the
reply. He might have passed unnoticed
the Insulting message which had asked
him to become party to a fraud, or to
have saved himself from the certainty
of future abuse, permitted the use of
his name on the "committee." But he
took the trouble to answer. The an
swer was deserved, complete, fitting; it
could not have been better. Hearst has
a scheme for erecting a monument to
his own glory. He desires that the
memory of the brand of patriotism he
keeps in stock be perpetuated in stone,
and that the public pay for the stone.
To excite a general interest he has an
nounced the prospective shaft as de
signed to be to the sailors of the Maine;
also that collectors of contributions are
entitled to a rake-off of 10 p*er ccn J To
this palpable pretense, either through
fear or thoughtlessness, some persons
of standing have loaned their names.
Mr. Cleveland had the wisdom to de
cline, being neither foolish nor afraid.
This trick of the Journal's is one of the
lowest it has undertaken in ail its
career of infamy. If that paper is to
it must be regarded
as a type of the greatest evil now
threatening this country- It is more
dangerous than war, more deadly
than pestilence. Before its be
smearing assault no reputation is
safe, Â«o privacy sacred, no canon in
violate. So open in its lies, so brazen
in its meddling, and the laudation of its
intrinsic foulness; so calm in its as
sumption that the people are unclean
creatures, delighting in the odor of the
sewer or capering joyously on the gar
bage heap, it has already created a
false and damaging impression. As a
matter of fact, the people despise it-
They do not believe a word it says.
They cannot think any cause it advo
cates has in it aught of g d. They
may in instances fear it as a person of
breeding would dread an encounter
with a fish wife. It has brought upon
journalism in general an unmerited
opprobrium. Disgus.ed with its flaunt
ing lies, its stupid fakes, its pretended
interviews, its counterfeit virtue, its
noisome yearning for notoriety, read
ers may sometimes mis* ke it for a
sample of the daily paper. It is a sam
ple of nothing but filth: its methods
vulgar, its ambitions vile. As justly
might the women of the land be judged
by the scarlet outcast unblushing un
der her badge of shame. There is no
hope for the Journal while Hearst lives
and his money lasts. He sinks deeper
into the mire to which instinct has led
him. and wherein it is his happiness to
wallow, spattering any who incau
tiously approach. He has no moral
sense to which appeal : ay be made,
and would spurn the hand extended to
lift him to a decent level. But I can
not believe the Journal ~? to be per
manent. For the nonce it attracts at
tention, but so does any other malign
freak exhibited by a showman com
petent as a "spieler." Mr. Cleveland
did well. He has secured a new hold
upon his friends by adding to the list
of his active enemies this r.-n Hearst,
whose presence in journalism is a re
proach to public sentiment and a dis
grace to others who, in following a
calling which has every right to be
honorable, must in some measure be
regarded as his associates.
be a
A man named Groezinper has been
sitting on the bench of Police Judge
Campbell â while the latter jurist is
away permitting his intellectual pow
ers to recuperate. It has been said of
Campbell, lightly and Irreverently, that
he is a peach. If this fi<r.re is permis
sible, then the temporary Incumbent
is a whole basket of peaches, with a
pitcher of cream ajid a barrel of sugar
handy. To get to the facts, it may be
said that a number of gotlless but dis
criminating people, recognizing the
value of The Call, have been taking
this paper from the doorsteps of sub
scribers, their unholy act desecrating
the early dawn, but providing them
with the news. Before hearing from
Groezinger I would have called the act
stealing and the actor a thief. This
eminent authority, however, decides
that a newspaper on a subscriber's
doorstep Is not property. It has passed
from the possession of the publisher
and not into the possession of anybody
else. Therefore by the terms of the
Groezinger lack of reason anybody spy
ing It has a right to pick it up, walk
away with it and leave the man who

I am accused of having replied in
258 words to an indictment or ten
words. It is added that the answer as
made up of epithets. There are several
points about this which are incorrect.
In the first place the ten words consti
tuted neither an indictment nor an In
formation. They simply afforded a text
for a dissertation upon a particular
style of ass to which the author of them
clearly belonged, and, far from being
abusive, the .; dissertation contained
nothing more violent than a delicate in
timation tending to gently and con
siderately place the author aforesaid in
his class. Yet I confess his return for
this courtesy gives me a new impres
sion of his intelligence. He can count
correctly the words in forty lines of
type V . â¢/;.â¢ ?
One who. from some feeling whicli
seems to him to modesty, hides be
hind a fictitious name, cannot reason
ably expect serious notice. Yet I will
do a specimen of this sort the honor
to call attention to an irritating weak
ness of his, manifest in a tendency to
correct the English of others and em
ploy bad English himself. He would
better, with a view of improving hi*
own style, read the -work of Emanuel-
Elzas appearing in this paper, than do
it with the idea that Mr. Elzas needs
to take lessons from him. In the pen
product of the anonymous person in
question there are grievous errors al
ways, so bald and distressing that a
child might perceive them. "I object,"
affirms this authority, "to the 1 word
'subjugate' in the sense of 'subordi
nate.' " Why? A gentleman of literary,
repute, by name Longfellow, onca
translated the "Inferno." and in doing
so made bold to employ the following
expression:
I understood that unto enco a torment
The carnal malefactors were condemned
â Who reason subjugate to appetite.
But it is to be charitably remembered
that Longfellow lacked the advantage
of basking in the peculiar mentality
which essays to shed light upon Elias
and the rest of us and fails through,
having no light to shed. In the same
scathing paragraph of the carper oc
curs the phrase: "It Is only when
such writers â¢ â¢ â¢ â¢ misuses the
Queen's English." To fall into the ex
pressive methods of the unknown I
might add that such writers do not, as
a rule, misuses.
â¢ â¢ â¢
The courts indicate a desire
to get hold of a lawyer named
Holliday, who, in grasping an
other's money and clinging to the
same, failed to hedge himself about by
processes rendering the operation legaL
For this professional oversight he ia
clearly in need of rebuke. He ought at
least to be brought back and induced
to divide the purse. But the interest
ing point to the public will be that on
his bonds for $2000 are two men who
are not worth any such sum, who are
also on other bonds, and who In eaci
instance could have got there only
through perjury. There was never a
better opportunity for putting a pair
of rogues in jail. Personally I have
not the least idea they will be thus
treated. The straw bondsman seems to
be immune so far as punishment is
concerned. I have not the slightest
doubt not only that these particular
ones will escape, but that they will go
on more bonds any time they can get
$5 for doing so. In many cases prison
ers are let out on bail known in ad
vance to be worthless. When the bonds
are declared forfeited the incident
-. I do not impugn the honesty of
Police Judges. Perhaps they are ig
norant of these facts, yet it is strange
that they should fail to be aware of
that which is familiar to everybody
else-
IRREPROACHABLE.
No monarch in the -world can cou^t
upon more devoted support than can tha
President of the United States. The peo
ple of this great republic hare faith In.
their leader and they admire his calm,
firm and honorable attitude In this crisis.

ADVERTISEMENTS.
iPQRTANf
TO THE
PUBLIC!
I wish to call to your attention that j
I have the largest and most select ;
stock of woolens and Â» offer to make i
suits to order at 25 per cent less than
the price for which you could get the
same quality of goods elsewhere.
Every good, patriotic Califoroian should
patronize a firm that gets the work
made by white labor here in this city,
and that is what the firm of JOE
POHEIM does.
The firm employs all the way from
100 to 300 workmen steady at a fair, j
good salary. We are making suits to
order for $12, 515, $17 50 and $20. One-
third of this is paid out for labor done
here, and as that money is spent here
by our workmen, every customer de-
rives an indirect benefit from it; where-
as if you buy ready-made clothing you
are simply boycotting the workmen of
this State, as the ready-made clothing
is all made in the East or in Chinatown
and the money paid for labor is sent
East, instead of being spent here. We :
also make broadcloth, French pique,
beavers and the best English diagonals
to order for $25, $30, 535 and $40 to $50.
These are suits that would cost you at
a high-priced tailor at least from 25 to
40 per cent more. The question may be '
asked why this firm should sell so much
cheaper than other firms, "The reason
la very simple. First, we buy woolens ,
in large quantities at reduced prices; '
secondly, we must and do make quick
sales at a small profit. "While high-
priced tailors sell one suit we sell five, j
A professional man, a doctor, lawyer,
clergyman and a teacher can have a
dressy suit made to order of diagonal,
pique, beaver, broadcloth or doeskin
for $25 to $35, which will look and wear
as well as any suit from a high-priced
tailor for which you would have to pay
$60. We make a specialty of $25, $30
and $35 suits, and give you fine value
for the money. For a man who cannot
pay from $20 to $35 we can make an ex-
traordinarily good suit for $12, $15, |
$17 50, which beats any ready-made
suit. This suit will be cut in style, and
the money paid for the labor will be
spent here. So if we make you a fine
suit for $12 to $17 50 you can readily :
s?e that we will give you the best suit
in the country for $35.
We carry the finest goods, and you '
can have the privilege of picking out
your goods at the cloth-houses and we
will make your suit just as reasonable. \
Some say that the people in the East
are better dressed than the people in
California. Why? Because they get
their clothes made to order. If a work-
man in the East cannot pay $35 for a
suit he gets one made to order for $10
or $15, and it fits him, is cut in style
and gives the working people employ-
ment where the suit is made. They
don't import clothing from California
made by Chinese, if the Californians
would patronize home industry the
times would be better on this coast.
The firm of JOE POHEIM has always
made it a point to buy HERE all goods
that can be bought on as reasonable a
basis as in the East, so as to give the
preference to home industry. This firm
possesses the good will of the public
and has for the last twenty-three years
done the largest merchant tailoring
business on the Pacific Coast.
~ We always treat you well, give you
the most for your money and keep
your clothes in repair free of charge.

St. -V "

THE SAN FRANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, 'APRIL. 10, 1898.
JAPANESE
COMPLAIN OF
MR. NORTH
Their Minister Makes
an Unfounded
Charge.
Alleges That His People
Are Discriminated
Against.
Commissioner Roberts of Phila
delphia Sent Hither to
Investigate.
â â >*
CONTRACT LABOR AGENTS, j
They Have Misrepresented Matters
and Commissioner North Makes
a Vigorous Denial.
The Japanese Minister at "Washington '
has made complaint to the Government ;
against Immigration Commissioner North, I
accusing him of demanding a higher â¢â 
standard of qualifications for Japanese
attempting to land in this country tnan
is prescribed for immigrants of other na
tionalities.
These representations were made to the
Minister by certain Japanese contract
labor agents in this city, one or two of
whom have been mixed up in disreputable
transactions connected with both suc
cessful and frustrated attempts to land
contract laborers in droves. They have
represented that white immigrants are al
lowed to land upon their bare statements,
while the Japanese are haled before the
special board of inquiry and put through
a stringent process of cross-examination,
being treated like persons suspected of
being criminals rather than industrious
and honest citizens of a friendly nation.
As a result of the complaint of the
Japanese Minister, the Secretary of the
I Treasury has dispatched to this city j
< United States Immigration Commissioner \
Roberts of Philadelphia, and has request- '
ed United States immigration Commits- ;
sioner Rice of Victoria, B. C, to co-op- j
, crate with Commissioners Roberts and
North in examining into and reporting
upon the procedure followed by tne lm- I
, migration Bureau in this city.
It will be remembered that a few weeks :
ago Comnyssioner North examined a
batch of Japanese laborers who had ar
rived by way of Victoria. They were
part of a gang of Japs to which Mr.
North had refused a landing, the evidence ;
being clear that they were contract la- :
borers. The Victoria people had been i
permitted to land by Mr. Rice.
This apparent laxity on the part of Mr.
Rice gave rise to murmuring among the
owners of transportation lines operated ;
between San Francisco and Japan. They
said that if the door was to be thrown
wide open at Victoria and double-locked
at San Francisco there could be but one
result, and that would be to turn the cur
rent of Japanese travel to Victoria and
to give San Francisco the go-by. Mr. ;
Rice was notified shortly afterward by i
' the Secretary of the Treasury and the
i Commissioner-General of Immigration
that he would afford pleasure to the ad
ministration and would put a stop to the
i complaints if he would study the plan i
I pursued by Mr. North and if he and Mr.
I North would mutually agree upon a uni
form course in such matters.
Commissioner North yesterday de
nounced as false the charge that he had
i applied one rule to Japanese and another â 
: rule to white immigrants. White immi- :
( grants came hither with their families j
and told straight stories as to their in- i
| tention of making the United States their '
home. There was no evidence whatever I
that they were coming as contract la
borers. On the other hand, Mr. North j
! had been obliged to refuse a landing to ]
j squads of Japanese, young men who ar
rived with $30 in their pockets and were I
dressed in the same lot of European I
clothing obtained from the same estab
i lishment in Yokohama, and some of them j
being found with contract labor certi- j
j ficates on their persons. They could not
I tell a straight story, but lied and con- |
I tradicted themselves at every turn. For
I those reasons they had been denied a !
landing, and white persons under the j
same circumstances and telling the same '
\ improbable yarns would have been cx
i eluded as well.

er is past and the season for catching
Colds is over. This makes the Spring
Cold agfravating and t"~a victim wants
to get over it in a hurry, and so he can
by taking "Seventy- seven"; it "breaks
up" Colds and checks the Grip. You
have tried "77" now try llnmpftrey*.'

and Weak Stomach; for Rheumatism
and Lumbago; for Infant Diseases,
Croup, Whooping Cough, etc.

ceipt of price, 25c, or 5 for $1; may be
assorted.

gists', or sent free, tell* all.
Humphreys' Medicine Company, New
Yorlc
down from Sacramento and are registered
at the California.
The other day an old fellow, charged
with grand larceny, was on trial in one
of our Superior
Courts. It seems
that he and a vis
iting Englishman
had been out tak
ing in the town
with the result
that they both
IMPRISONED
BUT NOT
DISHONORED.
had become so full that they could not
bend over without spilling. In this con
dition they separated and the Briton went
to bed, where he slept off the effects of
his debauch, arising in the morning to
discover that he had a big head and $60
less than he counted upon. He at once
Jumped to the conclusion that his com.
panion of the evening before had "touch
ed" him, so, after hunting up a drug
store to get something for his nerves, he
hunted up a detective and had the fel
low arrested and employed special coun
sel. In the person of a little shyster, to
prosecute him.
As the evidence proceeded it proved
more and more that the poor old fellow
was as Innocent of any theft as a babe
and that the extent of his shortcoming
began and ended with a bottle. Finally
he r nself was placed on the stand and
the^prosecution realizing that, unless
something unexpected was developed,
they 'would lose their case, put him on
the rack and subjected him to a cross-
examination that was simply barbarous, j
He. however, managed to pass through ]
it all right and the little lawyer was
about to conclude when a happy thought j
seemed to strike him and he said, "Were j
you ever In prison before In your life?" I
"I was," replied the defendant. "Where, j
when and on what charge?" asked the I
lawyer, as a smile of triumph mantled his
features and h*> glanced toward the jury j
as much as to say, "Pay close attention;
the unexpected which I have been work- i
ing for is about to develop." And it did. j
With a sudden stiffening of his whole
frame and with a flash of fire from his :
old eyes he answered, in a voice that 'Â
fairly rang with martial feeling. "An- ;
dersonville.^in '63, for getting captured
on a battle-field after receiving four
wounds "n defense of the same flag that
floated over the Maine."
It took the jury just ten seconds to :
acquit him.
Adjutant-General A. W. Barrett has
i come down from Sacramento and is stay
ing at the California.
Mrs. P. Lorillard Jr. and P. Lorillard 111
i are at Palace, where they arrived last
I njght from New York.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Williams of
Brooklyn, N. V.. are at the Occidental, ac
companied b>* their daughters.
James A. Lacy, of the Parke Lacy Com
pany, has returned from his trip to Skag
uay, and is staying at the Grand.
Dr. F. Schwartzschild of Tesla, Cal.,
traffic manager of the Alameda and San
Joaquln Railroad, is visiting here.
P. L. Pratt, U. S. N., and Jose Proc
hazks, a coffee raiser of Guatemala, are
two of the late arrivals at the Palace.
W. If. Bracket and E. Pattee are two
Central American coffee planters who ar
rived on the City of Para and went to
the Grand.
Officer E. F. Lenord has entirely re
covered from a serious cold which at
one time threatened to develop into pneu
monia, and is again to be seen on duty
around the hotels.

ma\\r.
BALD-FACED
SATSUMA FIRST
Dr. Rowell's Chestnut
Horse Won the Rich
Burns Handicap.
The Winner Piloted in Masterly
Fashion by Jockey H.
Shields.
Buck Mbbslo W.s Unplaoed-Won't
Dtnca Ran a Great RaeÂ«, Fin
ishing Second.
Satsuma, the bald-faced son of Mac-
Duff, captured the richest prize of the
California turf at Oakland track yes
terday. Nearly 10,000 people frantically
cheered Dr. Rowell's great chestnut
horse as he led Won't Dance under the
wire.
The event was a handicap, and the
allotment of weights was the cause for
an onslaught of many naughty things
hurled at Handicapper Brooks. Not
withstanding all this, it was one of the
best contested races ever run in Cali
fornia, and Jockey Henry Shields and
Satsuma are heroes of the hour.
The big event of the day was fifth
on the card, and ten horses accepted
the issue. The Burns & Waterhouae
pair, Traverser and Candelarla, held
first place in the betting at odds of 5
to 2. Jim Murphy told all of his friends
to have a bet on Buck Massie. and
the hero of many an equine battle was
second choice in the belting. The Mon
tana people thought well of the chances
of Ostler Joe, and eagerly accepted the
8 to 1 offered about him. Ed Corrigan
went out of his way to say that Won't
Dance had an undeniable chance, and
when the daughter of Longfellow fin
ished second the books winced. Against
Satsuma, with Shields up, the ring laid
10 and 12 to 1.
It was after 4 o'clock when the horses
were summoned to the post, and fujl
twenty minutes had elapsed before
Starter Ferguson released the barrier
to a perfect start. As prophesied,
Traverser passed the stand first, fol
lowed by Buck Massie, Fonsovannah
and Ostler Joe. Soon it became appa
rent that Fonsovannah was sent out to
kill off Traverser, and three furlongs
from home the hopes of "Pa" Bradley
were blasted â Traverser was beaten.
The chestnut, however, led Fonsovan
nah into the stretch, with bald-faced
Satsuma at their heels. Henry Shields
on the latter rode the race of his life,
and gradually taking command the
long-Umbed rider piloted the outsider
past the winning post a head before
Won't Dance, the mile and a quarter
being negotiated in 2:07^. The latter
mare ran a wonderful race, for as the
stand was passed the first time she
was last of the bunch Thorpe brought
Candelaria up from the far rear, taking
third place.
Shields, the rider of Satsuma, re
ceived a great ovation on his return
to the stand, and richly he deserved it,
for never was a hurse better handled.
The winner was decorated with a
handsome floral horseshoe placed over
his neck by Thomas H. Williams Jr.,
president of the Jockey club, and Dr.

I the congratulations of his many
â  friends.
Of the other six events the favorites
! scored first in four. The betting was

AWAITING
THE ORDER
TO MARCH
Infantry at the Presi
dio and Benicia
Barracks Ready.
Shelter Tents and Full
Equipments for Field
Service Issued.
Batteries Will Be Placed at
Santa Cruz to Protect the
Powder Works.
PREPARATIONS FOR WAR.
Work on thÂ© Military Cables Con
neotirj A: gel Island and Aleatruz
With the Mainland.
The First United States Infantry,
stationed at the Presidio, is ready for
the front. As announced exclusively
in yesterday's Call, orders were re
ceived Friday Instructing the com
manding officer, Colonel Evan Mi'es, to
have the companies of the regiment
hold themselves in readiness to leave
at a moment's notice. Instant prep
arations were made to execute the or
der. Shelter tejits were drawn and
other field camp equipage issued to the
soiaiers.
Yesterday morning the companies of
the regiment stationed at the Presidio
were inspected in heavy marching or
der. Every enlisted man was sup
plied with the lieid regulation allow
ance of clothing and one tin cup, knife,
fork and spoon, constituting the mess
furniture of a soldier in the field. Each
soldier in line had his overcoat neatly
wrapped in one-half of a shelter tent.
The inspection was thorough, indicat
ing the readiness of the command to
move without delay to the front.
The following dispatch shows that
orders similar to those issued at the
Presidio were given at Benicia Bar
racks:
BENICIA. April 9, 1898.
Orders have been received at the
Benicia Barracks instructing the
commanding officer. Colonel Smith,
to have the companies of the First
Infantry under his command to hold
themselves in readiness to leave at a '
moment's notice. Inspection is now
being held, and all that are not fit for
service -will be left out. The sold
iers express plenty of enthusiasm
over the order.
Many representatives of the gentler
sex, after reading The Call yesterday
paid a visit to their friends stationed
at the Presidio. The First Infantry has
been at this statin: for many years,
and the officers and enlisted men have
formed many lasting friendships in the
community. The departure of the reg
iment for the front will cause many
tender expressions of regret, but the
eoldiers stand ready to go where duty
demands.
Orders for the regiment to march
may come to-morrow or may be post
poned for days. At the post exchange
where the enlisted men assemble to
smoke and gossip wagers are laid that
the orders to leave will be given before
Monday midnight. At the Presidio
Club, where the officers of the garri
son loiter occasionally and talk over
the news, the opinion finds many sup
porters that the recent orders do not
si -nify immediate departure for the
front. Some of the officers believe yet
that war with Spain will be avoided,
by Spanish concession.
The order posted at headquarters
last Friday, which directs that officers
shall not leave the Presidio without
Bpecial permission from the command-
Ing officer, has not been revoked or
modified. This signifies that the order
to march is hourly expected.
General Bhafter, commanding the de
partment, will arrive in the city from
the south to-morrow morning. First
Lieutenant John D. Miley. Fifth Artil
lery, aid and engineer officer on the
general's staff, returned from San Di
tgo yesterday. The report of the com
manding officer's inspection of the San
Diego fortifications will be forwarded
at once to headquarters of the army in
Washington.
It is known that the defenseless con
3ltlon of severaJ of the cities of the Pa
cific coast has engaged the attention of
General Shafter. It is surmised that a
Spanish cruiser or privateer might
ADVERTISEMENTS.
A POPULAR MISTAKE
Regarding Remedies for Dyspepsia and
Indigestion.
The national disease of Americans Is
Indigestion or in its chronic form, dy-
spepsia, and for the very reason that
It Is bo common many people neglect
taking proper treatment for what they
ronsider trifling stomach trouble, when,
as a matter of fact, indigestion lays
the foundation for many Incurable dis-
eases. No person with a vigorous,
healthy stomach will fall a victim to
consumption. Many kidney diseases
and heart troubles date their begin-
ning from poor digestion; thin, nerv-
ous people are really so because their
stomachs are out of gear; weary, lan-
gruid, faded out women owe their con-
dition to imperfect digestion.
When nearly every person you meet
Is alilicted with weak digestion it is not
surprising that nearly every secret pat-
ent medicine on the market claims to
be a cure for dyspepsia, as well as a
Bcore of other troubles, when, .in fact,
as Dr. Werthior says, there is but one
genuine dyspepsia cure which is per-
fectly safe and reliable, and moreover,
this remedy is not a patent medicine.
but it is a scientific combination of
pure pepsin (free from animal matter),
vegetable essences, fruit salts and bis-
muth. It Is sold by druggists under
name of Stuart's Dyspepsia Tablets. Js'o
extravagant claims are made for them,
but for indigestion or any stomach
trouble. Stuart's Dyrpepsla Tablets are
far ahead of any remedy yet discov-
ered. They act on the food eaten, no
dieting is necessary, simply eat all the
â¢wholesome food you want and these
tablets will digest it, A cure results,
because all the stomach needs is a
rest, which Stuart's Dyspepsia Tablets
give by doing the work of digestion.
Druggists sell thr-se tablets at 50 cents
per package. Little book on slomach
diseases and testimonial* sent free by
Â«uddree*ing Stuart Co., chemists, Mar-
make a demonstration against Santa
Barbara and even land a force of men
and demand tribute.
In view of the importance to the Gov
ernment of the powder plant at Santa
Cruz preparations are In progress to
erect defensive works at that point. It
transpires that the department com
mander considered this subject several
weeks ago and has since decided to
erect a battery and establish a garri
son at Santa Cruz. Whether the forti
fications will be garrisoned by troops
of the United States army or compa
nies of the National Guard of this
State has not yet been determined. As
measures of defense progress it be
comes obvious that there will be plenty
of work for the State troops. A regi
ment of the National Guard may at
any hour be ordered to duty at the Pre
sidio.
It also comes to light that the army
authorities have decided to materially
strengthen the defenses of San Diego.
The battery of ten-inch rifles now in
position may be exposed to an enfilad
ing fire from a Spanish cruiser. Ad
ditional earthworks on the flank to the
ocean may be necessary as a protec
tive measure. It Is understood that
other batteries will be erected to guard
the harbor against an enemy's ap
proach. A regiment of the National
Guard, or at least a battalion, may be
sent to San Diego.
The Santa Cruz position is specially
important because the Government has
ordered vast quantities of Santa Cruz
powder for shipment to the Atlantic
seaboard. The public will not be ad
vised when the shipments are made,
but the fact remains neverthe!ess that
the po-wder has been contracted for and
the transportation has been secured
by the quartermaster's department of
the army. The Works are not more
lhan'two miles from the ocean: hence
a privateer throwing shells in that lo
cality might explode the works.
Colonel Miles, commanding the post
at the Presidio, was at Fort Point yes
terday afternoon when the 12-inch
breech-loading ritie, which is to be
mounted on a disappearing cariage.was
landed from a barge near the fort. The
water was smooth, and the contractor
had no trouble in getting the great gun
from the barge safely on shore before
dark. The gun was moved above high
water line last night and will be hauled
up the hill and placed in position with
out unnecessary delay. This gun weighs
fifty-nine tons. The carriage on which
it is to rest weighs ISO tons.
Captain George E. Sage, U. S. A., re
ceived intelligence by wire yesterday
that he had been assigned to duty with
the Sixth Artillery, Colonel E. B. Wil
liston, Fort McHenry, Maryland. The
captain, who was recently pro-moted
from first lieutenant of the Fifth Ar
tillery, is a native of New York, and
was appointed a second lieutenant in
the Nineteenth Infantry from Illinois
September 30, IS6S. July 14, 1869, he was
assigned to the Fifth Artillery, and
February 21, 1881, was promoted first
lieutenant. Captain Sage served with
the Fifth at stations along the New
England coast from Fort Trumbull,
Conn., to Fort Sullivan. Me. In May,
IS7O, when the Fenians made their at
tempted invasion of Canada, Captain
Sage accompanied his battery to the
scene of disturbance in Northern New
York and Vermont. In the fall of 1873
his regiment was ordered south, and
in ISM it garrisoned the posts in New
York harbor. In IS9O the Fifth came
to the Pacific Coast and was stationed
at posts in San Francisco harbor and
Fort Canby, Wash., with headquarters
at the Presidio, at which post Captain
Sage was stationed till August 14, 1894,
when he was appointed military in
structor at Mount Tamalpais Military
Academy at San Rafael.
Of the $90,000 appropriated by Con
gress on estimates submitted by Gen
eral A. W. Greely. chief signal officer,
United States army, for cables to con
nect electrically the fortifications in
the harbors along the Atlantic and Pa
cific coasts with the main land, the de
partment of California has been al
lotted a sufficient sum to connect all
the islands in San Francisco harbnr
and fortifications at Lime Point, Fort
Baker and Fort Mason. The destruc
tion of the military cables between Al
catraz and Angel islands ,nd the main
land long since left the fortifications in
the harbor isolated and entirely un
connected electrically. Work is now
being rushed on this work by the sig
nal officer of the department. Lieuten
ant Frank Green, and when completed
the entire system of our harbor de
fense will be connected electrically,
so that not only will the transmission
of orders be constantly maintained but
the entire control and the direction of
the defense will be under one master
mind.
MASONS OBSERVE EASTER.
California Commandery No. 1,
Knights Templar, Will Attend
First Congregational Church.
California Commandery No. 1. Knights
Templar, will attend Easter service in
uniform this evening at the First Con
gregational Church, Post and Mason
streets. Rev. George C. Adams, pastor of
.the First Congregational Church, and
Rev. Sir W. E. Smith, prelate of Califor
nia Commandery No. 1, Knights Tem
plar, will officiate. Music will be ren
dered by the church choir. The head of
ficers of the Commandery are Eminent
Sir John P. Fraser, commander; Sir
Charles H. Wilson, generalissimo; Sir W.
H. Frank Titus, captain general. Follow
ing is the programme to be presented:
Organ prelude, "Pilgrim Chorus" (Wag
ner), during which the Sir Knights will
enter the church and be seated ; hymn,
"Onward. Christian Soldiers" (Sullivan);
Invocation by the pastor; song, by the
choir; confession by all present, with the
prelate. Sir Knights kneeling; sentences
of hope by the prelate, Sir Knights re
main kneeling; song by the choir, at the
end the eminent commander giving the
word to arise, a dialogue between the
prelate and the Sir Knights following;
the Easter Psalm, all standing; Bong by
the choir, preceding and following the
command given by the eminent com
mander to be seated; the lesson, consist
ing of music and devotions; prayer, with
response by the choir. Sir Knights still
kneeling: contralto solo. "The Day of
Resurrection" (Btevensonl; hymn, con
gregation Joining in; offertory, "Easter
Song" (Oranier); sermon on "Christ, t:ie
First Fruits of Them That Arc Asleep."
Rev. George C. Adams. D.D. ; the Apos
tles' Creed, Sir Knights arising at order
from eminent commander and repeating
words with the prelate; requiem by choir.
Sir Knights and eoDgregatton standing;
benediction by the pastor; organ postlude,
during which the Sir Knights leave the
church.
Hydraulickers Not Convicted.
The Jury failed to agree in the case
of Ah Louis, Ah Chung and Ah Chang,
tried in the United States District Court
on a charge of hydraulic mining without
permission from the Antl-Debrls Associa
tion. The defendants were engaged in
working the old Indiana Hall mine, nÂ«aÂ«-
Gold Run, and It was alleged that they
used monitors. This they denied, and the
evidence was conflicting.

Guy McCord, the proprietor of a poker
"Joint," was yesterday held to answer be
fore the Superior Court by Judge Joach
imsen on a charge of felony embezzlement
in $1000 bonds. . HÂ« got several diamonds'
from Frances Gerry to take to a Jeweler
on Third street to. bo reset, and he . got
the Jeweler to substitute paste for the
real. articles by telling him that the Jew

THE SAX FRANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APRIL 10, 1898.
STRONG HARES AND FAST DOGS
INGLESIDE.
One of the best local cards ever drawn
was run down at Ingleside Coursing Park
yesterday, and the way the talent was
kept on the run was proof positive that
something will "be doing to-day." A
large Saturday crowd was on the ground,
but they found it almost Impossible to
guess the winners. A long string of top
notchers and many second-raters started,
but the way they had been drawn made
the sport of more than general Interest.
The judge decided as follows:
In the run down Lynch & Maher's Da
kota beat T. McHughes' Tic-Tac-Toe, T.
Butler's Susie beat Deckelman &
Panarlo's Glen Roy; E. W. Duffy's B B
beat James Lace's Ellen Terry; James
Masconi's Olein beat Conncll Bros.' Sir
Walter, J. Dean's Connemara beat W.
Dalton's Famous, Connell Bros.' Log Boy
beat Thomas J. Burkes Little Pete, G.
Smart's Silkwood beat D. Kaher's Bell of
Mosc ow, J. Kinkaid's Nelly Conroy beat
F. G. Fentiman's Blue Bell. Lowe &
Thompson's Patrla beat T. M. Rogers'
Olga, James McCormick's White Wings
beat W. Dalton's Lady Napoleon, T. Cro
nln's Magnet beat W. Ryan's Sweet Mu
sic, W. Dalton's Sinaloa a bye. M. Mich
allk's Fireball beat W. C. Glassen's Mys
tery-, J. Shea's Firenza beat E. Camp
bell's Bendalong, M. D. Hill's General
beat T. Cronin'a Thornhill, Deckelman &
Panario's Old Glory beat E. C. Jones'
Gaslight, T. Cooney's Right Bower beat
J. Quane's Vigilant, Deckelman & Pana
rio's Decorator beat D. Hooper's Koo
Lawn, James Byrnes' Seminolo beat J.
Murnane's Flashlight.
M. Kerrigan's Lady Blanche beat E.
Campbell's Daisy; Connell Bros." Senorlta
beat J. Quane's Princess Marie; W.
Ryan's Signal beat T. Mcllugh's Lady
Hopp; Lynch & Maher's Mystic Maid
beat W. Nilon's Fly; Larkey & Rock's
Myrtle beat J. Byrne's Occidental.
Immediately after the run down a con
solation stake was drawn, resulting as
follows: Koolawn vs. Vigilant; Princess
Marie vs. Olga; Sir Walter vs. Lady Na
poleon; Bell of Moscow vs. *â¢ lashlinght;

HALE & NORCROSS
DECISION IS IN
It Is No Nearer a Conclusion
Than It Was Many
Months Ago.
Supreme Court Rehashes a Former
Ruling and Sends the Caso
Back.
The long-expected decision in the case
of M. W. Fox against the Hale & Nor
cross Silver Mining Company was hand
ed down yesterday, and the findings of
the majority of the court leave the
matter in practically the same condition
that it was In after the previous de
cision by the same tribunal. The opinion
was written by Justice Temple and con
curred in by Chief Justice Beatty and
Justices Henshaw and Harri/on, Justices
Garoutte and Van Fleet dissenting. The
substance of the decision is summed up
in the following findings:
The judgment will therefore be as
upon the first appeal, that the judg
ment below is set aside and the Su
perior Court is directed to enter a
judgment as of the date of the first
judgment against Alvinza Hayward,
H. M. Levy and the estate of W. S.
Hobart, deceased, for the sum of
$210,197 50, with the interest from
that date upon the issue, for having
paid an excessive price for milling
the ore in the Mexican and Nevada
mills. As to the issue presented by
a claim for damages sustained for
reason of imperfect and fraudulent
milling, a new trial is awarded and
the court is directed to proceed and
try that issue and make findings in
accordance with the views hereinbe
fore expressed.
In order tbat the full meaning of this
dfdsion may be understood a brief his
tory of the" matter must be given. M.
W. Fox, on behalf of himself and other
stockholders of the corporation, began
an action against the company, and par
ticularly against Hayward, Hobart, H.
M. Levy, the president of the company,
and the Virginia and Mexican Mill, the
Nevada Milling and Mining Company and
several directors, wealthy citizens of the
Pacific Coast. The defendants were ac
cused of conspiracy and frauds of the
most gross nature, the principal charge
bring that Hayward and Hobart, owners
of the mills, made an arrangement with
the ethers so that ores taken from the
mine to their mills should be so treated
that a large part of the precious metals
should go into the slimes and tailings
and later be converted to the use of the
conspirators, who in turn would divide
with the suborned president. Levy, thus
defrauding the stockholders out of large
sums of money.
The case was first heard before Supe
rior Judge Ilebbard, who found that the
directors named in the complaint, to
gether with Hayward, Hobart and Levy,
were guilty of fraud. That the sum of
$210,000 be paid by the accused in lieu of
the fraudulent excess of milling charges
and the enormous sum of $1,025,000 Judg
ment for the amount embezzled. From
this an appeal was taken to the Su
preme Court, where the Justices, after
long deliberation, exonerated the incrim
inated directors of the charge of fraud.
They also reversed the Judgment relating
to the $1,025,000 embezzlement. The Judg
ment on the first amount named, $210,197,
was affirmed, the higher tribunal holding
that thiÃ was merely for an overcharge
for milling, but In the damages for fraud
in milling the Judgment and order were
reversed.
When the remitlttur went down the
Judge of the lower court entered Judg
ment for $210,197. and from this another
appeal was taken, the contention being
that the Judgment was segregated and
there could not be two Judgments in one
ADVERTISEMENTS.

CHICAGO DENTAL PARLORS,
24 SIXTH ST.. COR. STEVENSON, Open Evenings.
UNION PARK.
The big racing event at Oakland track
yesterday attracted quite a number of the
supporters of coursing from the Union
Park coursing grounds, yet, all things
considered, there was a comfortable at
tendance when the first course was called.
The betting was especially lively and sev
eral thousands of dollars changed hands.
The Call's tips, as usual, were heavily
played, and out of twenty-four courses
but four selections failed to cash.
The following 1b the result of the first
run down of the all-aged stake:
Sans Souci beat Alameda; Forget beat
Kilkenny Girl; Tessie Fair beat Van
Knapp; Tod Sloan beat Sharkey; Douglas
beat Black Pete; Green Valley Maid beat
Van Cloie; Van Needa beat Arapahoe;
Terrona beat Santa Alicia; Chit Chat beat
Carmen; Camilla beat Vida Shaw; Sweet
Lips beat Ben B; Chartist beat Harkaway
II; Theron beat Port Costa Lass; Magic
beat Lady Harkaway; Promise Me beat
Electric; The Turk beat Lady Grace;
Move On beat Gilt Edge; Moore's Pre
scription beat Lor- Byron; Herculese beat
Amorita; Wmte Chief beat Gannon
Pasha; Eclipse beat Commodore; Rusty
Gold beat Marcella; Mountain Beauty
beat Royal Buck; Flying Buck beat Rey
Alfonso.
In the first round of to-day, The Call
makes the following selections, which will
prove successful provided the hares run
up to their form of yesterday:
Forget to beat Sans Souci; Tessie Fair
to beat Tod Sloan; Green Valley Maid to
beat Douglas; Terrona to beat \an Nee
da; Chit Chat to beat Camilla; -Chartist
to beat Sweet Lips; Theron to beat Magic;
Promise Me to beat The Turk; Move On
to beat Moore's Prescription; Hercules
to beat White Chief: Rusty Gold to beat
Eclipse. Flying Buck and Mountain
Beauty should make a clinking course
with Buck to win by a small margin.
Doubtless the stake will be won by
either of the following dogs: Flying
Buck, Rusty Gold or Theron. Green Val
ley Maid will have a number of warm
admirers, as she is running fast and
strong.
In the puppy stakes Palmer Hill beat
War Cloud; Royal Oak beat Arrow; Pas
time beat Quiver; Star Pointer beat
Dempsey; Bonlta beat Sunbeam; Flying
Faster beat Gold Brick; Handy Andy
beat Obadiah; Minerva beat Liberty Bell.
As the young dogs are very uncertain
in their running, selections will not be
made. Flying Faster ran very well yes
terday, and may possibly land the stake.
case and that the court must wait for
that portion of the judgment that was set
back for further trial. The position of the
defendants was sustained by, the Supreme
Court, the judgment was reversed and
the case sent back to await the final ac
tion of the lower court in the ca.se in its
entirety.
That portion of the original judgment
which was remanded for a new trial (the
part relating to the damages sustained
by imperfect and fraudulent milling) was
attain tried before Judge Hebbard, who
found for the plaintiff fur $417,000. which,
with the $210,197, was entered against the
defendants, and this constituted the judg
ment from which this last appeal was
taken. As stated, the decision of yester
day places the case in exactly the same
position as when the tirst Supreme Court
decision was rendered.
The decision was not in the least a sur
prise to many. It is the custom that the
nature of a decision by this high tribunal
shall not be known until after it is hand
ed to the clerk of the court and filed. On
Friday the stock brokers, or some of
them, seemed to know all about what
ti.e verdict would be. and as a result over
0000 shares were unloaded on thp market,
the price tumbling from $1 30 to $1. Some
one in the inside must have given a tip
which was not slow to be taken. Im
mediately after rendering the decision the
court departed for Los Angeles.
BECEPTION OF ASPIRANTS.
Ladies' Sodality of St. Ignatius
Church Will Add New Members.
A solemn reception of nevr members to
the Ladles' Sodality at St. Ignatius
Church will take place this afternoon at
3 o'clock. Rev. Father Calzia, the spirit
ual director of the society, will receive the
aspirants, after which the office of the
Blessed Virgin will be recited by the mem
bers. Father Calzia will deliver an ad
dress, at the conclusion of which a sa
cred musical programme in honor of the
occasion will be rendered, a special fea
ture of which will be the rendition of an
instrumental trio for' violin, orpan and
piano by the Misses Agnes, Angela and
Clotilde Devlin. Hymns will be sung by
the lady members and will conclude the
programme.
The sodality is at present io a very
flourishing condition, and has upward of
700 members, owing to the zeal and earn
estness of its spiritual director, Rev.
Father Calzia.
The magnificent steamship Morgan
City of the Ladue-Yukon Transporta
tion Company, which is consigned to
Johnson- Locke Mercantile Company,
not having arrived on her scheduled
time from New York, her sailing date
for Juneau, Dyea. Skaguay and Copper
River has been changed to April 16, on
which date she will leave from Folsom
street wharf.
A Benefit Entertainment.
The Dramatic Club of the California
School of Elocution and Oratory will give
an entertainment on Tuesday evening,
April 12. at Golden Gate Hall. 625 Sutter
street, for the benefit of Miss Emily Cur
tis, president of the school. The price of
admission has been fixed at 50 cents. An
excellent programme has been arranged,
consisting of music, both vocal and in
strumental, dramatic recitations, poses
plastiques and the farce "Obliging a
Friend." As the California School of Elo
cution and Oratory has long been noted
for the high quality of Its training and
the accomplishments of Us students, an
evening of genuine enjoyment may be ex
pected by all.
Advances made on furniture and piano*, with
or without removal. J. N'oonan. 1017-1023 Mission.
To Improve Tilden Street.
A petition has been sent to the Board
of Supervisors from the- residents In the
vicinity of the westerly end of Fifteenth
street, asking that Fifteenth street be
opened and extended westerly to Tilden
street; also to lower the grade of the lat
ter thoroughfare to that of the former
bo as to make Tilden street accessible by
way of Fifteenth and allow a propor
drainage. The petitioners are: Q. Moulin,
James H. Duncan, ChriÂ» Leavy, Charles
F. Helln. Patrick Prior, B. P. \ornoch,
J. B. Gorman, John Talford.N. Knoll,
Daniel Frank. Julius Relmer, A, J. Bolf
lng, John Dolan, Thomas Jennings, Mrs.
Leavy, Charles S. Noyes. Harry D. Roar
ers, Gottlieb Carle, George Carle, W. C.
Mysell.

-* very room; elevator runs all nlnh*, *KRUTTSCHNITT ADVANCED.
General Manager of the Southern Pacific Promoted
to the Fourth Vice-Presidencu.
Julius Kruttschnitt, the newly elected fourth vice president and gen
eral manager of the Southern Pacific Company, San Francisco, was born
July 30, ISo4, at New Orleans, La., and graduated ..s civil engineer from the
Engineering School of Washington and Lee University of Lexington, Va.,
In lv 3. He entered the railway service in IS7S, since which time he has
been consecutivelyâ July LISTS, to January, 1880 â engineer of the extension of
Morgan's Louisiana and Texas Railroad and Steamship Company; Janu
ary 1, ISSO, to April 1, ISSI, roadmaster of the western division, and April 1,
1881. to April 1, ISS3, assistant chief engineer and general roadmaster of the
same road. April l, ISS3, chief engineer and superintendent of Morgan's
Louisiana and Texas Railroad and Steamship Company; October 1, 18S5, to
July l, ISS9, assistant manager of the Atlantic system of the Southern Pa-
Company; July 1. 18S9, to October 1. 1896, general manager of the At
lantic system of the Southern Pacific Company; vice president of the Gal
veston, Harrisburg and San Antonio Railway and Texas and New Orleans
Railroad; president of the New York. Texas and Mexican, Gulf, Western,
Texas and Pacific, and Sabine and East Texas railways; October 1, 1595,
to date, general manager of all lines of the Southern Pacific Company.
"SINBAD" AT
THE TIVOLI
The Tivoll commenced Its silly season
lnst night with the new Easter piece,
â i. the Sailor." a typical Tivo'.i
burlesque, with everybody's music and
ly'a plot and no end of pictures,
dances, nonsense and noise. It Is the pol-
I the management to put on such
productions at regular Intervals and the
policy of its patrons to patronize them
handsomelyâ and as "Sinbad" is quite as
elabcrately and expensively gotten up as
nr.y of its predecessors, and the cast a
ne and a strong one, it is easy to
anucipate a popular run. Last night's
â  mance, In spite of the inevitable
jerks and drags of an opening*, was hi
rariously received by an audience that
led the doormat for space. After
once complimenting several of the scenic
sets, the costumes, the ballet and the ever
trusty chorus the applause all goes to the
Individual specialty work of the perf â¢rni
ers. wbo are the bulk of the entertain
ment. Turn follows turn with breathless
rapidity and in somewhat tactful va
riety. The spoken lines of the piece !
proper hardly ever are in evidence, which
Is doubly a good thine, since what little
there is of straight dialogue is even
worse than the usual Tivoli product.
UÂ£ the big casl Carrie Koma, Edwin
Elevens. Thomas Leary and "Bob' Mitch
o, enji yed particular prominence. Mr.
Leary, as Tmbad the Tailor, Insisted <>n
his by rather more noise than was vital;
Mr. Mitchell's was thrust upon him by
two-thirds of the audience, who. having
come in the capacity of personal friends
and admirers, were not to be dissuaded
merely because the management had
been so shortsighted as not to supply
"Bob" with a large, plump part.
Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Branson are cast
as a team of tax collectors and general
utility comedians, and they have small
chance of glory until in the hitter part
of the second act, when they stuff a cap
ital comic duet. When Mr. Mitchell's
opportunity finally did arrive he parted j
â with his nervousness and met it admira
bly, singing and dancing with the easy
humor and genial personality that have
long stood him in valuable stead. After
all then; is but little difference between
a good amateur and a good professional.
In responsibilities no greater than his in
"Sinbad" Mr. Mitchell does not need the
applause ot personal friendship to point
hia success.
Mr. Stevens is an Irish mariner this
time, and entirely unlike hims.-lf in any
other personation. In singing the "Bogie
Man" he misses that mystical i
which Norman used to give the song,
through hurrying it, and his "invisi
ble drill" scene is not worth the while;
) â¢ ! : these, and Castain Paul Jones
O'Scuttle is the best thing he has done
in many a day. Carrie Koma. an inval

C. P. HUNTINGTON SPEAKS.
Distinctly Denies the Story That He
Is Opposing the New Charter.
A story has been printed that C. P.
Huntington, president of the Southern
Pacific Company, is fighting the new
charter for San Francisco. The Call,
deeming it advisable to ascertain if the
story had any foundation in fact, sent
a reporter to interview the railroad
president on the topic.
It was some little time before Mr.
Huntington comprehended the meaning
of the Questions addressed to him. He
said that he did not know that a charter
was pending and certainly had no no
tion of opposing a measure before he
underFtood its provisions. He remarked:
"I have had no consultation with Mr.
Herrin or any cither officer of the com
pany on this subject. Any charter that
is agreeable to the voters of San Fran
cisco will suit the railroad company. If
property interests generally are pro
tected by the pending charter, I presume
railroad property will share In the gen
era: m<.asurÂ«? of protection. The people
of San Francisco evidently understand
the provisions of the proposed organic
act for the government of the city. I do
not understand that there is a proposi
tion pending to impair vested rights or
confiscate property. I apprehend that I
would be apprised of the fact If the
charter threatened to destroy property.
You can say distinctly that I have had
no conference with Mr. Herrin or any
one else connected with the company in
the matter of opposing or supporting the
proposed charter. The subject has not
been discussed or brought forward in
any form for consideration by the repre
sentatives of the Southern Pacific. We
can live under laws agreeable to other
property-owners."
Mr. Herrin of the law department of
the company was interviewed on the
same tonic. He denied without hesita
tion or qualification that he was oppos
ing the charter. He remarked: "1 have
had no conference on the subject of the
charter with C. P. Huntington. I have
not consulted with any of my associates
in the company on the subject. The
topic has not been discussed in my pres
ence and expression of my views as an
individual citizen has not been solicited."
Advances made on furniture and pianos, with
or without removal. J. Xoonan, 1017- 1023 Mission.

yesterday rendered a decree awarding
$1046 44 to the Black Diamond Coal Mining
Company in payment of the company's
claim against the steamer H. C. Grady;
also $1450 to sailors and other claimants
â  r wages, supplies, etc.

it to him secretly for a while, then I told him
of It so now I don't mind letting my name he
published. I am going to recommend it far and
near, so with many thanks I close. Respect-
fully, AMANDA CARTER."
And such cures as these remain so perma-
nently, even the worst cases where the habit
seems to have blotted out the last remaining
spark of self-respect. There are thousands of
women who would make almost any sacrifice
to throttle the rum demon.
Tears and prayers are of no use. Pleading,
pledges, loss of social or business positions are
unavailing to stem the tide of absolute deprav-
ity. This famous remedy, Golden Specific, dis-
covered by Dr. Haines, has reunited thousands
of scattered families, it has saved thousands
of men to social and business prominence and
public respect; has guided many a young man
into the right road to fortune; has saved the
father, the brother, the son and in many cases
the wife and daughter, too. Such a Godsend
to the fireside should be known to everyone.
Dr. Haines is not a philanthropist In his own
estimation, and yet he is one of the greatest
benefactors to the family we know of. Upon
application to I>r. J. W. Haines, 218 Glenn
building, Cincinnati, 0.. he will mall a free
sample of the remedy to you. securely sealed
In a plain wrapper; also full directions how to
use it. books and testimonials and everything
