HOW TO SUCCEED
AS A MINISTER.
*i Believe a .Minister's Duties Divide
Themselves Under Two .Heads ; .His
Work, as a Preacher and as a
Pastor ."â By Dr. John 'flail.
Wi:AT 1i ministerial success?
Not the attraction of a
crowd, nor the awakening of
admiration for an "elegant
preacher,' a "brilliant speak
er," a "splendid ore-tor." What is a
minister? An embassador of Christ, be
seeching men to bo reconciled to God
through him. The success is to be
measured by the extent to which this
reconciliation is promoted.
Buppoee that tho Spanish Government
sent an embassador to Cuba to beseech
the rebels to be at peace with Spain,
ar.d the embasssdor was described as
"eloquent," "brilliant." "very interest-
Ing." in his address to the rebels, and
by them, yet they held on In their rebel
lionâ could he be described as success
ful?
This article, as I understand it. Is not
to deal with the choice of the ministry
as a profession. The young men to
whom it ia addressed are supposed to
have settled that momentous question
In the affirmative. They desire now
only the few suggestions that experi
ence ran give to inexperience as a,
guide in their life work.
A minister's duties divide themselves
under two headsâ his work as a preach
er and as a pastor. Neither one should
be emphasized to the neglect of the
other. Some men succeed in the for
mer field and fall in the latter, or vice
versa, but to make his efforts effective
for the promotion of God's truth the
minister should labor assiduously In
both.
As a preacher the minister Is called
upon to prepare and deliver sermons to
his congregation. In this the first thing
to determine Is his range of subjects.
On this point Christ has explicitly di
rected us, "Whatsoever I have com
manded you." To the appreciative stu
dent of the Bible this Is sufficiently
definite, and rules out many themes
that have found their way into the
Christian pulpit.
The central figure of all Bible teach
ing, the most effective that the preach
er cati present, the one he is especially
enjoined to herald is the Christ.
This should be his constant theme.
IK is to lift up Christ, to set forth his
saving work as finished on the cross,
and to show that while he is Prophet,
to bo our teacher, and King to rule
over us, it is by his atoning death that
we have lite through beiie*ing in him.
This is glorying in the cross.
This presentation of Christ implies
the setting forth of God's attributes as
holy, just, merciful and faithful, man's
sinful condition, and it Implies obliga
tion on men, when they believe in and
love the Savior, to keep his command
ments. And so true evangelical
hing is the divinely given means
for producing good ethical results â for
promoting morality.
This exhibition of Christ's saving
work is to be presented in reliance on
the Holy Spirit, not in one's genius,
persuasiveness or earnestness; and
then, when souls are saved and
brought to confess Christ, the glory is
given to him who opens the eyes,
creates anew in Christ, and Is, in the
!ife of a believer, the spiiit of holiness.
It may be objected that this preach
ing of Christ puts away variety from
the pulpit and produces a dull same
ness In the sermons. If hearers are
simply looking for entertainment, for
â 'sensational" talk of "the times," they
will sympathize with this criticism;
but if they attend church to worship
God, and be taught of Christ, they will
find variety in the teaching, for In the
history of the race from the opening
chapter of Genesis through the Mosaic
economy, the history of the Hebrews,
the works of the prophets and all the
New Testament, Christ, the Savior,
and the godliness that comes through
faith in him. are more or less clearly
set forth, and that in beautifully varied
aspects.
There are many useful points about
the preparation and presentation of
pulpit discourses, but most of these the
young man will hear fully discussed In
the course of his special preparation.
No scientific knowledge, no classic, no
learning, no human truth comes amiss
to the preacher, yet there have been
many men with '"little Latin and less
Greek" who have mightily influenced
the lives and aspirations of their fel
lows toward the kingdom of God.
The bent cardinal rule I can think of
is to know your Bible (the English
version) thoroughly. Know It so well
that you can draw readily on it for apt
quotation to enforce and emphasize
your points. "When it enmes to utter
ing a grand truth or voicing an eternal
warning, the language of the bouk is
more forcible, more convincing, sticks
more firmly in the mind of the hearer,
than any you can command.
The tone of the preacher In his pulpit,
In my opinion, should bo positive, not
argumentative. We are not philoso
phers finding out things; we are exposi
tors of a revelation that settles things.
When Jesus said, "I am the way, the
truth, the life; no man cometh to the
Father but by me," he spoke positive
truth, which it is our business to echo
Let authors, poets and philosophers
have the fipld of speculation and imagi
nation. "We, my brethren, give our
selves to another task. We are to di
rect human pilgrims, according to set
tled and fixed commandments from the
Lord, into the way that leads through
'.he gate into the city.
That part of his duties comprised in
his work as a pastor the young man

Don-a-wauk looked at him contemptuously and

have sold our country, Indians and all; you speak of
houses, buildings and forts, but not one word of the In
dian. You," he continued, pointing to the baron,

promised the Indian much. When you came you said
you would build us sawmills, schoolhouses and
churches. You said you would teach us how to use
the soil for food as well as the sea. You taught my
people how to drink fire water, that is all. Indian
drink until his head is lost, and then he make bad
bargain. You get rich, he get poor."

needs to be especially reminded of. It
is the side of his work that he is likely
to hoar and to think least of during
his period of preparation.
To fill the requirements of his place In
the congregation, the minister must
know his people. How is he to know
them? Obviously the best way to make
their acquaintance is to go to their
homes, to see the family where the
family lives, and converse with them
in the freedom of their own homes. He
may direct this part of his work as hia
special situation makes it seem best,
but he should go among his people as
much and as often as he can.
Any ordinary minister who Is to do
spiritual good to his people must love
them. Ordinary men found their affec
tionate Interest on acquaintance. It Is
not love in general and in the abstract
that makes a channel to the human
J>ART 111.
spirit, but love to Individuals, into
whose faces and in some degree into
whose hearts you have looked.
All this will make the pastor a better
preacher. A man tells you of his life,
his sorrows, perhaps his sins; his lip
quivers and his c" cs overflow in the
recital. If you have the first elements
of a minister's nature in you. you must
feel and speak to that man evermore
with some influential memory of the
Interview.
It may be added thnt the life of a
preacher is to be in harmony with the
truth that is taught. He must show by
his walk and conversation that the
message he carries is true to himself,
firmly believed an-1 sincerely acted
upon.
Let It be said, Jn conclusion, that
ministerial success is not to be meas
ured by the audience, the crowd, the

was to go with the sailors to his father, and she would

again and again. When the sailors reached the shore
and approached her, she told them that in anticipa

of 11-la-hie. The unsuspecting sailors took the boy
without further inquiry.
Louise and Don-a-wauk stood and watched. The

God!" A voice of a child was heard, and, looking up.
Louise saw the boy of 11-la-hie. "Where Is my
mother?" he asked.
Louise looked down upon the poor deserted, moth
erless child, and with a cold and heartless smile the
replied: "Gone!"
That night the storm came, and the wind blew.
Away up on the mountain side the dim rays of a can
dle shone through the rifts of a cabin wall. Within
sat Captain Prim. He was writing to his wife, 11-la
hie, telling her of his coming home, and how happy
they would be. Before he had finished he heard the
crashing of trees above his cabin roof. He ran to the
door, but It was too late. The great landslide of Ka
rakk Mountain was upon him. It crushed his cabin
like an egrgshell, and beneath the avalanche of stone
the body of Cantain Prim lay entombed.

>f Baron Oranoff, at one time Governor of the Ter

ng a company of Russian capitalists, who are

In the province of Vladimir, fall on these llnet, he will

Don-a-wauk, now eighty-one years of age, is liv
ing to this day in the Indian village at Sitka.
When he heard of the tragedy on the trail he ex
claimed: "The son of 11-la-hie shall not lie as food
for the crows!" and taking a small company of In
dians he rescued the body and gave it a burial after
the fashion of his tribe, by wrapping it in skins and
placing it in a covered canoe, hung on poles.
Bruin, the terrier widely known as the Hertford
shire Collecting Dog, has just died at his home at
Ware. Bruin was a genius at collecting money
on behalf of some charitable fund. His method
when soliciting subscriptions was to stand be
fore his object of appeal and bark persistently
until such object produced a coin, which the
intelligent creature promptly carried in his
mouth and placed in the collecting box in Mb master's
possession. In this way Bruin has raised large sums
of money for the crippled children's dinner in London
for the Prince erf Wales' Hospital fund, for the recent
hospital fund at Ware and other charitable institu
tions. v\ hen he became hungry he would beg for cop
pera on his" own behalf. On receiving them he would ,
quickly carry them to a neighboring shop where he "k
was known and obtain some biscuits In exchange

TALKIN* of the loss of the Almy
said the old shellback, as he
thoughtfully borrowed my to
bacco pouch and forgot to return
it -reminds me of an experience
I once had in the North Pacific . â¢ J
were near goln' the way of the Aim*
people? too. S only a mailboat come along
and picked us lit voyage of the old
"It was the last voyage of the old
bark Iris, a good ship in her daj . too.
But she was built way back in the
fifties in Maine, and. in the natural
course of events, she had grown tired
of sailing around the seas, and her
butts were apt to open now and again
at inconvenient times. We loaded up
our lumber at Portland and set sail for
Sydney, In Australia. But we^ne%er
got there, leastwise the bark didn t.
"We had only been out a couple of
days when we fetched right into a stiff
northerly blow, and the old bark kicked
up her heels tremendous. First we
tried running her under the lower
main topsail and the forestaysail. but
it wasn't any good. She had a heavy
deckload of timber and was very slug
gish, so that time and again sh^
pooped, the cabin was flooded, and the
wheel smashed into little bits. I don t
know where the man at the wheel
went, but we never saw him again.
"Then we got relieving tackles onto
the tiller, and hove her to with a tar
paulin in the mizzen shrouds. But it
wasn't much better so, the sea was
that heavy. Every plunge she made
seemed as if it would shake her rotten
old frame into little bits.
'â¢We pumped, it seemed to me, for
an eternity, but we couldn't make any
impression on the water in the hold.
It -ained on us all the time, for all the
seams were working loose by this time,
and if you looked over the rail between
the seas -< ou could see the oakum com
ing out. After a couple of days' hard
work, we found it was no use, and we
gave up pumping. Part of the deck
le- had already washed away, and the
rest we soon chucked overboard, so as
to lighten the ship a bit.
"The only good thing about a timber
laden craft is that she can't sink, ev
erything else is bad. Her cargo keeps
her afloat till she goes to pieces, and.
all we could do was to sit down and
wait until pome one cams along to takÂ«
us off. All our boats was long since
knocked to bits, but if they had been
there I don't know that we should
have cared much about taking to them
in such a sea. We were better off on
board the bark, bad as she was.
"The mizzen mast, being an old stick,
soon went by the board; our rudder
knocked into little pieces; we couldn't
steer or do anything, and we just hud
dled together on the poop. Luckily there
was a cask of water on deck which
hadn't been carried away, and being
tightly bunged the water was still
sweet. We made shift to get this up
on the poop, and we lived there for
about a week, drenched all the time
with salt water and eating nothing but
the cold stuff we could get from the
cabin lockers. The galley was long
since gutted, '.nd even if it had been
there, no cook living could have kept
a fire going. The main deck was
awash all the time, the bulwarks were
carried away pretty well fore and aft,
and it was as much as a man's life
was worth to try and get from the
poop to the forecastle.
"Wonder I lived through it, you say?
It was a wonder, but a man will do a
lot when struggling for :is life. But
that week's setting 1 there in wet
clothes give me chronic rheumatiz,
which nothing but a drop o' whisky
now and agin will keep under."
The old sailor touched his cap, as If
to emphasize the gentle hint, and in
the snug shelter of a neighboring sa
loon completed the tale of his rescue.
"The old hark was commencing to gr>
to pieces pretty fast, we could see. Bits
of her sheathing would come float
ing up alongside, and the hatches
burst up, so that the cargo was float
ing out from below. The sea was still
running heavy, and we knew that if
another blow came along it would fin
ish her and us. Then, one morning,
the skipper sings out: 'There's smoko
astern, boys.' Sure enough, we could
just make out a cloud behind us and
by and by it grew bigger, so that we
made sure it was a steamer coming
our way. There weren't any flags
left, so we tied a shirt to the stump
of the mizzenmast by way of a signal
of diAress. It didn't want any signal,
thaugh, to show the state we were in,
and as soon as the steamer sighted us
she altered her course a point or so aad
bore down.
"She was a welcome sight to us, as
she came sweeping along, her black
sides gleaming with the wet sea. and
her long line of brass-lined ports shin
ing with fresh polish. We could see
the passengers crowding to the side and
knew they were watching us through
their glasses. Then she stopped. Just
to windward of us, and we. saw the life- I
boat drop from her davits like a flash.
It was the prettiest sight I have ever
seen, I can assure you. Having the
wind and the sea with them, they were
alongside in no time, and I can tell you
we didn't mind jumping into the sea to
be rescued a bit. We were wet any
way as it was and the sea was too
heavy for the boat to lay alongside.
"They â¢ rolled us up in warm blan
kets and gave us hot grog, and I never
felt so comfortable in my life, for I
slept twenty-four hours straight off the
reel. As for the old bark, we left
her there, and I suppose she soon went
to pieces, for we never heard of her
again." J. F. ROSE-3OLEY.FIGHTING FOR ISLAM
ON THE AFGHAN BORDER
LAST ASS/\ULJ OF THE ZEALOUS JWbL^JI JO DJRIVE THE CJtoSS BEFORE TJIE GJ?ESCEfIT.
"VOien you're wounded and left on Afghanis
tan's plains.
And the women come out to cut up what re
niains.
Just roll to your rifle and blow out your
brnlns
An' so to your Gawd like a soldier."
THUS the omniscient Kipling In
his advice to a young British
soldier. It is not pleasant ad
vice, certainly, but those who
understand the manner in which
the wild hill tribes of Northern
India mutilate their dead enemies will
realize Ita soundness. It is a long es
taMished Mohammedan custom, al
ii part of thoir religion, to inflict
every possible Indignity on the body of
r. foe, and the women who perform this
hideous task would bp little likely to
hesitate because the soldier was still
living.
The English speaking world has re
cently been furnished with a vivid pic
ture of the difficulties attendant upon
a campaign in Afghanistan, where the
troops, in the face of a determined
enemy, have to make their way
through precipitous defiles and over
almost inaccessible crags. Lieutenant
"\V. L. Spencer Churchill, a scion of the
jrreat Marlborough family, has just
published a book which has taken Lion
don by storm. He details his experi
ence with the Malakand expeditionary
force, and the picture which he drews Is
by no means a reassuring one for the
British taxpayer, who will eventually
have to foot India's little bill for cam
paign warfare.
It is really a holy war, Islam against
the Cross, and ranged under their
sacred banner, th^ Afridis commit
deeds of fanatical heroism which excite
the admiration even of their enemies.
Churchill tells us how, in the midst of
a hot engagement, a Mollah or priest
â would suddenly appear on the pin
nacle of some beetling crag, his long
whit^ hair f.owing behind him, the holy
.rratped in his hand, encouraging
his fiillM\vers, both by gesture and
to renew their heroic efforts. The
appearance < f the Mollah always acted
like a talisman on the superstitious
Afridis, and he Be -mcd. indeed, to bear
a charmed life, for, though the bullets
whistled around him, he was never
t' ai.hed.
The impossibility of abandoning the
wounded makes fighting, for the Eng
lish troops, a very difficult matter. The
Afghans give no quarter; they have
their own code of honor, but it is not
the code of the civilized world. To the
ferocity of a Zulu they add the craft of
a Redskin and the markmanship of a
lioer. The world is presented with the
grim spectacle, "the strength of civil
ization without its mercy."
It seems strange to read of such bar
baric warfare in these advanced days,
but. as a matter of fact, the strife is al
ways going on. It is one of the legacies
of trouble which Great Britain's mag
nificent possessions in India have
brought her. Afghanistan itself, which
now forms the only boundary between
Russia in Asia and England in India,
is merely a collection of unruly hill
tribes, wild mountaineers whom no
government can tame. Even the Ameer
of Afghanistan has no power to keep
them in check, though his rule is ab
solutely despotic, and he enforces order
by the sword only. The country has
r been subdued by any monarch;
the hardy hill tribes who inhabit the
f;iPtnesFes of the Hindu Kush and the
Himalaya ranges will pay tribute to no
one, though they are always ready to
rob and murder whenever opportunity
occurs.
The very name of the State is of quite
modern origin, and is due to the Per
sians, who made a show of conquer
ing the land in 1735. The Persian rule,
however, did not last long, and the
country returned to its own unsettled
condition, nominally ruled by whoever
could seize the throne, might being al
ways right, and law and justice no
where.
This constant state of activity and
|T WAS LIKE CLIMBING A WALL, AND A HUNDRED TIMES AS DANGEROUS, TRYING TO REACH THE
/iFRIDIS' STRONGHOLD.
unrest has made the Afghans one of
the finest fighting races in the world,
as the British have time and again
found out to their cost. Despite the
large force which was sent against the
Afridis last autumn the tribes are still
unsubdued and the task will all have
to be done over again as soon as the
return of spring renders renewed fight
ing possible.
The mountainous nature of the coun
try gives its defenders every advantage.
It is but a succession of precipitous
ranges, each one forming an impregna
ble position which a few determined
men can hold against thousands. And
when, as at Darghai, one mountain is
captured, with great gallantry and loss
of life, the victors are only confronted
with another and equally strong posi
tion, which must likewise be stormed.
The difficulty of obtaining supplies and
kef-plpp- open the line of communication
renders the movement of any very large
force impossible, and the only way In
which victory can eventually be se
cured Is by hemming the tribes up on
sr.me mountain top and literally stirv
ing" them into submission.
This <tyle of border warfare Is no
new thing to the Guides and other regi
ments which constantly patrol il c
northwest frontier of India. The only
difference is that of size. The expedi
tion against the Afridis was under
taken on an extensive scale, therefore
it was called a war. The small expedi
tions which are constantly going on to
discipline some unruly tribe or other
are never officially recognized in this
light; the Government of India pru
dently says as little about them as pos
sible, and the British public never re
alizes that another successful little war
has been brought to a termination.
Sometimes, as at Chittral, the massa
cre of a British party throws a ghastly
light on the affair, and It becomes
I necessary to occupy the countiv in
â  force; at other times the troops, having
I Dhiwn up a few mud forts and de-
Btroyed a f-:w villages qui-jt-.v wilh
; draw and amicable relations with the
I tribe are resumed.
It costs the Indian Government a
' large amount of money to preserve even
: a semblance of peace on the border,
: for ever since the first disastrous Af
ghan campaign of 1839, it haa been
found cheaper to subsidize the tribes
than to fight them. If a headman will
govern his people in quiet, avoid raid
' ing, and keep the passes open, then he
will get an annual payment, if not, then
he will have to fight the British. Be
â  fore any hostile operations can be
! carried on in Afghanistan, the passes
must be secured. Especially the fam
ous Khyber Pass, through which the
river Kabul makes its escape from the
ranges of the Hindu Kush to the plains
nf the Pur.jaub. Every expedition of
I any size which has entered Afghanis
tan has gone through this pass, and it
was the neglect to secure it properly
which led to the terrible disaster of 1842,
; one of the most severe defeats which
i British arms have ever sustained.
It is always Russian intrigue which.
I commences the trouble in Afghanistan.
: The recent rising of the Afridis is more
than suspected to be due to a secret
agitation carried on by Russian agents,
though the Ameer has been careful to
deny any complicity in the actions ot
his unruly subjects. But in 1839 there
was no doubt about the matter. The
Ameer of the day, Dost Mohammed,
was openly dallying with Russia, and
i the British sent an expedition under
Sir John Keane, which dethroned him
and placed Shah Shuja on the throne.
Unfortunately Afghan treachery was
not so thurousrhly Understood then as
i it is now. and the force of 8000 men, left
.to support the new monarch on the
j throne, took no precautions to keep
i open its line of retreat to India. In
consequence the Afghans soon organ
. ized an insurrection against their new
; ruler and his friends, the English. The
I whole country rose, and after a num
j ber of nffu-prs, and even helpless wo
: men and children, had been treacher
i ously murdered, the British made a
treaty with the Afghans, agreeing to
withdraw from the country, on condi
tion of being supplied with provisions
and escorted in safety to the frontier.
Neither clause of this agreement was
kept. In the middle of winter, In tho
i bitter cold, without food, the troops b<*
; gan their disastrous retreat. Day after
THE SAX FRANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APRIL 10, 1898.
day they were attacked by large bodies
of the enemy, and within a week the
whole force, which numbered, includ
ing campfollowers, women and chil
dren, some 26,000, was destroyed.
The defeat, of course, was redressed
Kabul was retaken, but no subsequent
victories could restore the lost army
nor the Innocent women and children
who had fallen. And ever since then
India has been most careful to keep
control of the passes, hence the deter
mination with which she has gone to
work, at any cost, to subdue the Afridi
rising, for this tribe has been the guar
dian of the Khyber pass since 1880.
Lord Roberts, now a British peer, but
more familiarly known as "Bobs of
Kandahar," because of his famous
march from Kabul to Kandahar, is rec
ognized as one of the greatest living
authorities on the subject. In a re
markable speech which he made the
other day In the House of Lords he ad
vocated, as the easiest way out of the
difficulty, nothing less than the com
plete occupation of Afghanistan, and
the adoption of a scientific frontier cal
culated to block all Russian advances
toward India, Probably the enormous
cost of this scheme will prevent its
adoption, but It would have the ad
vantage of making the British frontier
conterminous with that of Russia, so
that the game of Intrigue hitherto so
successfully carried on in the buffer
state of Afghanistan would have to
cease. Also all the unruly tribes would
become British subjects and their paci
fication would be only a matter of time
and tactful treatment.
How little we really know of the In
terior of this part of Asia hap been
painfully illustrated by the awful late
of Walter Savage Landor, the well
known writer and explorer. Landor
was fired with ambition to visit the
sacred city of L'hassa, tho mysterious
home of the Lamas, in Thibet, one of
the few spots in the world which has
n^ver been explored by Europeans. He
started with a large expedition, but
most of his followers deserted him, and
the natives, discovering his identity,
made him a prisoner.
Apparently with the object of seeing
how much pain a white man could bear
without dying, they subjected him to
every variety of diabolical torture, and
Landor was only rescued at the last
moment by a British expedition which
heard of his predicament. And now,
with a courage which borders on rash
ness, a young American, Mr. W. Jame
son Reid, is about to attempt the same
feat. His plan is to get himself smug
gled into L'hassa in a basket of goods,
slung on a camel. Should he succeed
where Landor failed, it will be a re
mnrkable testimony to American enter
prise, but 'the odds are very much
against him. M. ROSE-SOLEY.
The Beautifying Bath.
It is not infrequently said that a
daily bath is weakening. This is such a
great mistake that it is difficult to un
derstand haw it is ever made. A daily
bath is just as necessary to bodily pur
ity as. daily prayers are to soul purity,
and it should be as conscientiously tak
en. In some place, and at some time
that cannot be recalled, this observa
tion has come to my notice, and its
truth made its Impression a lasting
one: "A lady bathes not to get clean,
but to stay clean."
It is true that remaining too long in
the bath may be weakening, but a
quick bath in either very warm or even
hot water, followed by a cold dash,
has only good effects.
A refreshing and practical bath is one
in moderately hot water with a little
sea salt in it â sea salt is practical and
chear> â pure white soap, a sponge and
a cheese cloth washrag. Cheese cloth
is both practical and cheap, and at the
same time sufficiently rough to remove
all dirt and not rough enough to
scratch. The sponge must serve as the
shower bath, and after the body is
thoroughly dry rubbing corn meal or
bran over it makes the skin soft and
velvety.
The use of a bag of bran instead of
a washrag is much favored by the
French women for the softening effect
it has upon the water and its tendency
to make the skin delicately white and
smooth. But no bath is perfect in its
results unless followed by a brisk and
vigorous friction of the hands or rub
bing with a coarse towel. â Katherine
Eggleston Junkermann in* March
Woman's Home Companion.
EASTER CUSTOMS
OF MANY LANDS.
THE loss Informed orthodox
Greeks in Alexandria will assure
you that their Easter Sunday â
which does not fall upon the
same day as that of the Cath-
lle Greeks â is regulated by the
cessation of the celebration of the Jew
ish paÃsover which it immediately fol
lows.
With them Easter services begin at
midnight and continue until dawn. The
day is regarded as a holiday and also
the most important one of the year,
and, if possible, no member of their
usually large oriental families Is ever
absent from such, as to remain away
on this occasion is considered a great
misfortune.
Every one Is attired as handsomely
as his means allow, and many as
sume the Greek national costume and
medals or badges are suitably dis
played.
Among the vast congregations none
watch the ceremony of the swaying
lights which accompany the first burst
of music, or follow the long and Im
pressive services with more interest, if
not comprehension, than the children,
who have previously taken such active
Interest in decorating the church can
dles with sprigs of olive upon Palm
Sunday, and who apparently have no
present desire for their beds or slum
ber.
When that part of the service Is re
peated which tells of Christ's ascension
from the tomb, which is the signal for
the choir to swell into joyful mustÂ«>,
and the deafentn~ reports of the vari
ous firearms discharged about the ca
thedral doors to ring out, they show
their great appreciation of the absorb
ing sounds, and the Impression that
Easter Sunday is the one day of the
year is indelibly stamped upon thoir
minds.
Instead of their usual simple break
fast, the meal served on their return
home and which breaks the Lenten
fast, always strictly observed by them,
begins with song, consists of many
courses and ends with dessert. After
this meal presents are distributed
among the immediate members of the
family, usually consisting of useful
things, such as necessary clothing
among the poorer classes, while the
rich give costumes both handsome and
costly, which are always more valued
The Mollah, sacred teacher of the Koran, sprang to the topmost pinnacle of the crag, pointing with one hand to the British soldiers below, in the other
waving the holy flag of Islam. His fanatical followers pressed close behind him, and leaping over the crest of the mountain, hurled themselves downward on the
foe, rolling great rocks before them as they went. The Mollah seemed to bear a charmed life, for though hundreds of rifles were aimed at him, and bullets whis
tled all around, he escaped unscathed.
by the recipients for being Easter gifts.
The home ceremonies disposed of, the
day is given up to calling upon friends
and receiving guests, and every one is
prepared to entertain.
As with other nations, eggs figure
conspicuously upon this day, and great
care and often skill is given to their
decoration. These are taken as gifts
to friends, and among the children a
particularly thick-shelled one is re
served by each, to be pitted against
those of their friends in the hope oi
winning numerous others.
The tiny cup of black coffee which
it is always customary to offer callers
is upon that day replaced by numerous
sweetmeats, cakes of all kinds predomi
nating, from the huge pyramid-shaped
loaf to the small imitation of an egg,
which proves to be a spoonful of fruit
and spices.
The gTeat quantity of eggs designed
aa gifts for calling friends are also ar
ranged In attractive or suggestive
shapes for the occasion, such as the
pyramids, crocodiles, a familiar cathe
dral, and even the Sphinx is attempted.
Friends greet each other with mu
tually expressed wishes for msfny hap
py returns of the day, and father, sons.
brothers and male friends emphasize
these wishes by kisses and embraces
bestowed upon one another as do the
gentler sex. Their Easter rejoicings
extend throughout the following Mon
day and Tuesday, and it is a time for
general good will, for the settling of
paÂ«t differences, and, like our Christ
mas, a time to remember the poor.
Easter Sunday in the Canton of
Chaux de Fonds, Switzerland, is given
over to amusements for children prln-
clpally.
It is not unusual for the snow to Ho
deeply in the gardens at Easter, but
the little baskets claimed by each child
of a family have been filled with
colored eggs and hidden among the
shrubs, and are perhaps covered un
der the snow still falling.
The gardens are all alive with little
bobbing heads as they hunt the bas
kets, representing nests, which the
hares of the forest are supposed to fill.
When the nests have been found and
the little numb hands warmed, they at
tend 9 o'clock service with their parents
and remain for Sunday-school, which
begins at 11 o'clock, for each one is
sure to receive a beautiful card picture
and an egg, nicely painted, from her
teacher.
After the church services the entire
family, dressed in the national costume
LAST MAD RUSH OF THE HILL MEN.
of their canton, meet their friends and
forming parties take the children pic
nicking, as they term it, though the
picnic is held at an inn instead of under
the trees as later in the season.
Everybody buys the enormous braid
ed Easter cakes, displayed in the bak
eries, and which are filled with almond
kernels and raisins, and the children
pass their day with eating cakes,
sweetmeats and in â  laying games, they
as well as the Greek children counting
that the best of all in which they try
to break the shells of their companions'
eggs with one they hope may be thicker,
for the boy or girl who wins the most
Easter eggs in this way is quite a lion
with the rest.
On returning home the children of
each family shell the eggs that remain,
and a huge dish of salad is made from
them, with a simple dressing and with
out greens, which they partake of for
supper. After this the father amuses
them as he himself was amused on
Easter evening when a boy, by hang
ing beyond easy reach a pole, from five
to six feet in length, wo-und with tis
sue paper in the national colors of
green, red and white, and upon which
he has strung 1 great delicious crullers
shaped like pretzels, and to secure them
the children must jump very high In
deed.
A former resident of this Swiss vil
lage remarked that the streets of
American towns upon the sth of July
presented the same untidy apppearance
as those of her childhood's home the
Monday following Easter, with the dif
ference that one was thickly strewn
with ragged, exploded firecrackers and
the other with shattered eggshells.
In Mexico the day which follows j
"Glorious Saturday" is not a day of
feasting, as Easter Sunday is ther^
considered the last day of Lent and
the people are still observing the fast.
The altars in the churches are, how
ever, relieved of the gloomy black dra
peries which covered them and decked
with flowers. The people also cast I
aside the mourning of Holy Thursday
and appear in their brightest attire, the |
dreary wooden grind of the matracns
give place to pealing bells. The tables !
filling the squares about the church j
doors, and upon which all kinds of i
tempting edibles, sweets, children's toys
and harmless drinks wore displayed for
sale during holy week are removed.
The young men and women, at other
times sternly restricted, who took ad- j
vantage of the throngs of worshipers
and the preoccupation of their elders
to exchange glances and form acquain
tances, now walk solemnly or demure
ly into the churches, their thoughts ap
parently occupied with nothing save
the services, beginning with high mass.
Amid the pealing of bells at the stroke
of 9, the hour at which Christ was
supposed to have arisen, the effigies of
Judas, which have been filled with ex
plosives, are touched off, and with the
deafening reports and vibrations Eas
ter services begin.
The Emerald 1 a is in no wise be
hind the rest pf Christendom in its.
celebration of Easter. It is hailed as
a day of joy and gladness by all good
Christians. The festivities as a matter
of course are enjoyed in proportion to
the means at hand, and, in the rural
districts, usually end with a little inno
cent merrymaking.
The day comes when nature is begin
ning to look beautiful. She is already
clothed in her garment of rich Irish
green, and the primrose â the first flower
of the spring â greets the eyo in all di
rections.
At the sign of the Bell, on the road to
Clonmel,
Paddy llegerty kept a nate shebeen.
â Old song.
Along the shores of Lough Mask
and Lough Corrib, in the province of
Connaught, the villages at the time I
write of were very numerous and
thickly populated with a sturdy and
healthy looking peasantry. Their
habits were primitive and their mode of
living from necessity very simple. Tak
ing^lnto consideration the way they
were handicapped in the struggle for
existence, they were wonderfully light
hearted.
It might be some wayside shebeen or
more likely a widow who, to try to keep
the wolf â or the agent, which is about
the same â f'om the door, would try to
turn an honest penny by giving the
cake on "Alsther Sunday."
The music comes next In order and
the best piper available is engaged to
furnish It. Other minor preparations
are seen to and when the cake is
brought home little else remains to be
done.
Easter Sunday begins with a dance.
It may not be generally known, and the
information be rather startling, that
the sun dances in that country on Eas-
Imorn! Well, if the outside world
ds in ignorance of it that's no fault
le people who live by Lough Mask,
who are able are out of bed at
n to see that wonderful perform
>. Nor are they disappointed. He
jre to be at his brightest on that
icular morning, and he does dance
t gleefully for at least fifteen min
after rising, to the intense delight
is beholders, then dismissing them
appy mood to enjoy the Easter egg
t and prepare for the religious ob
ance of the day.
Early in the afternoon preparations
for the dance begin. It is to be held
out of doors; usually on the public
road, a -potato garden being of more
benefit to the Irish cottager than a
"lawn" and far more in keeping with
his humble abode. The road is broad
and in good repair and a convenient
spot, well freed from dust, answers the
purpose very well. Borrowed and im
provised seats are placed on both Bides,
the piper's chair in its proper place and
all's ready.
A long-handled churn dash is fas
tened securely on the garden wall. The
cake is brought out, covered with a
snow white cloth, placed on the dash
in full view, and there left to play its
part.
The piper has arrived and is "dis
coursing" a few plaintive and sweet
old melodics â some of which even a
Patti might delight inâ to the admira
tion of the nearest neighbors, who have
come to welcome him. He plays on the
instrument known as the union pipes,
the wind being supplied by bellows at
tached to the elbow. He is blindâ most
Irish pipers are. I knew of but one who
was not. Yet he finds his way along
highways and byways without trouble.
His services are paid for by the danc
ers, each of whom drops a coin on the
plate that is placed beside him. "Pay
ing the piper" is proverbial.
The young people may now be seen
coming from every direction. Their
make-up is not quite as romantic look
ing as that of the Swiss or French
peasant, but they more than equal it
by their fine, healthy appearance. Dan
! cinq has commenced, and all seem to
i be enjoying themselves. The dancap are
not of the hugging variety. They are
more of the "stand off" kind. Jigs and
I reels were good enough fr â¢ them, with
an occasional country dance, led by one
or two of the more accomplished.
The dances go merrily on until dusk.
Nearing that time the cake, which hith
| erto, beyond a passing glance, has been
j taken little notice of, is now becoming
of deep interest, particularly to the wo
men folks. "And I wonder who's goin'
to bring in the cake," is whispered from
one to another.
The last dance Is called, and it prom
ises to be a lively one. So it is. One
couple after another drop out, and with
a bow and curtsey to the musician
stand aside. It may be two or it may
be but one couple who now hold the
floor and dance with more than usual
snirit. If the former â which seldom
happens â one couple good naturedly
gives way. The other keep on dancing
and putting in their best stept, the
crowd cheering. After tiring themselves
out both walk in the direction of the
cake amid more cheering. The "boy"
climbs up, takes it off its perch and
puts it in the "Colleen's" apron, which
she holds in readiness to receive it. She
carries it in â weighty as it is â and is
followed by "both their houses," to do
hnnor to the occasion and the land
lady.
The cutting of the cake devolves on
the lady who Lrought it in. She first
cuts out a liberal center piece which
she hands to the landlady. Then glanc
ing around she measures the house
and cuts accordingly. The next day an
elderly lady may be heard to ask, "and
who brought in the cake last night?"
Then, on being informed, "Was it now?"
"Troth an' sorra purtier couple in the
parish; an' its a weddin' we'll ioon
be bavin."

T< ) be well bonneted on Easter
Sunday is an adjunct as essen
tial to religious harmony as It is
a desire distinctly feminine. For,
"This is the day, and this the happy
morn.
When her flower of a bonnet is Just In
bloom."
This is the season when her hat is
trimmed to order on the congregation
side. To be obliged to wear an old
or an unbecoming bonnet on this day
ys is a severe pe. ance. And these
thoughts are certainly disturbing to the
.1 attitude of prayer.
That these sentiments are not wholly
th>* ;-i.mopoly of youth, some of our
representative women have given tes
timony in their reminiscent Easter bon
net trials.
"I really never attached much impor
tance to Easter bonnets until this
year," said Mrs. Nellie Blessing Eyster.
"I can scarcely tell why I should do
S3 row; but I must admit that I took
. onsiderable pride in this pink and
1 rown creation. Just to get a friend's
opinion one day last week I pulled the
bandbox containing it from under the
bed and found the latest (litter) ary
event of my household. The crown of
my bonnet was filled to the brim with
a litter of Madame Tiger's kittens.
"This is the first Easter that
I have had to purchase two bonnets for
the one occasion, and perhaps it is the
most important one; but it is not my
earliest Easter bonnet trial. This oc
curred in Baltimore when I was a girl.
It was my first visit to a city and I
found it a place of wonders. It wa3
the day before Easter, and I was go
ing to see the Mermaid, the beautiful
lady with long golden hair and a fish's
tail.
"Po tedious is this day.
As in the night before some festival
To an Impatient child that hath newrobea
And may not wear them."
"I worried my governess until
Bhe granted me the indulgence of wear
ing my new bonnet to the Zoo. Such
crowds of people were there and so
many things to look at that I grew im
patient to s<-e this wonderful mermaid.
I saw it and the pet illusion of my
childhood was destroyed. It made me
iT"?? to see such an ugly thing, and as
I turned away I saw in the distance a
girl with a bonnet on just like mine
âbut my, what shocking behavior!
Even at this distance I could detect
her supercilious airs. While she dis
gusted, still she attracted me, and I
found myself advancing toward her and
I was surprised to see her walk to
ward me. She was my own reflection
in a mirror. I tried to sooth my wound
< 1 vanity by getting even with the
monkeys. I poked the little ones with
my parasol until my bonnet was
snatched from my head by a big mon
key, that, unperceived by me, had
crawled up the bars above me, and in
a twinkling he doused it into a pan of
water within the cage. In less than
a minute each monkey had some rem
nant of that bonnet. Lace, ribbon and
flowers were trailed through the ivist.
"My governess converted her veil
Into a head-dress for me to wear horn*,
and the next day I was punished by
having to wear my old bonnet to
church."
"Wi bannet off, quoth I, sweet lass,
I think ye seem to ken me."

Mrs. S. J. Murphy relates an Easter
bonnet experience that all early settlers
will appreciate.
"Shortly after our marriage." Mrs.
Murphy began, "my husband and I
went to our new home, a settlement
way down in Georgia. This home was
a log cabin built in the edge of the
woods and our neighborhood, though
somewhat scattered, turned out en
masse on Easter Sunday. Besides there
was a new attraction â they wished to
see the bride. Need I add that the
bride herself was anxious to look well?
My husband, too, took a great interest
in my appearance, and this he mani-
"EASTER MORNING I MADE READY FOR CHURCH- WITH A JOYOUS HEART I WENT TO THE CLOTHES-PRESS FOR
MY BONNET, AND THERE SNUGGLING IN THE SOFT LACES AND PLUMES I FOUND A NEW LITTER OF KITTENS.
WAS I SURPRISED? WELL ! ! ! "
fested in the sudden interest he dis
played in the welfare of my Easter
bonnet. As I said before the house
was built of logs and in fair weather
sunlight streamed through the spaces
between the logs, while in stormy
weather â thereby hangs a tale.
"The day before Easter was heralded
by a storm. The roof leaked, the water
dashed in at the windows and streamed
in between the logs, and I spent the
entire day in hunting for a dry spot
for my Easter bonnet. No sooner
would I be assured that the box con
taining it was secure from the deluge
than I would be as speedily convinced
of its danger. Pans, boiler, pots and
the marvelous Parisian pompadours.
Feminine Paris looks as though it had
got out of bed and forgotten to
comb its hair. And in the light of
these facts the dear things met me at
the wharf with their hair parted and
coiled the same old way. 1 confess I
liked them all the better for it. There
is a similarity between that round, fiat
knot of hair and pins ''like mother used
to make." Every trace of "Hcimweb"
disappeared at the first climpse of
them.
But why this digression on hair when
hats are the subject of my discourse?
Because on the arrangement of the hair
depends the becomingness of the hat.
In Paris the milliners display strik
ingly new patterns for hats. Presto!
changes the style of dressing the hair
to suit the new headgear.
Milliners and hairdressers work hand
in hand. Every Parisienne, after a little
seance with her hairdresser, can wear
a "Shepherdess," the latest thing in the
way <>f hats and a creation that is a
direct evolution from the "Jane Had
ings" of last year and can be traced
still further back to the "Marie An
toinettes." Every Parisienne does pos
sess a "Shepherdess" and "entre nous"
it becomes a trifle monotonous. Here,
however, thf milliners import the latest
things, people try them on, find them
unbecoming and with that independ
ence that makes them so adorable they
Will have none of them. They do not
realize that it is not alone the con
tours of the face, but the arrangement
of the hair that makes a hat becoming
or otherwise.
Secretly I am delighted that San
Francisco hairdressers cannot live up
to San Francisco milliners. If they did
w/> might run riot in one direction in
stead of having such a charming va
riety of hats.
Daintiness is the chief characteristic
of the new importations. Feathers
have been entirely laid aside fr>~ the
nonce, and soft and airy aigrettes and
letted quills are occupyin their place.
Flowers are more beautiful than ever
before, and in exquisite coloring and
perfection of outline vie with nature's
own blossoms.
I have seen the "Shepherdess" dis
played in several of the shop windows
here. They are equally as fetching as
those dfsplayed in Paris, whence, no
doubt, they hail. Bent down to shade
the face, rolling high on the sides, and
drooping again in back, they are at
once picturesque and jaunty. It is
hard to say just wherein they differ
from the hats that Jane Hading made
bo popular in Paris last year. I think
the main difference lies in the fact that
they are smaller and the droop over

kettles literally covered the floor. Every
few minutes my husband would come
in from his work in the barn to inquire
if the bonnet were high and dry, for he
wished me to be 'in the fashion shin
ing,' and the storm showed no signs of
abating. I was well nigh worn out with
my labor that day, but at night I was
rewarded by a peep at the treasure
just before going to sleep. It smiled
back at me from its little dry home and
my heart was satisfied."
"When beauty's ensign yet was crim
son on her lips," Mrs. Huntington,
mother of H. E. Huntington, encoun
tered her first Easter bonnet trial.
"In those days," said Mrs. Hunting
ton, "the prevailing fashion was the
old aberdeeno. This was but a flimsy
affair, though exceedingly pretty, but
poorly adapted" to the whimsical East
ern summer climate. The frame was of
wire and the covering only paper.
"I was in New York State at this
time and foolishly dared to brave the
drive to Easter service without an um
brella. The early morning opened as
fair as a day in June, the day of all
days for wearing my aberdeeno hat.
But I had not reckoned on its close,
nor the deluge of rain that was to ut
terly ruin my hat.
"When I reached home I still wore
the wire frame upon my 1. :ud, but the
prettily fluted paper rim was lying
round my shoulders, a homeless mass."

the face is less pronounced. There is
a certain chic about them that the
"Jane Hading" lacked. Even the
French walking hats droop over the
face and are short in back. They are
trimmed in drapes, steel ornaments
and quills.
The toques are made entirely of
flowers on a straw or wire foundation.
Charming effects are obtained in
those made of the soft crushed roses,
the brim made of tiny rosebuds nest
ling among green leaves. I notice that
the yellows and burnt oranges are
holding high carnival here. Last year
a birdseye view of "hatted" Paris
would have shown one broad, brilliant
streak of flaming orange. This year
they have toned it down to a shade
called castor. I* is a cross between
TRYING IT ON.
fawn and dove, with a splash of yellow,
and is used mainly for the straws. It
combines well with almost any aiiade,
but is particularly adapted to tur
quoise blue and lemon. The violet
shades have given w'ny â¢ the laven
ders and lilacs. This Is a characteristic
of the season. The deeper shades have
all been supplanted by dainty color
effects.
The gorgeous cardinals, royal purples
and brilliant yellows have gone out
with feathers, and the blush rose, lilac
and lemon are the favorites. The Paris
milliners say that the flowers made in
these delicate tints are better able to

'â¢On this particular year, my sister
and myself were given bonnets with
the request that we should not wear
them until Easter. I should have been
glad never to have worn mine: but
whatever was given to us must be
worn with gratitude. My hair was
what was called in those days red. The
bonnet was red also. But the two reds
were of a different shade, and clashed
inharmoniously upon my oversensitive
nerves. How to avoid wearing that
bonnet at all was my study. I put it
away to try on alone after oiling my
hair to tone it down a shade or two.
But the unpleasant fact still remained
that it was the most unbecoming thing
that I was ever called upon to wear.
"Easter morning came all too soon
and the bonnet was adjusted with hu
miliation upon my red head. I shall
never -forget my suffering on that oc
casion. My little friends, seeing my
discomfiture, teased me by pulling my
strings and blowing the feathers until
my patience was exhausted.
"On my way home I had an alterca
tion with a girl who nulled my bon
net off and threw it in the muddy
street. I at once jumped on it and
left it there as a broken monument to
donation parties in old New England.
"Thus the day that should have been
the brightest of all the year was to me
a day "of horror, long to be remem
bered."

Shall I confess It? I think it more

SWEET MUSIC
in
EASTER EGGS.
THE chocolate hen has laid a can
dy egg that is the most wonder
ful thing you ever heard of. It
is a musical egg, and capable, in
its turn, of hatching out sounds
that Will fill the neighborhood of the
small boy owner with chagrin and as
tonishment. The candy man wondered
and wondered what to make this year
that would be new, that would cause
the other candy men to open their eyes
and perish with trade envy and the
customers to greedily buy. And that
is how the musical egg came about.
It is so hard that surely a Plymouth
Rock hen must have laid itâ though
they say the big chocolate one that
weighs fourteen pounds did bring about
this curiosity. At any rate, there it
Isâ a glorious preparation of sugar, that
makes your mouth fairly water. But
you mustn't let it â for that would mean
death and destruction to the magic
egg.
Every boy who gets one â and as it is
somewhat expensive, few will be the
proud possessors of the wonder â will
straightway want to gobble it up, in
stead of getting its secret from it in
the form of a beautiful sound. That
is, it will be beautiful sound if the boy
is a musician â otherwise it will proba
bly drive the neighbors out of the
opposite flat. If it is eaten, that will
kill the piano that lavs the golden
notes, for music can only be produced

I suppose, the satisfaction and happi
ness that all women feel, until they
look over the congregation and see some
bonnet prettier than their own. My
hair was very abundant, and my bon
net very light. There was quite a
little breeze and my bonnet was lifted
from my head without my knowing it.
Presently I stumbled over what I
thought a little black dog; and as I
stepped aside, I reeoernized my bonnet
as it went hopping and bobbing along
the pavement in my advance. After
a little pursuit the truant was Rescued,
and I gained my pew in time to sur
vey the new creations in head-dresses
that are always heralded on Easter
morning.

that I should have liked for myself.

that the next day one of the papers, in
giving a description of the Easter bon
nets, put the very bonnet that I so
much admired upon my own head."

such a sacrifice. All the more unpleas

was a small one. and my friends seemed

ed in the Shaker, with its green apron
back and green ribbons, felt glad that
a green barege veil covered my burning
face, and sorry that I had not sacrificed
something of my trousseau instead of
so much comfort by wearing my old
bonnet."

of Chantilly lace behind, and allowed

SHE MAKES A HANDSOME LIVING
Out of Egg-Farming.
TO COMBINE book publishing and
poultry keeping is an idea which
it takes an enterprising woman to
carry out.
This woman is Mrs. Sarah L.
Bliss, who is the publisher of the
Brooklyn Blue Book, and at her coun
try place, just outside the borough of
Brooklyn, and within the limits of
Greater New York, she has started a
chicken farm.
Commencing less than a year ago
with twenty-five chickens, she has now
over 1000 fowls, ducks and turkeys.
"Is there any money in keeping poul
try?" was the question tasked -" Mrs.
Bliss at her Brooklyn office.
"I will give xou some notes from my
expense book, was the reply, and then
you can judge for yourself. Of course,
the first year one cannot expect to reap
great profits."
"It costs a penny a week to feed a
hen. She will lay about 180 eggs per
year. For these an average price of
three cents each is given, four or five
cents in winter and three cents in sum
mer. If you care to put it down in dol
lars and cents you might average it In
this way:
1 hen; fooa for 1 year at lc a weelc I 62
ISO eggs per year at 3c each 5 40
Balance in the treasury at end of year,
per hen 4M
Balance in the treasury, per 000 hens.. 4S&O CO
Balance in the treasury, per 2uOO hens.. 97tK) UO
"I intend having at least 2000 fowls,
and then I may clear $6000; wages,
taxes, etc., will take a good $2000 or
$1500. At present I have only one man
to help me, and I pay him $32 a month,
or $384 per year; three men will require
in wages $1152.
"Ducks are more profitable invest
ments, for the reason that their food is
not so expensive. Where it costs a
penny a week to feed a hen, the bill of
fare for a duck may be of a variety and
quality to please the most fastidious
duckling and cost only one-half penny
per week."
In the expense account it will be
noticed that "broilers" are not men
tioned. They are a small gold mine in
themselves, and should pay the expense
of the chicken farm, leaving clear
profit for the eggs. Mrs. Bliss has
never found any difficulty in disposing
of her eggs, 600 every week going to one
hotel. She considers the cochins and
the wyandottes the most profitable
breeds, and she has some original
theories in regard to Henrietta's daily j

"The Easter hat most vividly difficult
to obtain that now presents itself," said
Sadie L. Ballou, "was a war-time affair.
My husband, v.-ho was one of the first
volunteers, had been taken prisoner at
Huntsville, Ala,, which reduced the
small private's pa â  to not even a unit.
With three mouths to feed by such
means as I could command by my
needle, no surplus was left for Easter
hats. But wit and every woman's ne
cessity (the hat) triumphed.
"I lived on the four corners of a
farmers' village in Northern Wisconsin
and drew water and such other inex
pensive luxuries as the well and the
hand of the deacon's wife around the
corner might contribute to necessity.
"One day she resurrected from the
loft of a mercantile storage a relic of a
dead fashion, a coal scuttle bonnet,
sometimes called a sky-scraper, and
gave it to n.e.
"That brim of brims so sleekly good
Not flapped like dull Wesleyans down.
But looking (as all church hats should)
Devoutly upwardâ toward the crown."
"It did not take me long 1 to change
the shape. After ripping and splicing
the braids I Bewed and shaped it into
form, dyed it in logwood dye. stiffened
it with gumarabic, and finally pressed
it over a stone cream jar into the then
fashionable shape. Sumach berries fur
nished me with the dye for my old rib
bons, and I plumed the hat with a
couple of soft feathers from the tail of
a hawk that my brother had killed.
'"To prove that the hat was a success
I have only to add that I set myself up
with a millinery establishment by tak
ing all the sky-scrapers he deacon's
wife had and selling them after re
modeling into the like my own
for the munificent sum of 50 cents."
, Dr. 'Beecher, a cousii. of the late
Henry Ward Beecher, said: "My re
ligion is not dogmatic; therefore an
Easter hat to me is not a necessity.
For fifty-seven years I have worn the
same style hat and dress. In fact, I
am so unconventional in this regard
that I have justly earned the sobriquet,
The woman of one hat and one dress.'
"Why? Because, when my best dress
or hat gets a little bit shabby, I go to
my tailor and order another dress made
in the same fashion. It is just so with
my hat. All I have to say is, 'I should
like to have one just the same as that.'
I have been called masculine, and never
except once in seven years do my
friends cease nagging at me, seven
years being the period in which a fash
ion is said to repeat itself. Then I
console myself with the thought that I
have set the style for others to follow,
and this is tlie only time in which I am
free from the persecution of my friends
regarding my mode of dress."
"The greatest humilif <n that T havn
been called upon to endure," said Mrs.
Judge Cooper, "was all on aciouiiL Â«.i
an Easter bonnet. At this particular
iime I was in Chicago â the celebrated
Windy City. Whether or not Chicago
deserves this appellation I can only say
J.hat the wind was the cause i.f my mis
fortune.
"It has been a grievous fault with me
since my girlhood to give my apparel
but a little attention after I am once
properly attired.. Upon this occasion,
as upon all preceding ones, I wa3 wool
gathering as usual while on my wav to
Easter services. It never occurred to
me that the wind could carry ray hat
away without my k-.owledge, but it did,
and to this day tit has kept its secret
well, for I have never found it.
"I walked into churf- proudly uncon
scious that my headgear had disap
peared, and was somewhat annoyed at
the manner in which a casual acquaint
ance stared at me. I resented her un
usual interest by holding my head a
little higher.
"I was made conscious of my loss in
a most embarrassing way. After serv
ice I walked up to the ci.ancel and was
absorbed in my prayers when one of
the elders touched me gently on the
shoulder and softly quoted from St.
Paul's epistle to the Corinthians. 'Is it
comely that a woman pray unto God
uncovered?'
"I raised my hand to my head and
was humbled beyond expression. Had I
been allowed to proceed with my pray
ers, contrary to the church law, I think
they would have been of little avail,
for my mind was in anything but a
spiritual state while smarting under the
elder's biblical rebuke "

diet, treating her as though she were
a dyspeptic young lady, to a drink of
hot water 'each morning. Plenty of
ground oyster shells are given, boiled
carrots and fish: one great point is to
vary the food, not to continue the same
diet for any length of time, otherwise
Mr. and Mrs. Fowl and all the little
Fowls may strike, and threaten to
change their boarding place. Plenty of
cayenne pepper, of course, is given with
the food.
Incubators are used entirely on the
Bliss place, one having accommodation
for 600, one for 400 and one for 150, cost
ing from $60 to $20 each or thereabouts.
Eight acres of land are needed for
2000 fowls, and some woodland if pos
sible. If ducks are kept, a pond is
necessary.
Mrs. Bliss devotes the business hours
of the day to her publishing enterprise,
coming in to her office in Brooklyn
about 11 o'clock.

JUDITH AS PAINTED
BY DIFFERENT ARTISTS
THAT Judith, the heroine of an
tiquity, the deliverer of the be
sieged city, is a character of Bible
history that has attracted the at-
tention of many artists, is quite
evident from the number of pictures of
this subject that may be found in the
world"? Art galleries.
A beautiful Jewish maiden who had
the mentality to conceive a strategy
and the courage and power to carry it
out Is a subject well worth the effort of
the most able artist.
She is generally represented in the
act of leaving the tent of Holof ernes,
carrying with her, as a trophy of vic
tory, the head of the Assyrian general.
One of the finest examples of this
THE TULIP AS AN EASTER DECORATION
EGGS in some form or other, I
whether alone or as an adjunct
to other viands, seem to be a
natural article of food for Easter
morning and to lend them an in
dividuality appropriate to the occasion
Borne sli-ht deviation from the ordinary
ways of serving them is desirable. The
idea suggested by the accompanying
sketch is simple and inexpensive and
can be prepared for the meal at odd
moments some days in advance.
The materials necessary are a sheet
of green tissue paper, and one each of
white, yellow, red, pink or any colors
desirable which are in accord with the
natural colors of the flower, a box of
water-color paints, some mucilage and
a piece of No. 1 green ribbon. Having
obtained these, cut from stiff paper pat
terns of the size and shapes indicated
in No. 1 and No. 2 of the illustration.
No. 1 is 1% inches wide by 6V4 long,
and represents the long, slender
leaves of the plant. These should be
cut from the green paper, allowing at 'â 
least three for each flower. No. 2
shows the petals of the blossom, is Z2
inches long by 4V4 deep, and each petal
measures 2*4 inches across its widest ;
part.
When these patterns are cut lay them
on the tissue paper, several folds thick,
in order to t -pedite cutting the design,
and whfn as many as are needed have j
b^en secured put loner, irregular dashes
of water color paint on the petals, red
on yellow, pink on white, etc., as indi
cated in No. 3. 1 his work can be done
very rapidly and more than pays for |
itself in the appearance of the flower '
when completed.
When these are dry curl the end of
each petal slightly by drawing It over
the dull edge of a pair of scissors or an
ivory paper cutter, and fold creases in
each, as also shown in No. 3. These
are now folded around an egg cup, a bit
of mucilage holding the petals together
FOR AN EASTER BREAKFAST.
representatlon may be found in the
Pitti Palace, the work of Christofano
Allori. a Florentine artist of the six
teenth century.
It is claimed that In this picture,
which is supposed to be his best prod
uct, the head of Judith is a likeness of
the wife of the painter, while the head
of Holofernes is supposed to represent
himself.
Allori v.as one of the foremost of his
school. His pictures are distinguished
by their close adherence to nature and
the delicacy and technical perfection of
their execution. His technical skill is
proven by the fact that several copies
he made after Correggio have been
taken to be duplicates of Correggio
himself.
and to the side of the cup, rendering the
decoration more secure.
Outside of the petals are placed the
leaves, which are then tied securely in
place by a small boy of narrow ribbon
of green, or in harmony with the flower
itself, having first been creased in the
fold shown In No. 1 and caught about
at the top of the fold with a tiny bit of i
mucilage.
Care must be taken not to cut the
petals apart, a mistake it is easy to I
make, and which wastes paper, time
and energy, as it is difficult to put them
in place singly on the egg cup, and
gain the correct effect shown in No. 4.
One of these stool at each plate at an
Easter breakfast table will give a
cheery surprise to the uninitiated mem
bers of the family, and the egg dis
covered therein is almost sure to have
a daintier flavor, so powerful is the ef- |
feet of our imagination upon material
things.
GOLD'S CIRCUIT OF THE GOLBE. i
"A million dollars gold from Japan en !
route to the Sub Treasury in New York i
detained for eight hours at Cedar i
Rapids."
This very metal, like as not, orlgl- !
nated in California, crossed the conti- !
nent in the form of double eagles, was !
shipped to London and converted into
sovereigns, went perhaps to France,
and, after circulating for a time in the
shape of twenty-franc pieces, was sent
to Japan in payment for silks, and com
pleting the circuit of the earth comes
back to us in payment for cotton.
The ceaseless ebb and flow of gold
around the globe in settlement of trade
balances proves that, independent of
all statutes, it is by natural laws the
money of the civilized nations. "When
one reflects on the heavy expense of
transportation and the great loss from
attrition, however, it Is surprising that
in the age of peace and international
THE SAN FRANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APRIL 10, 1898.
In the canvas of Mr. Mathews we
find he has deviated from the common
representation by painting Judith as
going on her terrible errand.
This is a very good example of Mr.
Mathews' excellent conception of Bib
lical subjects. His composition is ex
cellent, his color scheme satisfying, and
his drawing is a good illustration of his
unusual skill, which Mr. Seymore
Thomas kindly sr.id was unexcelled in
any of the artists of his acquaintance.
This picture was exhibited at the
World's Fair at Chicago, where it re
ceived a great deal of favorable atten
tion.
The subject of Judith is a favored
I one with Mr. Mathews, for hanging
very near the one just described is an
other, a pastel, expressed with much
i feeling, and representing the heroine in
I the act of entering the tent. Here the
' artist has admirably succeeded in de
picting the strong will and determined
: purpose that are characteristic of the
woman subject.
The pictures may still be seen at the
i Hopkins Institute of Art.
