WHY THE EG WERE CHANGED
FROM GRAY TO BLUE.
IT was the season of Easter along the
Eastern Shore of Maryland, and that
favored land, though the war was on
between the States and the Blue and
the Gray were fiercely contending for
a principle which could be settled
only by bloodshed, bore every evi
dence of nature that It was In truth what
Its people called It, "God's country."
Lying low and level, fresh in the spring
i green of its fields and orchards, shining
'in the silver strands of its myriad
I streams, stretching back and away from
! the rippling waters of the Chesapeake un
! til its clumps of woods rested on the east
j crn horizon and lazily luxurious in its
i balmy climate, it was. as it still is, a land
j of peace and plenty, fit for the restful
, quiet of body, soul and mind. As one of
! its songsters quaintly sings:
"Hfre terrapin and canvasback
Are to the manner born;
And here the nectar of the gods
Is rye instead of corn."
With Easter had come rejoicing among
! the dusky denizens of kitchen and cabin
along the Eastern Shore, for Easter was
1 the darkies" festival^ in those days, and
at no place was tfiVre more joy than
among the blacks of Kirkham Manor, for
! Major Winter, the proprietor of the
manor, was a kindly master, who let the
' fetters rest lightly on his slaves, and he
had announced that each of his people,
; big and tittle, should have a ticket to the
I circus which was to show in town on the
I Monday after Easter. It was not always
that a circus was one of the Easter fes
tivities, for Easter sometimes came be
fore the circus bloomed, but in the year
of this chronicle Easter nad fallen after
j the middle of April and the circus people
! had hastened to be ready on the Monday
j after. True, it was not a circus of the
j old-time splendor, for the war had made
that impossible, but there was a big white
' tent and spotted horses and ladies in tln
i sel Bkirts as short as they were glittering,
and there were hundreds of other fairy
I delights that grow In simple minds from
j the pictures on circus bills.
But the circus was only part of the
richness of the time. All work was to
stop at noon on Saturday, there was to be
church and ribbons and the best bib and
tucker on Sunday and on Monday and
Tuesday following the white folk were
to take hold of the work about the house
and place and let all the darkies In the
county go to town to have their full of
festivity. Cake walks aud feasts and bar
becues and weddings and hoedowns and
frolics of all kinds were In order, winding
up late Tuesday night, when even If some
came home drunken It was not held
against them as an offense.
And how they did enjoy It. It was free
dom to them, without anr of Its respon
sibility or care, and they bad no thought
for the morrow, except that It had not
WHAT THOMAS JEFFERSON
SAID
ABOUT ANNEXING CUBA
Copy of the Famous Letter on the Important
Question That He Sent to James Mon
roe Seventy-Five Years Ago.
THOMAS JEFFERSON wrote to
President James Monroe from his
home at Monticello, under date
of October 24, 1823:
"I have ever looked upon Cuba
as the most interesting addition which
could ever be made to our system of
States/
Monroe had addresÃed a letter to Jef
ferson, dated October 17, 1823, in which
Monroe expressed his opinion that we
ought to meet the proposal of the Brit
ish Government, and to make it known
that we would view an interference on
the part of the European powers, and
especially an attack on the (Spanish)
colonies, as an attack on ourselves.
This expression preceded the famous
"Monroe doctrine" message by but
forty days. In that short period, how
ever, Monroe's impression had solidified
into the strong words of his message to
Congress, December 2, 1823. At the con
clusion of his letter Monroe asks Jef
ferson's opinion and requests that the
correspondence be forwarded to James
Madison.
In view of the talk of an alliance with
England, it will be interesting to give
enough of this correspondence to show
how Monroe. Jefferson. Madison and
John Quincy Adams looked upon a simi
lar proposal, made when the Cuban
question was uppermost seventy-nve
years ago.
In reply to Monroe's letter, Jefferson
writes that the question "is the most
momentous which has ever been offered
to my contemplation sinoe that of in
dependence that made us a nation. ' He
points out the advantages of "detach
ing Great Britain from the band of
despots," and bringing "her mighty
weight into the scale of free govern
ment." "With her on our side." writes
Jefferson, "we need not fear the whole
world." But in the next line he de
clares that he "would not purchase her
amity at the expense of taking part in
her wars."
Jefferson declared his position on the
"Cuban question" in anticipation of tnÂ»>
designs of Russia, Prussie and Austria,
"a lawless alliance," says Jefferson,
"calling itself holy." He believed we
should "oppose, with all our means, the
interposition of any other power, under
any form or pretext," in the affairs of
this hemisphere.
In the memoirs of John Quincy Adams
we find that he, also, was called into
consultation on this "momentous
question. Adams writes under date of
November 15, 1823. that President Mon
roe sent for him to come to the State
Department, where the liters of Jef
ferson and Madison were laid before
him. Adams says that Madison's opin
ion in favor of accepting England s pro
posal is "less decisively pronounced
(than that of Jefferson), and he (Madi
son) thinks as I do, that this movement
on the part of Great Britain is impelled
more by her interest than by a princi
ple of liberty." .
The full text of Jefferson's letter is
as follows".
MdNTICEL,Lf>. October 24. 1823.
Dear Sir: The question presented by
the inters you have sent me Is the most
momentous" which has ever been offered
to my contemplation since that of in
dependence made us a nation. This sets
our compass and points the course
which we are to steer through the
ocean of time opening on us; and never
could we embark on it under circum
stances more auspicious. Our first and
fundamental maxim should be never to
entangle ourselves in the broils of Eu
rope- our second should be never to suf
fer Europe to interfere with Cis-Atlan
tic affairs. America. North and South,
has a set of interests distinct from those
of Europe, and peculiarly her own.
While the last is seeking to become the
domicile of despotism, our endeavor
ehould be to surely make our hemis
phere that of freedom. One nation, most
of all could disturb ub in this pursuit.
She now offers to lead and accompany
us in it. By acceding to her proposition
we detach her from a band of despots,
bring her mighty weight into the scale
for free government, and emancipate a
continent at one stroke, which mipht
otherwise linger long in doubt and diffi
culty. . , .
Great Britain is the nation which can
yet come, which is the true darky phll
'^Even' Christmas was not such a season
on the Eastern Shore as Easter was.
It was Saturday afternon and Klrkham
Manor \\;.s deserted of servants. Indeed,
it wa* oimofll deserted of all humanity.
MÂ« (or V ii'ttr had ridden over to a. neisli
bor's immediately after dinner at 1
o'clock, and no one was about except tne
major's only daughter. Kate, who nan
chosen to stay and color a bushel or two
of eggs for the children.
Kate Winter was the pride of the
naicr's heart, she was the mistress of
every man's heart if she chose to be.
Jv.n &:. l-npiit of mind and ey?, uuick
of tong-.Â»T anO motion, kindly withal and
beautiful, it was her right to ijio. and
she did. When the war had com?, her
conservative father had taken no decided
stand, but the high strung Kate was posi
tive she knew which side was right, and
at once announced herself. She was for
the South, and what an unmitigated little
rebel she was. The sight of a blue coat
made her eyes snap and a single strain
of "Yankee Doodle" put all of her nerves
on edge. Vet during the month of Janu
ary, last past, whicn she had spent in
the social whirl at Washington, the one
man who was most devoted to her was
Captain Leonard of the Federal army,
and. woman-like, the man she most
wished to be so was uaa same captain.
When she came home, the captain acted
as escort to her party as far a 6 Balti
more; a few weeks later he had come to
Kirkham Manor for two days; he had
come again late in March, and now he
was to spend Easter Sunday and Mon
day on his third visit. Just why she per
mitted these attentions, she could not
say. for the captain wore the hated blue,
and he was, in addition, a lumbering,
awkward, good-natured, simple, sincere
kind of overgrown boy that a woman
likes better than anybody in the world,
but doesn't think of loving as she might
love a husband. As for such a man.
himself, he rarely is conscious of his good
points, and failing in the tact to present
himself as he should, all the chances are
that married life with the woman he gets
will not be what he had a right to ex
pect it to be.
"He's a Yankee, Kate," her father
would say of the captain in a bantering
mood.
"He is a Leonard," she would retort.
"His ancestor was Jonathan Leonard,
brother-in-law of Lord Baltimore. Is
mine any better?" and Kate would smile,
because her father was a stickler for
family.
"All the more reason why he should not
wear the blue," argued the major, accom
panied by a strain from "Maryland, My
Maryland."
"Well, papa," with a toss of her head,
"what do I care? I am sure he Is noth
ing on earth to mo. I met him as I met
dosens of others, and If he wants to come
down here to see us," emphasising the
usâ "we can not very well shut our doors
against him. He Is a friend, or says he Is,
and I don't want any thins to be nearer,
do us the most harm of any one, or
all on earth; and, with her on our side,
we need not fear the whole world. With
her, then, we should most sedulously
cherish a cordial friendship; ajid noth
ing could more securely knit our af
fections than to be fighting side by side,
in the same cause. Not that I would
purchase even her amity at the price of
taking part in our wars. But the war
in which the present proposition might
engage us. should that be its conse
quence, is not her war, but ours. Its
object is to introduce and establish the
American system of keeping out of our
land all foreign powers; of never per
mitting those of Europe to intermeddle
with the affairs of our nations. It is
to maintain our own principle; not to
depart from it. And if, to facilitate this
we can effect a division in the body of
the European powers and draw over to
our side its most powerful member,
surely we should do it.
But I am clearly of Mr. Canning's
opinion that it will prevent. Instead of
provoking war with Great Britain.
Withdrawn from their scale and shifted
into that of our two continents, all Eu
rope combined could not undertake such
a war. For how would they propose to
get at either enemy without superior
Meets? Nor is the occasion to be slight
ed which this proposition offers to pro
test against the interference of any one
in the internal affairs of another, so
flagitiously begun by Bonaparte, and
now continued by the equally lawless
alliance calling itself "holy."
But we have first to ask ourselves a
question. Do we wish to acquire to our
own confederacy any one or more of the
Spanish provinces? I cordially confess
that I have ever looked upon Cuba as
the most interesting addition that could
ever be made to our system of States.
The control which, with Florida point,
this island would give us over the Gulf
of Mexico and the countries and the
isthmus bordering on it, &s well as
those whose waters would flow into it,
would fill up the measure of our po
litical well being. Yet, as I am sensible
that this can never be obtained, even
JUDITH WITH THE HEAD OF HOLOFERNES.
From a photograph of Allorl's great painting.
that's Yankee. But I do wish sometimes
that I was a man so I could light Captain
Leonard."
Kate was fully in earnest, too. and her
father was careful not to banter too far,
seeing that he had done so once to his
great discomfort, for the pretty Kate was
not all angel.
In the midst of the egg coloring Aunt
Mary, the cook, came hurrying to the
house as fast as she could.
"Fo' de Lawd, Miss Kate." she puffed.
"I done seed de Cappen a-comin' an' I
knowed you wuzn't especkin' uv him fer
two hours yit, so I jis run up f'um de
awchid to tell you an' gib you a chance
to spruce up a little 'fo' he gits yer."
Hut it was too late, for even as Aunt
Mary was performing her errand of
mercy, the captain rode up to the house
and he saw Kate at the kitchen window
as he swung round the corner of the lawn.
As Aunt Mary had said, he was two
hours ahead of time and Kate almost lost
her temper at the promptness of the man.
for there was no one on the place to re
ceive and entertain him except herself
and there was no escape. He had stopped
beneath the shade of a large tree in the
yard and there Kate, like a true house
wife in her working attire, appeared be
fore him with a basket of eggs and color-
Ing paraphernalia in her hands, and the
captain thought he never saw her look
ing half so pretty. That he was in love
with her needed no angel come from
heaven to proclaim to all the Eastern
Shore. It was in his eyes, his face, his
hands, his voice, his manner.
THOMAS JEFFERSON.
FAC-SIMILE OF PART OF THE LETTER THOMAS JEFFERSON SENT JAMES MONROE IN OCTOBER, 1823, TOUCHING TWt
ACQUISITION OF CUBA &f THE UNITED STATES.
with her own consent, but by war, and
its own independence, which is our sec
ond interest (and especially its inde
pendence of England), I have no hesita
tion in abandoning my first wish to fu
ture chances and accepting its independ
ence with peace, and the friendship of
England, rather than its association at
the expense of war and her enmity.
I could honestly, therefore, join in the
declaration proposed, that we aim not
at the acquisition of any of these pos
sessions; that we will not stand in the
way of any amicable arrangement be
tween them and the mother country,
but that we will oppose, with all our
means, the forcible interposition of any
other power, as auxiliary, stipendiary
or in any other form or pretext, and
most especially their transfer to any
power by conquest, cession or acquisi
tion in any other way.
I should think it therefore advisable
that the executive should encourage
the British Government to a continu
ance in the dispositions expressed in
these letters by an answer of his con
currence with them as far as his au
thority goes; and that, as it may lead
to war, the declaration of which re
quires an act of Congress, the case shall
be laid before them for consideration at
their first meeting and under the rea
sonable aspect in which it is seen by
himself.
I have been so long weaned from po
litical subjects and have so long ceased
to take any interest in them that I am
sensible that I am not qualified to offer
opinions on them worthy of any atten
tion; but the question now proposed in
volves consequences so lasting and ef
fects bo decisive of our future destinies
as to rekindle all the interest I have
hitherto felt on such occasions, and to
induce me to hazard opinions which
will prove only my wish to contribute
still my mite toward anything which
may be useful to our country, and pray
ing you to accept it only at what it is
worth. I add the observance of my con
stant and affectionate friendship and re
spect, THOMAS JEFFERSON.
I As she met him now, laughing, she told
him she was just about to color a dozen
Easter egg* for him to take back to
1 Washington, but he had come too soon,
: and they were not ready.
He might have turned her remark nicely

i bility of seeing her too soon, but the cap-

Instead he saJd, as he pointed to some
! colored cloth in her hand:
"What color will they be. Miss Kate?"
"Gray." she responded promptly and
much to his surprise at her interpreta
tion of his innocent question. "It is my
color, Captain Leonard, and to be knight
of this lady you must wear the color she
gives you. But why did you come so
early to stop me at my work?" she added,
still lightly enough. "Papa was expect
ing to return in time to meet you and do
the honors, but here you are and what is
ever to be done with you?"
She looked at him ruefully, and he
smiled, but there was a shadow In it.
"It was my only opportunity. Miss
Kate." he replied seriously. "I am
ordered away to leave Washington on
Monday and join my regiment before
Richmond at once. Men are needed there,
and I am only too glad to be able to do
what I can for my country-"
The lines in Kate's face grew hard at
his words, and she looked at him as if
she would speak as she had often spoken
before, but she restrained the first im
pulse and waited for him to go on.
"I thought I would like to see you once
more before I went away," he continued

LOSS OF LIFE
A MONG INFANTS
rT^HE Medical Record says: ThÂ« fact
T^ls well known to medical men
I that where infants are massed
I together in large numbers their
J- chances of living are immensely
diminished. Convincing proofs â  Â« .JWW
have recently been afforded in the case ot
foundling hospitals in Italy and Franc*.
There is no need, however, to go abroad
for confirmatory evidence.
At the Randall's Island Foundling Hos
pital, an institution supervised by the
New York Department of Charities, of 36Â»
infants under six months of age received
during 1896 and treated continuously only
12 remained alive April 15. 1897. The aver
age duration of life of the 354 who died
was between five and six weeks. The
death rate was 96.7 per cent, and only two
of the survivors were bottle-fed.
A few historical comments will empha
size the needs of foundlings. Up to within
three decades practically nothing was
done for them in any English-speaking
country. .In England under the poor law
of 1834 the young "were merely received
to die, and the few who struggled into
life were trained only in ignorance, idle
ness and vice." In Philadelphia, until
1885 all waifs were sent to the foundling
ward of the Philadelphia Almshouse,
where the death rate was practically 100
per cent.'
In New York, only a quarter of a cen
tury ago, the child who was not at once
destroyed by the despairing mother had
no alternative but a lingering death in the
almshouse under the care of aged pau
pers. Reports show that of the infants so
placed scarcely one ever survived. At the
present time, except In New York city,
Philadelphia and in Massachusetts condi
tions remain the same.
Michigan has its placing out system for
older children, and Minnesota and other
States are helped by well-organized chil
dren's aid societies. But except in Massa
chusetts very little effort has been ex
erted to change a system which at best
seems only a legalized form of infanticide.
We must, of course, except the purely lo
cal and unorganized individual kindness
which has always in some measure, but
very inadequately, coped with the need.
The New York Foundling Asylum on
Sixty-eighth street shows how needless
and how criminal is much of the mortal
ity among foundlings. Its origin is due
to Sister Irene, whose fame is national.
In 1569, with only $5 in her pocket, she
began the work by placing a little crib
outside the door of her small house on
East Twelfth street. That crib now
stands within the present magnificent
buildings of this charity, and on the af
ternoon of February 21 received its 30,0915t
temporary occupant.
The system as evolved by Sister Irene
and carefully continued by others since
her death consists in paying a foster
mother from among the respectable poor
to care for a foundling, as well as her
own babe. The care ceases at the end
of three years and children are then
returned to the asylum for kindergarten
work and schooling, until finally placed
in good families the country over In
a special interview with Sister Teresa
Vincent, the present superintendent, the
following noteworthy statistics were se
cured:
In 1892, of the 2591 children of various
ages cared for, 611 died, an average of
22.8 per cent: in 1893, of 2962 there died
596. an average of 20.1 per cent; in 1896, of
2300 there died 573, an average of 24.9 per
cent.
In relation to the most recent 369 deaths
it is interesting to note that 95 of those
who died were received under one year
of age, while 128 of the fatal cases were
received between one and two; showing"
that while under the Randall's Island
barrack system it is almost certain death
to a more infant to place it there â in the
Foundling Asylum its chances are better
than if kept for a while in neglect an<l
hunger and 111 treatment by Its mother.

1898
OULD the brown-gowned padres
M of ten decades past rise from
their sleep this Easter morn and
look upon the scene of their
\ former labors by the Golden
what would they find fa
miliar in the area from Hunters
Point to the Presidio, from Bernal
Heights and Lone Mountain cross to
the seawall?
Little, indeed, save sky and bay and
the warm Californi . sunshine, for these
are the only things that man cannot
harness to the van of progress.
The astonished gaze of the fathers
would rest with loving remembrance
upon an adobe roof here and there â un
less commerce had sent these, too, into
eclipse by hideous and desecrating
painted signsâ and then, turning to the
old Mission Dolores, I fancy tears of
gratitude might come that time had
not ruthlesssly swept from sight this
monument of their labor. Within its
quaint and consecrated structure their
troubled souls, disembodied or reincar
nated, would be certain to gain peace
as of old.
To-day the voices of trained s^nd sal
aried singers will thrill the souls of
listeners with their melody or faJl upon
ears too dulled by indifference to heed
the spiritual significance of words and
music. Yesterday, as it were, since
time swings the cycles so swiftly â the
people sang for .he very love of the
Eastertide and its gentle lesson to man
kind; and with the notes of'Te Deum,"
"Laudamus" and "Gloria in Erccelsis"
â vvr-re mingled feelings of joy that they
c mid thus worship God In the wilder
ness. Yesterday the silver-throated
bells of Dolores broke the stillness of
the morning air. To-day service will
be proclaimed from the steeples of mag
nificent churches whose presence but
eerves to accentuate the simple beauty
of their white-walled predecessor.
A hundred years ago the site of this
commonwealth-to-be was a sandy ex
panse of hill and vale, tangled with
malva and wildflowers, grown with
scrub oak, manzanita, mesquite and
madrone to the water's edge. Yerba
Buena Cove reached to Montgomery
street. Quail were plentiful and un
afraid. I'pon the hills that were not
t > be eternal, because of the dwellers
of the future who should come to raze
them, she^'- cattle, horses and mules
of the pueblo roamed and fed, and at
night were the prey of bears, for in the
ITL'S the stock was greatly deplet
ed by wild beasts. Saint Francis de
Assist, bullded on the Laguna de los
Dolores, had been completed nearly
ty-one years and was perfect in
its plcturesnueneps, its interior being
as richly decorated as was possible
with tho facilities at hand. The huts
of the Indians had been replaced by
adobe dwellings with tiled roofs in
i^nt number to accommodate the
families of the married neophytes. Sol
flier? were garrisoned at the Presidio
as now. About 3600 bushels of crops,
mainly wheat, were stored in an adobe
building near!; I long, the keys
to th' 1 community granary being held
b" Uu as, the alcalde, comision
nd senior regidor. A trail led its
winding irregular way from Presidio
to Mission. Around Potrero and fields
a ditch was dug. some nine feet wide.
The settlement was prosperous, and the
hearts of Fathers Palou and Cambon
and the indefatigable Serra were
thankful, for, ns Serra hn<l s;ti'3 upon
completion of this, the sixth of the
California missions, "our Father tit.
Francis, with the holy cross of the pro
cession of missions, has reached the
last limits of the Western continent.
To gt> farther he must have boats."
And what of the people whom the
bells summoned to worship on that
Easter day of long ago, with heads
bowed reverently before the image at
the altar of St. Francis, patron saint
rt. Presidio and Mission?
There were not many hundreds of
fouls, and they numbered friars and

Indiansâ a strangely assorted
. gation, among whom none spoke
iglish word. The Latin of the ser

the Mexican language weretheirspeech.
As a class, they were an intelligent,
law-abiding community, for when
Anza brought his colonists hither more
than 1 wenty years previously, he had
betft instructed to Beiect only men and
women of hirrhest character to found
the new settlement,
[re Landaeta was in charge of the
mission, having replaced Padre Cam
bon when the latter became too ill for
duty. He was assisted by Friars Fer
nadez and Abella. Ramon Abella
was a Spaniard of much ability and

many years Bole survivor of those who
came h>re previous to 1800. When the
present century was fourteen years old

Mission in "76. Pedro Alb.-ml, a Span
ish lieutenant-colonel, was by reason
of his rank in command of San Fran
cisco port. Diego Borica was Governor.
ji genial, wealthy and progressive
man, his wife the beautiful Donna
Magdalena de Urqulde?.
Among those who received the ben
ediction of the snowy-stoled priesthood
on that far-off Sabbath were many
whose dust has lain through undis
turbed generations in the mossy, lvy
parlanded burying ground of Dolores.
Th<-r^ were names that how mark the
highways and byways of a great city,
wnose hills are traversed in a few
jnornf-nts' space, where once the foot
of rn;iri and beast sank knee-deep In
the drifting sand. Other names are
interwoven with the most romantic
events of our State's history.
There were the Alvarados. one of

EASTER SUNDAY SERVICES, MISSION DOLORES, SAN FRANCISCO, ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGO TO-DAY.
"And what of the people whom the bells summoned to worship on Easter day one hundred years ago, with heads bowed reverently before the image at the altar of St. Francis, patron saint of our
port, presidio and mission. They numbered friars and laymen, soldiers and civilians, ranchmen and Indians-* strangely assorted congregation-among whom none spoke an English word.
nals. Ramon and Joaquin; Jose Aguila,
a prominent Mexican settler; the <"as
tros, Francisco, Jose, Joaquin and
Simeon; Luis Peralta, who came with
Anza when a boy, was in 17 I jÃ put in
command of the San Jose Mission and
later became a don, securing the grant
of San Antonio rancho, where Oakland
and Alameda are now, the Pachecos,
Bartolo, Ignacio and Miguel, and rep
resentatives of the Galindo, Gonzales,
Aceves, Martinez and Valencia fam
ilies.
From the dwarfed, thatched tule hut
of the Indian, held together by dried
grasses, to the architectural giant of
which the Spreckels building is an ex
ample, is a far cry. One hundred years
have altered the landscape, scarred the
face of nature, and driven her primitive,
improvident children forth to wage un
equal battle with thrifty newcomers.
The adobes and their builders are dust,
Yerba Buena a tradition, the wilder
ness reclaimed. Civilization, in all the
glory of noble achievement and the
shame of vice unspeakable, is come to
the Golden Gate.
LILLIAN FERGUSON.
DIPLOMATIC LIFE
in
WASHINGTON,
IF the stress of social life in Wash
ington prove a trial to those forced
to take part in it, at least there can
be no complaint of monotony, for
when surfeited with the faultless,
impassive demeanor of one legation
the impulse and fire of the South can
be sought at another, or the subtlety
and smooth polish of still another coun
try may be studied at but a stone's
throw.
To drive, in a few moments, from
England to Guatemala, from Spain to
Germany and then to China, Japan,
Hawaii, or where you will, is a feat not
to be attained in any other city in the
world, and, as the showman says, "It
must be seen to be appreciated."
The Right Honorable Sir Julian
Pauncefote, G. C. 8., G. C. M. G., Em
THE SAX FRAXCISCO CALL, SUXDAY, APRIL 10, 1898.
bassador and Envoy Plenipotentiary, is
the dean of the diplomatic corps. He
lives up to the wealth of initials suc
ceeding his name in dignity of manner
r.nfl mien, ;md is an able representative
of her Majesty. He is a large, stout,
florid man of ripe years and pleasant
manners, alive to the importance and
honor of his position and determined
that others shall realize, through him,
Englaud's pride and England's might.
So long has he been accustomed to take
the lead at dinners, receptions and all
official or private entertainments that it
is almost impossible fur him to brook
any rivalry of the position which he
claims both by right of seniority and
because, as Embassador, he represents
the person of his sovereign. But of
late he has been forced into a second
ary position on two occasions and
Washington declares that he is a sad
der and a wiser man. Still, it took tht*
State Department to place Sir Julian
Pauncefote and he did not tamely sur
render what he considered his rights.
When the wealthy Mrs. Leiter invited
Sir Julian and his wife to dinner, the
Embassador wrote and requested a list
of her guests. In her reply Mrs. Leiter
named Vice-President Hobart in the list.
Sir Julian then wrote to his would-be
hostess to ask where she proposed to
seat her Majesty's representative.
When her answer informed him that he
would follow the Vice-President he de
clined the invitation and the question
became a state matter. Thus Sir Jul
ian's position and the Leiter dinnerwere
the discussion of the hour until the
State Department finally delivered the
verdict, during the Grant monument
ceremonies in New York, that Sir Jul-
ian took precedence of all excepting the
President and Vice-President, the
Vice-President, heir-apparent to the
Presidency, being the second man in
the land and therefore ahead of the
Dean Embassador of the Diplomatic
Corps.
It was shortly after this notable de
cision that President Dole of Hawaii
became the guest of the nation. Psesi
deot McKinley bade the Diplomatic
Corps to a dinner in honor of his dis
tinguished visitor, and again Sir Julian
lost his bearings, for immediately suc
ceeding the President of Hawaii and
his wife were the Hawaiian Minister,
Mr. Hatch, and his wife. Sir Julian, it
is said, failed to appreciate the brilliant
bi/ard, with its splendor of rare orchid
bloom, failed to enjoy the gallant as
semblage, the fair, jeweled women, the
decorated foreign representatives, the
costly viands, the music, the conver
sation, and, in short, all that went to
make one of the most noteworthy din
ners ever seen at the White House.
But if Sir Julian has faults, he also
has virtues, and as a host he is un
paralleled for courtesy, hospitality and
gallantry. The Pauncefotes live in a
handsome mansion on Connecticut av
enue, where they entertain largely and
magnificently. Their famous bal poudre
was the event of this season in Wash
ington. The genial host we- ably as
sisted by his wife, whose manners are
cordial and sympathetic, and by his
daughters, Sibyl, Lilian, Audrey â can
not one imagine the daughters of the
Pauncefote house? Typical English
girls, with complexions and faultless,
high-bred manners.
No greater contrast to this English
household can be found than at the
German embassy. Herr yon Holleben,
the Embassador, is a jolly bachelor, for
whom all the girls are setting their
caps and for whom all the mammas
have an appreciative, welcoming smile.
He lives in a magnificent house, that
contains the handsomest private ball
room in Washington, of which he takes
full advantage. He is the host at many
an informal dance, more pretentious
"hop." or still modre formal cotillon.
Having no ladies in his household, he
generally asks a couple of young mar
ried women to receive with him (and at
his last ball he secured the aid of two
charming womenâ Mme. Patenotre, the
lovely wife of the former French Minis
ter, and Mme. Hengelmuller yon Hen
gervar of Austria-Hungary. These two
are alike in their undeniable popularity,
beauty, wealth and family, although of
marked and distinct individuality.
Madame Patenotre was a Miss Elver
son of Philadelphia. She was visiting
in Washington when she met Monsieur
Patenotre, who fell in love with her al
most at first sieht. They met at a large
reception. Monsieur Patenotre noticed
the tall, fair girl, whose air of style
and distinction added attraction to her
beauty. He approached nearer; near
enough to overhear the conversation
shy was holding with those around her.
To his surprise it was in French. His
interest in her was doubled; he noted
the purity of her accent and listened
delighted for a few moments to his
mother to-ngxie. Then he rushed off to
seek for an introduction to the lovely
French girl. When he learned that she
was an American he was astonished,
but no less interested, and from the mo
ment tfrey were introduced his atten
tions were marked and devoted. The
acquaintance begun that ni-rht culmi
nated sc-on after in a brilliant wedding.
Monsieur Patenotre was always some
thing of a lady killer, and is not a man
to forgive any slight from the fair sex.
He and Assistant Secretary of State
Rockhill have been throughout on un
friendly terms, the result of an old
trouble in China, where, one afternoon,
Monsieur Potenotre called cm Mrs.
Rockhill and was told that the lady
was engaged. Monsieur # Patenotre
never forgave this, and the rancor be
tween the Rockhills and the French
Minister has been undistnaised and
frank. When Secretary of State Olney
was absent from Washington, and in
tercourse between Mr. Rockhill and
Monsieur Patenotre was unavoidable,
the situation was awkward in the ex
treme.
Tb.e unfortunate Senor Dupuy de
Lome was popular, good looking and
attractive and he had many friends in
Washington to regret his short-sighted
mistake. Senor de Lome's wife did
everything to add to his popularity and
was, perhaps, more of a lobbyist than
any woman in the diplomatic circle. She
combined infinite tact with rare dis
crimination and she did much to sub
due the feeling against Spain.
A diplomatic reception was given at
the "White House this winter, during a
period when discussion on Cuba was
hot in the House and feeling ran high.
How she managed it no one knew. It
must have been the result of skillful
maneuvering â but for over an hour Ma
dame de Lome walked through the spa
cious rooms of the White House on the
arm of Secret-ry Sherman. She was
the observed of all observers and con-

jecture was rife as to the political sig
nificance attached to this promenade.
The De Lome family have many
friends to sympathize, if but few to
condone, for never was a woman more
fitted for political lif- or a man of
more gracious courtly manners. To
add to the sting, their two young sons
must ever be under the cloud of their
father's disgrace and can never aspire
to any position in the country to which
they have returned.
But at least Senor de Lome can re
tire with his grief and hte regrets. Senor
Lazo Arriaga 01 Guatemala, who has
lately lost his wife, cannot be alone
with his sorrow, for he is still repre
senting his country, and he must fill
his place in th_ Washington season.
Senor Lazo Arriaga and his wife were
quoted as an ideal couple, cited as the
love match of the diplomatic corps.
Mme. Lr.zo Arriaga was a Caetilian
beautyâ the type of exquisite, rare
woi-.ankind of which one reads. She
was the idol of her husband, and they
were a noble-looking pair. Mme. 7 zo
Arriag-a's death was particularly sad,
for she left nine children, the youngest
a baby of but a week or two.
Another house with an element of
tragedy hovering about it is that of
the Brazilian legation. Ser.or Men
donca is threatened with total blind
ness, and it is a {.athetic si~ht to see
his wife guiding his steps through the
gay and brilliant assemblages of a
Washington season. Senor Mendonca
has the finest collection of paintings in
Washington. He has the true artistic
temperament, and his pictures have al
ways been his delight. The affliction
that will take from him the sight of his
dearly loved tr sures is particularly
deplorable. Mme. Mendonca looks like
a Spanish woman, though she is an
American. She was born in Maine, but
went to Brazil when quite young.
There she became a governess to Senor
Mendonca's daughters, and while in
that position he fell in love with her.
Strangers always think her a Spaniard
from her appearance and an attractive
little accent.
The most popular receptions in
"Washington are those given by the
Mexican Minister and Mme. Romero.
It is h^rd to define just wherein lies
the secret of their success above oth
ers, but the palm is theirs. Mme. Ro
mero, like Mme. Pat notre, is also from
Philadelphia. She was a Miss Allen, an
heiress and a belle. The Romeros have
been longer in '.he diplomatic corps
thin any other foreign representatives.
Miss Murphy, a handsome San Fran
cisco girl, married a diplomat, Mr.
Vincent Dominguez, secretary of the
legation of the Argentine Republic.
Mme. Dominguez flashed like a meteor
upon the social season; her gowns, her
jewels and her rich beauty making her
a dazzling center for admiring gaze.
But a powerful rival to all these fair
women is the tiny-footed Mrs. Wu, the
'wife of Mr. Wu Ting- Yang, for when
ever she appears she is the center of
attraction. To no woman, no matter
how fond her liege lord, is accorded
such attentions as the Chinese Min
ister showers on his small-footed wife.
After they have made their bows to
host and hostess Mr. Wu invariably
lifts his wife in is arms and carries
her to a seat near by, while the big
footed women of other countries stand
around with the men, and no doubt
often sigh for the enforced repose of
Mrs. Wu.
The Chinese Minister is considered
one of the brightest and wittiest men
In Washington and he has the repu
tation of being able to tell a story that
would make Chauncey Depew look anx
iously to his laurels. At one of tho
famous Gridiron dinners â for which in
vitations are eagerly soug-ht and where
only the brightest and most popular
men obtain access â the best story told
after dinner was that related by Mr.
Wu Ting-Yang.
Mr. Kwai, the interpreter of the Chi
nese legation, is married to a pretty
blonde from Springfield, Massachusetts.
They have one baby, as have also the
Wus, and they all live together in the
Chinese legation.
When the ladies of the legations, the
Ministers and Embassadors, the Secre
tary of State â the only member of the
Cabinet invited to a diplomatic dinner
â and about fifteen distinguished priv
ate citizens assemble at the Whita
House, it is indeed a brilliant gather
ing. The guests, about sixty-three in
all, are presented in the east room to
President and Mrs. McKinley by Col
onel Bingham. First, the four Embas
sadors with Sir Julian Pauncefote at
the head, and then the Ministers in
the order of their arrival at the Cap
itol, the oldest resident coming first.
Mrs. McKinley sits at the right hand of
the President â instead of opposite him
as did Mrs. Cleveland â because she is
subject to fainting spells and her de
voted, lover-like husband wants her by
his side, where she is the recipient of
his watchful attentions. This manner of
placing husband and wife is remarked
upon by many, but, as Herr yon Hol
leben has remarked, it is all in the cus
tom of a country: to a German diplo
mat it is the most natural to see the
President and his wife seated thus, be
cause the Empress always sits at the
right of the Emperor, being considered
the first lady at all times.
Upon Lady Pauncefote devolves the
duty of signaling to the ladies to rise;
perhaps this motion is in many cases
not unwelcome, for in the placing of
sixty-three guests many a trying situ
ation must be involved. No doubt
sparking interchange of thought is la
bored with the Minister from Korea, no
less than when uncongeniality dampens
one's powers of repartee.
RICHARD HAMILTON POTTS.

FAVORITE DISHES OF WELL KNOWN CHEFS
EGGS, eggs, eggs, eggs in every
way.
How many eggs o you think
are consumed In San Francisco
on Easter Sun<" iy? Just stop and
do a little lightning calculation of
your own before you read on. And
then find that, though you have placed
the figures pretty hieh, you have fallen
wide of the mark. For S-n Francisco
never does anything by halves, and
when it falls a-egg-eating it means
that the chickens have had to do their
level best to provide a supply of rgs
large enough to meet the demand.
Between the hours of sunrise and
Bunset on Easter Sunday 800.000 eggs
are consumed in the city of San Fran
cisco. Eight hundred thousand eggs
demolished In one day! And that Is a
conservative estimate arrived at by
studying facts and figures as found in
the books of produce houses that sup
ply the market with eggs.
Several of the commission merchant*
place the total number of eggs con
sumed at a higher figure. But averag
ing the figures offered by those who
have the necessary data to make a
computation, the result is the startling
fact that 800,000 .eggs are used on Eas
ter Sunday.
The average length of an ci" is 2%
inciies, therefore 800.000 eggs would, if
placed Bide by side, make a line a little
over twenty-eight miles â "â â¢. length. Or
in other words, San Francisco on Eas
ter Sunday consumes twenty-eight
miles of eggs.
According to the City Surveyor s fig
ures it is a little over seven miles from
the foot of Market street to the Cliff
House. If you started in at the foot of
Market street and strung 800,000 eggs,
one touching the other, from that point
to the Cliff House, you would have
enough eggs to place a double row on
each side of the street the entire dis
tance. Ami there would still be enough
left to make scrambled eggs for a hun
dred of the bigsrest egg-eaters that the
city could produce.
.fust to what use the 800.000 eggs or
twenty-eight miles of eggs are put it
is hard to say accurately. A large
jiumber of them are converted into bril
liant colored hard-boiled Easter eggs to
rielight the eyes of the children at the
expense of their stomachs if they at
tempt to eat ti>o many. Easter comes
but once a year and most children are
allowed to give their appetites full
pwing. The number of eggs that one
healthy child can consume is in direct
ratio as Incredibly large as the number
consumed by the entire population.
The hotels and restaurants use an un
usually large number of eggs on Easter.
Nearly everyone eats eggs for break
fast on that day even though they es
chew them or. all other days. Then
dishes are selected for the menus that
require a great many eggs. A great
many families make of the Easter
morning breakfas an egg-eating con
test.
The bakeries do their share to bring
the number up to 800,000. Not only is
the demand for pi s and cakes greater
on holidays, but in order to have their
confections especially good It is neces
sary to use a larger number of eggs
than are ordinarily put into them.
Since there are almost 300.000 people
In San Francisco the 800,000 eggs, if
TIIE SAX FRANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APEIL 10, 1898.
equally distributed, would give each In
dividual 2 2-3 eggs.
In one way or another San Francisco
consumes its twenty-eight miles of eggs
âsoft or hard, colored or natural,
boiled, fried, poached, baked, scrambled
or rolled into an omelette. Some like
them hot some like them cold, children
have even been kn^wn to eat them nine
days old.
Next day there Is generally a sudden
falling off In the egg sales. An anti
egg feeling, as it were, sets in. There
are those who even wait a year before
falling to again. But when Easter
comes round again they join the jubi
lant throng in trying to drive the egg
consumption of San Francisco over the
1,000,000 mark and join the joyous Eas
ter shout of eggs, eggs, eggs.
Of Ruskin Professor Muller says
that he was uncompromising and se
vere onl;' with his pen. "He was re
ally the most tolerant and agree
able man in society. He could dis
cover beauty where no one else could
see it, and make allowances where
others saw no excuse. I remember
him as diffident as a young girl, full
of questions, and grateful for any in
formation. Even on art topics I have
watched him listening almost defer
entially to others who laid down the
law in his presence. His voice was al
ways most winni.-g, and his language
simply perfect. He was one of the
few Englishmen I knew who, instead
of tumbling out their sentences like so
many portmanteaus, bags, rugs and
hat boxes from an open railway van,
seemed to take a real delight in build
ing up their sentences, even in famil
iar conversation, so as to make each
deliverance a work of art. Later in
life that even temperament may have
suffered much, and one saw that his
wounds had not quite healed."
If ever there was an active, power
ful brain, adds Muller, !t was Rus
kin's. He worked very hard, "but I
doubt whether hard work by itself can
ever upset a healthy brain. His was a
very sensitive nature, and an over
wrought sensitiveness is much more
likely to cause mischief than steady
intellectual effort.
"I remember taking Emerson to
lunch with him in his rooms in Corpus
Christi College. Emerson was an old
friend of his. and in many respects a
cognate soul. But some quite different
subject turned up, a heated discussion
ensued, and Ruskin was so upset that
he had to quit the room and leave us
alone. Emerson was most unhappy
and did all he could to make peace,
but he had to., leave without a recon
ciliation. , â ', â ,
"It is very difficult to make allow
ance for these gradual failures or
brain power." â
Matthew Arnold Professor Mulier
had known at Oxford as an under
graduate, and he watched and ad
mired him to the end of his life. He
was beautiful as a young man, strong
and manly, yet full of dreams and
schemes. His Olympian manners be
gan even at Oxford; there was no
harm in them, they were natural, not
put on. The very sound of his voice
was Jovelike."
He was a delightful man to argue
with, not that he could easily be con
vinced that he was wrong, but he
never lost his temper, and in the most
patronizing way he would generally
end by, "Yes, yes! my good fellow, you
are quite right, but, you see, my vieÂ«.
of the matter Is different, and I hare
little doubt it is the true one!"
Of living personages, and especially
of living royalties, Professor Muller
abstains from recording his recollec
tions, a wise abstention, yet one which
undoubtedly robs his readers of much,
interesting material. But here and
there a harmless anecdote finds its
way through his reticence.
Thus he resolutely closes his lips in
regard to the Prince of Wales' stay
at Oxford, save that he considers
himself entitled to produce one small
treasure from the many he has stored
in his memory. This is a sixpence
which he won from his royal highness
at whist.
"I have always been a very bad whist
player, but good luck would have it
that I won a sixpence at Frewen Hall,
the Prince's residence at Oxford. The
Prince maintained that I had calcu
lated my points wrongly, but not be
ing a courtier, I held my own, and
actually appealed to General Bruce
When he decided in my favor, the
Prince graciously handed me my six
pence, which I have kept ever since
among my treasures."THE SAN FRANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APRIL 10, 1898,

The relief committee visited California
Lodge last Monday night and the mem
bers met with a very "vrdial greeting by
the many who were in attendance.
An individual styling himself "Dr." N.
G. Welsh presented himself to the relief
committee some time since and applied
for relief on the representation that he
was a member of Rochester .Lodge No.
756 of the Jurisdiction of Pennsylvania,
in need of temporary assistance. Since
then the committee has learned by wire
that there is no puch lodge in existence.
the impostor, who is well up in the work
of the order, and even had the semi
annual password of the previous term,
was taken to the basement of the City
Hall, where he was presented to the as
sembled watches. The officers were di
rected to watch him. All the lodges in
this jurisdiction have been warned aa to
"Dr." Welsh.
The Veteran Association will pay a
fraternal visit on Thursday next.

woman of the committee on entertain
ment.

changed its name to Conrad out of com
plimeni to thu grand president, Mrs.
Belle \Y. Conrad. The president of the
ii.-w parlor Is Miss Eva Murphy and the

burn and John Heenan as delegates to j
the Grand Court, and Henry Ruble and
John Lynch as alternates. This court
has appointed a committee to give an
entertainment on the anniversary of its
Institution.

manifested in this order, and quite a
number of courts have been working in
the initiatory degree. Most of the court

MILLINERY
DEPARTMENT
IN THE
NEW ANNEX.
It's a great responsibility catering in
Millinery to the ladles of San Francisco.
Our NEW MILLINERY DEPARTMENT Is
one of our most surprising successes.
We hoped to win favor âwe bought the
best the French and Eastern markets af-
ford â engaged Miss Ryan of New York,
Miss Kirchner as head trimmer and ten young
assistants â more orders than these ladies
could â engaged ten more assistants, and
after months of careful planningâ buyingâ our
New Millinery Department is one of which
we are justly proud. We alone did not make
It a success; but after putting before you,
ladles, the best- Millinery you Inspected, ap-
proved, bought â you caused our success.

before the grand body.
COMPANIONS OF FOREST. F. O. A.
John Bickford has been elected dele
gate from Bonlta Circle to the Grand
Circle and Miss Bailey was chosen as
alternate.
At Golden Gate Council last Tuesday
night seven candidates were initiated.
The grand chief companion has an
nounced the following visits: Thursday,
the 14th. to Orange Blossom Circle, Oro
vllle; 15th, Yuba Circle, Marysville; 19th,
Presidio Circle, San Francisco; 20th, Sur
prise Circle, Woodland; 23d, Freedom
Circle, Nevada City; 27th, University
Circle, Golden Gate. She will make them
in the month of May.
KNIGHTS AND LADIES OF HONOR.
The eleventh session of the Grand
Lodge of the Knights and Ladies of
Honor will be held In this city In Pythian
Castle on the 19th inst. Mrs. Belle W.
Conrad will retire from the office of
grand protector, and Z. T. Whitten of
this city and H. C. Traphagen of San
Jose will be candidates for the office. S.
B. Carleton, who for eleven years has
been a very efficient grand secretary, will
decline the offer to be continued in office,
on account of other Interests demanding
too much of his time. A. Gompertz and
H. W. Qultzow are candidates for the
office.
The past grand protector of Sacra
mento was in this city last week.
NATIONAL UNION.
Last Monday evening at the meeting of
Yosemite Council there was the initiation
of one candidate, after which A. A. Her
zog was elected usher and F. G. Rumpf
speaker. It was decided that hereafter,
after initiation In this council, there
shall be a programme of song, music and
talks, also a collation.
Last Tuesday night California Council,
after the business meeting, was enter
tained with an interesting programme,
during which there was a great deal of
talk in favor of supporting "Old Glory-"
C. E. Kerr entertained with a solo vocali
zation, Joseph Semeria told some comic
stories, Vice-President H. A. Graves read
an Instructive article on fraternal insur
ance, the quartet charmed the council
with vocal selections, and Secretary King,
Past President Hastings and Messrs. Gib
son and Copperwaithe roused the council
to a high pitch of enthusiasm by ad
dresses on the duty of the hour in up
holding the honor of the United States
and standing by the American flag.
Golden Gate Council will next Tuesday
have several candidates to initiate.
Prospects are that the entertainment to
be given on the 19th of May in Odd Fel
lows' Hall In celebration of the anniver
sary of the order will be a grand affair.
THE CHOSEN FRIENDS.
There was a good attendance in the
hall of Empire Council on last Monday
night on the occasion of the official visit
Of the grand officers. Addresses were j
made by Grand Councilor Boehm, Su
preme Councilor Button, Grand Recorder i
Wallis and Past Supreme Councilor Ar- |
nold. There were also remarks by mem
bers and visitors and the membership
promised to advance the interests of the
order by personal efforts.
Social Council had an initiation last
Thursday night, and after the work there
were addressee by Past Supreme Coun
cilor Arnold. Assistant Grand Councilor
Savage, Grand Recorder Wallis, Deputy
Gibson and others. California Council ]
will consolidate with the council on the
21st inst., and on that evening there will
be an entertainment of the new mem
bers. The council expects to initiate
ten members before the close of May.
Last Tuesday Assistant Grand Coun
cilor Savage and Grand Recorder Wallis
visited Teutonia Council and witnessed an
initiation conducted in the German lan
guage. The council was addressed by the
visitors.
The grand officers will visit Crystal
Council on the 14th inst.
There will be a district meeting of the
THE SAIS T FRANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APRIL 10, 1898.
HALE BROS.
All those delicate touches necessary for personal adornment for Easterâ all those little aids which woman, lovely
woman, uses to still further increase her charmsâ all these have been bought, and the Easter woman is symbolical
of all that is chic in Fashion's realm. Now
THE HOUSEWIFE TURNS TO BEAUTIFYING THE HOME.
After we get a work of art, such as an oil painting, we enhance its value by a good frame, and so a good housewife
further surrounds her charms by thoroughly renovating her home after Easter. Down come the curtains, up with
carpets. There's a reign of soap
. . . AND . . .
Elbow-greaseâ there's a feeling of discomfort for hubby for a time; but after the home takes on clean carpets, new
curtains, new bedspreads, the dining room receives its new linen, madame's boudoir receives brighter huesâ and hubby's
library its spring cleaning ! After all this
LIFE SEEMS AGAIN ONE BRIGHT HONEYMOON.
It's so, good wife, isn't it? You know how it was last year. Hard time, spring cleaning! But then how satis-
fied hubby isâ what a cosy air the clean-up has given your home, and life is brighter. Did we help you then?
If we did you were satisfied. If we didn't we want to this year.

IMPROVED ORDER OF RED MEN.
Last Monday night Osceola and Winne
mucca tribes had high life below stairs
in the big wigwam on Post street. It was
a grand smoker given by the two t ibes
in the basement of the wigwam, at the
suggestion of F. B. Swan, D. D. G. S.
Under the direction of W. E. E. Klipstein
of Osceola Tribe, who was the master of
ceremonies, there was presented a very
entertaining programme, and between
numbers a committee passed around pipes
and tobacco and a collation with accom
panying refreshments. The programme
included a short address by Deputy Swan,
trio by Messrs. Childers, Baumhauer and
Skirvin, recitation and presentation of
stereopticon views by Mr. Jennings, duets
by Klipstein brothers, recitation by F. D.
Brandon, banjo solo by G. Bramhall, ad
dress by Grand Chief of Records C. F.
Burgman and other numbers by volun
teers.
Great Senior Sagamore Joseph Allison
of the Great Council of Pennsylvania, the
largest jurisdiction of the order. In a let
ter to Henry A. Chase. P. G. S., of this
city, says: "We expect to have a large
increase this great sunâ sure it will be
2500. Our present great sachem. Dr. Rod
gers, worked faithfully and zealously for
our order, and deserves all success possi
ble. I visited thirty-six tribes outside of
Philadelphia, been In twelve different
counties and traveled nearly 2200 miles.
Found all the tribes working well and
gaining in membership. We meet in
Honesdale next May and expect to make
a good report to the urand Council."
DEGREE OF POCAHONTAS.
At the meeting of the Daughters of
Montezuma Council in its wigwam last
Monday night two palefaces were adopt
ed, the work being done in a very satis
factory manner by the chiefs. After the
ceremony there were some short talks for
the good of tn*> order, and that was fol
lowed by the serving of a light collation
and the passing of a social hour.
WOODMEN OF THE WORLD.
A new camp, composed entirely of Red
Men of the Improved Order, will be insti
tuted in the Red Men's wigwam on the
evening of next Wednesday. It has been
organized by H. B. Jennings, a hard
worker for fraternal advancement and
one of the great chiefs of the Red Men.
It will be, in compliment to the order
from which the membership is drawn,
called Calumet.
Head Manager Boak will go to Chico on
Thursday next to aUend a grand rally of
Woodmen in that place.
Next Wednesday evening the degree
team of Spruce tamp of Alameda will
confer the degree on a number of candi
dates for camps, botn cnarter and pro
visional, in the hall of Golden Gate Camp,
in Native Sons' Hall. As this is one of the
best teams in the jurisdiction, it will at
tract a large attendance of choppers.
Past Head Counsel Moses will shortly
attend a session of Woodmen in Salt Lake
City, when steps will be taken to form
ulate a reserve fund, a feature whicn all
new organizations are adopting.
Golden Gate Camp will give another
log-roller, with the view of beating the
record made at the last one held â t..at of
securing 107 applications.
COMPANIONS OF THE FOREST.
The open meeting by Loyal Circle
to-morrow night will be marked by an
excellent programme of song, recitations
and fancy dancing. The affair is to be
strictly invitational.
The Past Chiefs' Association will rive
a social on the 14th Inst. On the 12th Vio
let Circle will give a social, on the 16th
Washington Circle will give one and on
the 23d Loyal Circle is to give a ball.
The prospects are that two or three new
circles will be instituted In this city be
fore the first of May.
California Circle announces a private
masquerade for the 20th Inst.

SOCIETY.
The dizzy whirl of society will be re
sumed after to-day, and dances, hops,
luncheons, theater parties and weddings !
innumerable are promised for the near ;
future.
Society has been busily planning for ;
the last few weeks, and the Easter bon- j
net is ready for Its fair wearer, and tne j
buds promise to look sweeter than ever |
this year.
The season of pleasure will not be long
here, for hardly will the Easter bells have
rung out their joyous peals before it will
be time for the fair devotees at the shrine
of society to be tripping away to their
country homes.
Mrs. Ed Newhall entertained the Colo
nial Dames at a colonial breakfast at her '
home in San Rafael on Tuesday. 'me
service was of old silver and china. The
ladies went across the bay on the 11
o'clock boat, and held a short business 1
session before sitting down to breakiast.
A merry afternoon was spent, the twen
ty-five guests returning to the city at 5
o'clock.
Owing to Holy Week, the musical ride
to have been given on Thursday by the
San Francisco Kiding Club was deferred,
as many members did not care to partici
pate.
The members of the Entre Nous Cotll- j
lon will give their sixth assembly and :
gc-rman on Friday evening, April 29, at |
the Palace Hotel.
ihe members of the N. S. L. -K. 10
have issued invitations .or an "at home"
for next Tuesday evening, April 12, at ;
Sherman, Clay & Co's Hall. It promises i
to be a most successful and brilliant
gathering.

and Miss Rutherford of Mrs. Long.

The wedding of Howard Badger, for
merly of Stockton but now with the Bell
Telephone Company In this city, and
Miss Mary Ellen Thomas, daughter of
Mayor W. R. Thomas of Oakland, â will
take place on Wednesday, April 20, at
the home of the bride's parents, 816
Eleventh street, Oakland, in the presence
of relatives and intimate friends only.
Miss Irene Baker and Miss Ethel Bates
will be the bridesmaids and A. D. Fitz
nugh will act as best man. After the
wedding there will be an informal recep
tion. The couple will pass their honey
moon on a southern trip, after which
they will reside at the corner of Market
and Eleventh streets, Oakland.

The wedding will take place the middle
of May.

Wedding Bells.
A dainty wedding took place at high
noon at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on
Wednesday. The participants were Wil
liam H. Levings. a prominent young :
journalist of this city, and Miss N. Lillian
Walker, daughter of Mrs. Orveille N.
Purely of Boston.
Miss Mildred Well was married to Julius
S. Schweizer at the home of her parents, j
ISI4 Pine street. Rev. J. Voorsanger offi- ;
elated. The bride wore a traveling gown j
of pearl gray. A handsome hat completed j
! the toilet. Her bouquet was of lilies of â¢
I the valley. Miss Ella Schweizer. sister of
; the groom, was maid of honor. Her gown
' was of pure silk and chiffon. Miss Annie
. Weil and Miss Edna Weil, sisters of the
1 bride, were the other attendants. Their j
: frocks were of organdie, one over pink, the !
other over blue silk. Bernhard Weil was
i best man and Alexander Schoenfeld, Al
plionse Weil. Davis Schoenfeld. Leo Weil
and S. B. Hamburger the ushers. Alma
â  Schoenfeld, as flower girl, led the proces
sion, which came in to the march of
: Mendelssohn, played by Julius, Alva and
j Milton Posner and Miss Grace Crocker.
I The bride was attended by her father and
Mrs. Well, who wore a handsome black
velvet and stood with the wedding partj'.

Phoebe Greenbaum took place Sunday
week at the residence of the groom's sis
ter, 722 Golden Gate avenue. Rev. Dr.
Levy officiated. Only the immediate rela
tives were present.

! King of Los Alamos were married on

parents. Mr. and Mrs. K. Morris, 1309

A quiet but very pretty wedding was
celebrated at 1817 McAllister street, the
residence of Mr. and Mrs. A. Mayfield,
when their daughter, Miss Lillie Mayfield,
was united in marriage to Mr. Lipman
M. Kaiser by the Rev. I. Myer. The cer
l emony took place in the presence of the
| immediate families of the young couple,
and scores of congratulatory telegrams
| were received from all parts of the globe.
Mr. Kaiser is a member of the well
known firm of Hlrsch & Kaiser and Miss
Mayfield is one of California's most beeu
tiful and accomplished daughters. The
parlors were handsomely decorated for
the occasion with ferns, smilax and roses
and were a veritable bower of beauty.
Mr. and Mrs. Kaiser will be at home at
1620 McAllister street after their return
from the South.

wedding of David H. Green, the young
commission merchant, and Miss Carrie
Wood, which took place at the home of
the bride's parents. Mr. and Mrs. S. N.
Wood. 1458 Page street. The ceremony
was performed by the Rev. Dr. Neito
shortly after noon. The parlors were
artistically decorated with roses, lilies
and smllax.
After the ceremony the twenty rela
tives present partook of an elaborate
breakfast, after which Mr. and and Mrs.
Green left for Del Monte, where the hon
eymoon will be spent. Upon their return
they will reside at 1458 Page street.
The wedding of Herman Sternan and
Miss Esther Cohen, daughter of Philip
Cohen, the California pioneer, took place
on Sunday at the home of Sigmund
Strauss, 1452 Leavenworth street. It was
a quiet affair.
The wedding of Arthur M. Humphrey,
with the firm of Taft & Pennoyer, and
Miss Mollie E. Shull took place on the
evening of the 30th ultimo at the home
of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Will
iam Shull, 53$ Jones street, Oakland. The
ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr.
Coyle.
Ir\ Charity's Name.
The Board of Lady Managers of the
Eye and Ear Hospital, at 1107 Sutter
street, have undertaken to give a musl
cale and tea on the 16th of this month
at the residence of Mrs. Rebecca Jen
nings, which has been generously placed
at their disposal for the purpose. The
entertainment will be conducted in rather
a novel manner. It will not adhere to the
customary rigid programmes of such
affairs. Instead, it is intended to pre
sent specimens of the music of all na
tions, performed by appropriately cos
tumed performers, especial attention be
ing given to that of the Orient and its
peculiarly picturesque adornment. The
affair will borrow additional eclat fronÂ»
being held in a favorable social environ
ment and under the auspices of so many
prominent ladies who constitute the
patrons of the worthy charity.
The young ladies who belong to the
auxiliary of the Children's Hospital de
termined to give up a day of each week
during Lent to sewing; not toying with
the needle and thread, concocting useless
trifles, but real serious sewing. And so
yards and yards of bright tennis flannel
were bought, scissors snapped merrily
fingers unused to the needle became deft
with practice, and the result is a heaping
pile of dainty little sacques.
This morning every child in the hospital
will be given one of these sacques. There
are pale pinks, dainty, blues, brilliant
crimsons and every other conceivable
shade to delight the eyes of the children.
And they are so soft and comfortable
in addition to being pretty. The chil
dren ought to have them, but many of
them are without them. One day one of
the doctors casually remarked "that it
would be a very pleasant thing for the
sick children if someone could devote one
afternoon a week in reading and playing
with them. And so it was that several
young ladies determined that the best
way to observe Lent would be to supply
this deficiency.
The young ladies who have met every
week to sew on these sacaues are the
Misses Ella Morgan, Mollie Thomas,
Helen Thomas, Therese Morgan, Helen
Hopkins, Edna Hopkins, Caro Crockett,
Emily Carolan, Genevieve Carolan, Alice
Hagar, Bertha Smith, Minnie Houghton,
Mary Eyre, Laura Bates, Gertrude Bates,
Miriam Moore, Frances Moore, Julia Av
erill, Clara Smedberg and Edith McÃean.
personals.
Miss Ethel Keeney, with her grand
mother, Mrs. William Alvord, and Dr. J.
W. Keeney, left for New York on Sunday
last.

. .. .. ;7.-;;.-.- - â ' â -; ->Church Windows.
FOR the combined purposes of ornamentation, practical use and the 11
lustration of religious thought, no portion of a sacred edifice Is more
rtant than its windows. In them the art of the day finds expres
through the grace of the designer and the skill of the painter; the
resa of the stained glass industry of the period is manifest, the
taptp? â  !' the people apparent and their faiths and dogmas set forth so dis
tinctly that the historian, by turning to them, can discern at a glance the
artisanship and spiritual condition of the era In which the windows were
placed. Indeed, as monuments of historical worth, church windows can
scarcely be surpassed In value. By their mute yet eloquent agency, the mile
stones of religious progress may be traced from the sixth century to the pres
ent day, for colored windows existed at Constantinople at that time and also
in St. Peter's at Rome, and historians agree that they were in use as early
a? the third century. In Alsace may bt? seen a window of the eleventh cen
tury, undoubtedly the oldest specimen of the stained glass art which has sur
vived the ravages of time and accident. The most superb window of the pres
ntury is declared to be in the Parliament House, Edinburg. It is an
example of the Munich School of glass painting.
Windows for ecclesiastical usage, formed by mosaics of colored glass,
MEMORIAL WINDOW, TRINITY CHURCH.
one canonized here. The next largest windows are the
sanctuary window in the cathedral at Sacramento and
the transept windows in St. Francis de Sales, Oakland.
Three fine memorial windows have been recently
placed in Trinity Episcopal Church by Walter E. Dean,
George Marye Jr. and George A. Pope. These represent
Munich in ecclesiastical art, the subjects being "Christ
og Little Children," "The Resurrection" and "Ser
mon on the Mount." A pretty window, though not large,
in Trinity is a X" >i n t â¢ '<l <me in the southeast transept, rep
resenting the baptism of Jesus Christ by St. John. A hand
some gift is the Calef window in the west wall.
A London window in Grace Church represents "Christ
ing Little Children." The same subject is carried
out with tenderness and skfil in the chapel of Maria Kip
â¢'â¢rphan.'tgf, the only stained glass window placed there,
and a beautiful piece of work.
St. Ignatius, one of the finest structures of its kind In
the United States and owning the largest and finest or
gan in the country, has only foreign windows in its mas
sive walls. St. B^rigid's is ornamented by a handsome
circular window some eight feet in diameter, exceedingly
rich in coloring, the center space presenting a life-like
portrait of the late Archbishop Alemany. Three win
dows in the Russian church are of local origin.
St. Mary's Church of the Paulist Fathers, for many
years a landmark on California street, has fourteen win
dows of especial interest. The two largest portray re
spectively "St. Paul Preaching at Athens," after Raphael's
Famous painting, and "The Conversion of St. Paul," after
Rubens. The Frank J. Sullivan memorial is a notice
ably fine window in St. Mary's.
St. Mary's Cathedral on Van Ness avenue, a splendid
plr-ro of architecture, has five local figure-windows of
much-admired workmanship, the majority of the others
being European. An Eastern memorial window of original
design is that In the Spanish Church on Broadway, lllus-
THE SAX FRANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APIiIL 10, 1898.
painted with an enamel *
made permanent by fire,
and presenting pictures
with the fidelity of an oil
painting made transparent,
had their origin in Chris
tian religion, although
Egypt in ancient times
used enamels to ornament
the surface of glass.
France and Germany claim
the distinction of discover
ing the art, but It is prob
ably in Italy that it was
conceived. During the thir
teenth century Italy gave
the works of many masters
to the world, but with the
passing of the centuries
her achievements have
ceased, and Germany now
leads in this, one of the
most noble of the arts.
The windows of the mod
ern house of worship are
the last subjects for con
sideration of the builders.
They do not, as a rule, ever
enter into the plans of the
contractor, but are the
gifts of wealthy members
of the congregation. The
erection of memorial and
decorative windows has
long been a custom both
appropriate and interest
ing, and fortunes innum
erable are yearly expend
ed in this way throughout
the world.
San Francisco, though so
far distant from the art
centers of the "t>!d world,
has not been deprived of
these objects of beauty. In
our churches may be found
splendid specimens from
Munich, a few of Eastern
make, one or two from
London, but â and this
speaks well for local art
and home industry â the
majority were manufac
tured here. To enumerate
all would be impossible, but
several of the most nota
ble may be mentioned. Of
these the greatest in size
west of the Rocky Moun
tains is in St. Rose's
Church, 16x33 feet, a
Gothic window beautifully
executed, representing St.
Rose of Lima in Dominican
garments, with a halo ol
her is the
Angrel of
Peace, bear
ing a palm
branch. St.
Rose is the
patron saint
of America,
and the only

WINDOW,

trating the presentation by a native shepherd of the image of Guadalupe tt>
the Bishop.
The Frauen Verein some years ago gave a costly window to St. Paul's
Lutheran Church. Upon its left is Ste Paul with sword, to the right St. Pe
ter with keys; above, Bible, chalice and dove. The effect is striking, the
color scheme and execution most excellent.
"Christ Walking on the Water" is the theme of a very artistic piece of
work in St. Peter's on Alabama street. St. Francis is fortunate in its pos
session of "Our Lady of Lourdes" and "Sacred Heart." A window of note
in Westminster Presbyterian is the Greenwood memorial.
St. Dominic's has a beautiful window, delicate in coloring, yet charmingly
distinct, representing St. Raymon. The window attracts by reason of its ad
mirable detail, rather than its size.
Holman Hunt's celebrated picture, "Light of the World," is repeated with
fine effect in glass in St. John's Episcopal Church. The chancel windows here
are worthy of study. They are originals and represent the nativity, cruci
fixion and resurrection. Another notable window, a memorial, is the one ded
icated to St. John, in St. John's Presbyterian Church. The figure is finely
done and the coloring exceptionally pleasing.
St. Joseph's
has a sanctuary
window ex
tremely rich in
Its blended and
contrast ing
hues. "The Na
tivity" is the
Bubject. Here also the eye
rests with admiration upon
two memorial works of
stained glass art, the deli
cate tinting of which was
chosen because of the posi
tion they hold in regard to
light, "The Sacred Heart of
Our Lord" and "Sacred Heart
of the Virgin." The two ed
ifices now in course of con
struction, Holy Cross and
the new St. Luke's, will
ients of fine windows.
ROUND
WINDOW,
ST. BRiGID'S
CHURCH.
The custom of giving win
dows to churches is charac
teristic of all countries.
Gifts of superb masterpieces
are a source of pride and
pleasure to the donor, and no
testimonial of regard for a
dear one passed away or of
interest in the perpetuation
of religious thought, could
be more satisfactory or en
during. A handsome church
window is literally a thing
of beauty and a joy forever,
for unless wantonly destroy
ed by an act of vandalism it
is capable of withstanding
the forces of nature for cen
turies untold. Throughout
the ages it may serve the
manifold purposes of protec
tion from the elements, of
demonstration that a re
markable branch of art may
outlive nations themselves,
and of providing an object
lesson of singular historic in
terest. Thus the giver of a
window knows that the deed
is not one to last but a day
or a lifetime, but for a pe
riod the length of which no
prophet may determine.
The chief peculiarity of
church windows Is the irreg
ular system of lines travers
ing their surface, sharply
visible within as black divid
ing marks, but noticeable
from without as merely a
metallic means of connect
ing the colored panels. Opin
ion varies as to the desira
bility of these in point of
beauty, and unsuccessful at
tempts have been made to do
away with them, but their
utility in fastening together
the many pieces of mosaic
and the strength thus given to the whole make them indispensable. Ribbons of lead,
soldered at every angle, furnish this required support. So much a component cart of
the art are these lines that to eliminate them would d t th ti h f t
him who has studied with feeling the subject of windows
as offerings at the shrine of religion. In no way do they
interfere with the pictured whole, if properly placed.
Artists who paint on glass are confronted with condi
tions entirely absent from those in which the painter of
canvases employs his skill. It will be readily understood
that the methods of painting upon opaque and transpar
ent surfaces are essentially different. Outlines must be
sufficiently sharp to be seen clearly at a distance, else
the effect will be either wholly or partially lost upon the
observer, when figures are reproduced. In short, it is a
department of the painter's art that is a law unto itself.
The high lights are the natural color of the glass, known
to the artistas "pure" or "local" color. To produce
shadows or accentuated colors the enamel is laid on with
corresponding thickness. The glass must previously be
burnt very carefully in order to fix the enamel thereon. Dur
ing the last century England produced a number of not
able glass painters who have left us some fine specimens
of their handiwork.
THE NATIVITY, ST. IGNATIUS CHURCH.
Inseparable from the thought of church worship is the
softened, prismatic light cast within by transparent pic
tures that are sermons in themselves. He who con
structs them leaves a niche for himself In history, but of
those who see his achievements comparatively few realize
or appreciate the Infinite pains he has taken to produce
such results, or the high order of talent and careful plan
ning necessary to accomplish them. The maker of win
dows must be in thorough accord with his work in order
to be successful. He must be a student, a mechanic and
an artist, his idea of the fitness of things unerring, his
judgment thoroughly reliable. The slightest incongruity
in the work is not only perceived by all who are capa
ble of criticizing Its quality, but it will remain a lasting
reproach to him. There is no more pitiless searcher for
defects than the daylight, which, penetrating a window,
reveals its Imperfections, or, finding none, brings forth
for admiration of the observer the wonders that the maker
has wrought.
"When barrel organs, once the usual accompaniment of
the magic lantern, came into use, a native of the prov
ince of Tende was one of the first who traveled about
Europe with this Instrument.
In his peregrinations he collected money enough to
enable him to purchase from the King of Sardinia the
title of count of the country where he was born â for
which, probably, in a time of war, he did not pay above
a thousand guineas.
With the remainder of his money he purchased an es
tate suitable to his rank, and settled himself peaceably
for the remainder of his days in his mansion.
In the entrance hall of his dwelling he hung up his
magic lantern and his organ facing the door, there to
be carefully preserved till they moldered to dust; and
he ordered by his will that any one of his descendants who
should cause them to be removed should forfeit his in
heritance, and his patrimony revert to the next heir, or,
in failure of a successor, to the hospital of Tende.
Only a few years ago the organ and lantern wert still
to be seen carefully preserved.

conducts that comic monthly. The La

Itself apparent even in The departments j
supposed to be conducted by those more
or less intelligent females, who as
sume to give counsel to our wives, our
sisters and our daughters on the meth- I
ods they should adopt for the proper j
conduct of their li>jes. Do you wish
to know how many tlmet per evening
it is considered comme-il-faut to em
brace your best young lady? Ovid Bok
Will enlighten you. Are you in doubt
as to whether or not you should eat
ice-cream with a fork? Consult Ches- .
terfield Bok and he will guide you. Are
you anxious for political or diplomatic
preferment? Talleyrand Bok will as
sist you. Would you seek wealth on
the Klondike? Here are Expert Bok's
potent and original observations on the j
subject: "Chances on the Klondike de
pend, as everything else does, on the
young man who
takes th^m. So far
as the life is con
cerned, I think it Is
one of hardship and
dep ri v ation." "I
think" is good in

traying as it does
an intimate knowl
edge of the subject,
combined with an
unsought-for and
unexpected d i ffl
dence.
Talieynrd Bolt
N'nw, I am not one of those who, to
employ tho words of the first Psalm,
"pit in the seat of the scornful," at the
mention of religious matters, nor would
I. when hearing them discussed, an
swer with the sneer or the false pro
phet of old. "Which way wont the
spirit of th* Lord?" Nevertheless, 1
am decidedly opposed to the adminis
tration of spiritual advice and consola
tion In homeopathic doses, and regard
it little less than blasphemy to mix sec
ular and r^llginus matt j) in the man
ner that Mr. Bok does !n his Ladies'
Home Journal. Rarely a month passes
where this error against the canons of
good taste is not committed in Its most
flagrant form. Take the April Issue
for Instance. On page 40, in a column
headed "Problems of Young Men," by
Edward W. Bok. you may read this:
A YOt'NG MANS GREATEST HELP.
