TEACHERS AND SCHOOLS.
The convention of the Southern Cali
fornia Teachers' Association, which was
held In Los Angeles during March 31 to
April 2, was largely attended by dele
gations of teachers from all the southern
counties.
One of the most Interesting talks of
the session was by Professor Starbuck of
Stanford, who took for his subject a
phase of child study which he called
ire Hewa First in the Rough." Pro
fessor Starbuck began by describing how
nature builds in minerals and in plants,
and then said that the teacher is learn
ing the secret that the same process of
development is followed in the human
being. If all this were thoroughly un-
Serstood, it would aid very materially in j
:he work of the school room.
Professor Starbuck emphasized the im
portance of kindergartens and manual
training in bringing all the activities of
\.he child into play. Touch, he asserted,
.s also fundamental, and at 12 years the
'.hinking machinery should be developed.
Esthetics and morals are tho funda
mentals of child nature. We must see
that these fundamentals are deeply in- |
grained in the child, and then nature will I
:ake tare of its own.
Professor J. IL Guinn made a strong
plea for systematic teaching of local his
tory as a "means of cultivating a love for
the subject and also as a preliminary j
step in the study of national and general
history.
"No State," said the speaker, "has a
more instructive, a more interesting or a i
more varied history than California, and
no State has had so many different forms
Of government. First, a semi-military, !
Bemi-eeclesiastical dependence of Spain; ,
next a territory of Mexico; then the
Estado Libre de Californiaâ a republic

EDUCATION IN SANTA CRUZ.
Santa Cruz Ccinty has a school system
of which It Is justly proud, not only on
account of the. high standard that has
been attained, but because it dates as far
back as IM9â the year of gold. Few of
our California counties can make a like
boast.
The first school in Santa Cruz of which
there is any record was private, con
ducted by a Mrs. Case. One or two other
private schools were also opened a little
later, but a public school with an enroll
ment of twenty-five pupils was started In
1853 by Mr. Frick.
In 18C9 we find >0 pupils recorded.
Other school houses "were erected as the
need came, and In IST6 a high school was
established, which -was regarded with
great pride by the townspeople. Profes
sor \V. \V. Anderson was the first prin
cipal, and the school prospered under his
administration.
Mr. D. C. Clark was chosen principal
! in 18S4, and has ever since remained in
charge of the school. From the beginning
of his administration, and later as City
Superintendent of Schools, Mr. Clark has
! spared no time nor energy to advance tho
; cause of education in his chosen field. Ho
at once began to remodel the course of
study in the schools, and with the aid
of the county superintendent. J. W. Lin
i scott, and a corps of forty-four willing
| and efficient teachers, he placed the
| schools upon the firm basis they occupy
| to-day, and so spread the fame of them
' that "pupils from other counties flocked
in, until the old school houses were over
crowded. This necessitated the erection
of the new Lincoln School and the recon
struction of the Laurel and Branclforte
buildings.
In 18t>9 the University of California rec
ognized the excellence of the. preparatory
work accomplished In the high school,
and placed the school on Its accredited
' list. Miss Minnie Sullivan and Louis
Bernhelm were the first graduates to
enter the. State University.
Connected with the public schools of
Santa Cruz is a free kindergarten em
ploying two teachers. This is also under
the management of Mr. Clark.
NATURE STUDY IN OUR PUBLIC SCHOOLS.
When tho child's initial life in the
j schoolroom begins we should foster a
love of the study and guide him aright
I in the perception of the good and beauti
i ful as it is found in nature and nature's
works.
Make the study 83 practical as pos
sible and treat it as a whole. Tiring
plant! and flowers into your schoolroom
to better illustrate your work, lie lavish
; in your decorations and collections of
i thebe treasures from nature's storehouse.

She appears to be the only American

rhinoceros-like hides of our local four

Also encourage your pupils to make col- 1
lections. This will naturally lead to lit
tle talks on the plants and animals they
have observed. First take up the most '
familiar forms, noticing their different
characteristics and comparing them, I
then gradually enlarge your researches :
until all known forms peculiar to the i
vicinity have bÂ«en described. Relate short

Require at times illustrated composi
tions. Ry training children to use their'
own eyes we improve the work in draw- ! ,
ing and at the same time furnish food for
thought. Children express in language
much better that which they find out
themselves by observation. This gives
them self-confidence, and In addition cul
tivates their powers of observation, love
of literature, truth telling, truth-seeking
and increases their vocabulary.
Systematic nature study in the gram
mar schools would give an impetus to the
study of botany, zoology, etc.. In the
high schools. These studies exert a
moral Influence, broaden the sympathies,
elevate their tastes and lead them to
higher thoughts. ANNIE BASS.
Redding, Cal.
FROM SAN BERNARDINO COUNTY.
Last week, after one of the most suc
cessful meetings ever held there, the
San Bernardino County Teachers' Insti
tute adjourned to meet for the remain
ing three days with the Southern Cali
fornia Teachers' Association in Los An
i geles.
Tho sessions were held in the High
School building in San Bernardino, and
great interest and enthusiasm was mani
fested in the entire programme.
Interest was manifested in the speci
mens of drawing, penmanship, composi
tion and science work from the various
county schools which decorated the walls
and tables. One of the most artistic fea
tures of the display, classed as drawing,
was the modeling, paper cutting, fold
ing, designing, border making, etc., which
showed a commendable beginning In the
line of manual training. The Lugonia
and the Redlands schools exhibited cred
itable work In sewing and drafting on
paper.

THE SHAPING OF MODELS.
Once -in the presence of Disraeli an
over-confident youth ventured to ridicule
the proverb makers. "Any one," he said,
"could make proverbs in quantity." And
the statesman answered: "MaKe a few!"
It is needless to say thnt. had the young
man accepted the challenge, he would
have acquired a sudden and lasting re
spect for a genuine proverb.
Now a series of Sloyd models is a good
deal like a collection of proverbs. They
are plain, unpretentious affairs, but there
is a great deal in the reason of their be
ing. The original Sloyd school at Naas,
Sweden, has been in operation for twen
ty-five years, yet Dr. Saloman's teachers
aYe still altering the courses, each year
introducing new models and modifica
tions of old ones.
Recent years have seen numerous am
bitious attempts made, both In this coun
try and England, to originate systems of
manual training, but thus far there is
not a successful elementary manual
training course In operation in either
country that has not Naas to thank for
its foundation principles. These princi
ples are:
L Gradation of difficulty.
The exercises must proceed from
known to unknown, from simple to com
plex, from the easy to the difficult. In
this respect articles made of wood are
very misleading In appearance. But tho
basis of organization lies not In the mod
els themselves, but In' the tool exercises
which they embody. Here, then, Is a
question of tool-sequence:
Are Borne of the wood-working tools
easier of manipulation than others?
Of two or more exercises with the same
tool, may one be easier than another?
The answer in both cases is affirmative.
It Is a simple enough matter to roughly
cut a stick in two with a cross-cut saw,
but quite another to put a good bevel on
that same stick with a chisel.
The Naas people think the Sloyd knife
is the best adapted for the beginning, and
so the first two or three models of the
Naas series are small modeled articles re
quiring the use of the knife. In England
it does not seem to have occurred to them
that there is such a thing as tool se
quence, except among tho teachers, who
are following the Swedish system.
In tho manual training courses of the
stage of his story. "A Desert Drama '
narrates the startling adventures of a
party of ten. who are captured by the
Dervishes while engaged in the explor
ation of Egyptian ruins. The dramatis
personae comprise three' impossible
Americans, an equally impossible
Frenchman, a dry-as-dust English so
llcltor with a penchant for the use of
legalising, and two or three students
archaeologically inclined. These fill a
short volume of a couple of hundred
pages, which you may read in an hour
with some little interest, but without
much profit.
* â¢ â¢
My compliments to "Chames." a gen
tleman employed on the staff of the
Boston Traveller, and will he please
accept my thanks for being the direct
cause of my indulgence in a series of
broad grins' at his parody on Mr. Kip
ling's "Vampire." I reprint it here
that my readers jnay also enjoy it.
ANOTHER "VAMPIRE."
(A long way after Kipling.)
An ass there was. and be took delight
(Even as you and I)
In sitting far Into the hours of night.
Cutting and dealing with all his might.
And hating to quit at the morning light
(Even as you and I).
Oh. the Bleep we lost and the heap we lost.
And the useless cards we drew;
All In that simple and popular game.
That always enticing and popular game.
Which there's no need to name for you.
An am there was. and he held a "pair"
(Even as you and I)
Of aces, and drew two more quite fair.
Then bet all he had. with never a cars.
But a "straight flush" broke him beyond
pair,
(Even as you and I).
Oh. the moans we made and the groans we
made
O'er the pots that we ought to have won,
All In that simple and popular game.
That gentleman's gamp, the American game.
Where you get a good run for your "mon."
Still the ass will play when he has the doagh
(Even an you and I)
And the chips will come and the chips will go;
He'll say with a nod when they're oomlng
â¢low,
"It's time for my luck to change, you know"
(Even as you and I).
And it Isn't the sin and It isn't thÂ» tin
That makes us all sore and 111;
It's thinking of hands that we ought to nave
held.
The "fulls" and the "fours" that we ought to
have held,
And the "flushes" we couldn't fill.
EMANUEL ELZAS.
UNDER THE DUTCHMAN'S RULE
SHREWSBURYâ By Stanley J. Weyman.
New York: Longmans. Green & Co.
For sale by Doxey. Price $1 50.
Of the historical novelists of the modern
school there is probably no writer who
turns out his work in a more clear cut,
conscientious fashion than Mr. Weyman.
If he is less romantic than Anthony
Hope, if his heroes lack the blind dare
devil chivalry of Conan Doyle's, he Is at
any rate more graphic -and concise, his
Characters move naturally in their ap
pointed epoch, and nothing of local color
that careful study of the period can pro
vfde Is lacking.
It Is difficUit. however, in spite of the
admirable technique displayed, to follow
the developments of this novel with sus
tained interest. It is a complicated story
of court intrigues during that stormy
period of English political life which fol
lowed the downfall of the Stuarts and the
restoration of the Protestant succession.
William 111, promoted from the humble
position of stadtholder in Holland to
the dazzling position of King of England,
was but Insecurely seated on the throne.
Many of the nobles and a large propor
tion of the commonalty were opposed to
his rule, the air was full of intrigue, and |
plot after plot for his deposition and for '
the restoration of King James was form- j
future, physiological psychology wu
likely have a say. Ltanley Hall and oth
ers are showing that the musculr- or
ganization of a child does not develop
simultaneously throughout. Thus, a ciind
has learned to push his arms about and
run while It is still a difficult matter ior
him to pick up a pin.
J. Liberty Todd of Philadelphia has de
veloped a remarkable system of drawing
on this basis, Jus younger pupils stand
at the board, and with both hands tiraw
large free designs in place of the crariped
affairs usually found In drawing-books.
There is food for thought here for those
who are trying to drag woodwork down
into the primary grades, the proper place
for clay modeling an^ caruooard work.
We cannot develop the pupils' self-re
liance by doing nls work for him or caus
ing It to be done by machinery. So the
Sloyd idea requires that the exercises
shall be reasonably within the pupil's
ability of performance.
The suggested use of models is import
ant. A birdcage does not moke for tne
highest motive. A birdhouse does. In
general, all models making for destruc
tion and detention are to be quietly dis
placed for those which are constructive
a. id altruistic .n their suggestions.
In shaping model series, the American
tendency of late years gives preferment
to school apparatus over articles of home
une It can hardly be otherwise in this
day of correlation^ -tudy^ KENYQN
Stanford University.

The Schoolmasters' Club of San Diego
I recently adopted resolutions favoring the
cd. only to end In exposure and the de
1 capitation of the chief movers on Tower
: Hiii.
It is mnrvelous how William manager!
to escape all these dangers, and to main
j tain his hold on the affections of the Eng-
I Ilsh people. Jt may be that he was only
' accepted as a pis aller. that the memory
of Stuart tyranny and misrule was too
recent in the minds of men to allow of
the revival of this dynasty. Or it may be.
if Mr. Weyman's picture of the King Is
correct, that the was much in the man
to command admiration and respect: that
he had the Inborn dignity of royalty and
a full share of that mysterious magnetic
power which compels allegiance.
We see William first just at the time of
the great assassination plot, when a
scheme to waylay and murder him while
out hunting came perilously near suc
cess. Our first glimpse of the monarch
is at Kensington Court, when the nar
rator of the story, a humble clerk, is
| brought unexpectedly Into the presence of
the King.
"We stood upon the threshold of a wide
and splendid gallery, set here and there
with huge china vases and hung with
pictures, which even then I discerned to
be of great beauty and afterwards learned
were of no less value. Letting my eyes
travel down this vista they paused na
turally on a spot under one of the win
i dows, where with his back to us and
ribbons In his hands a slight gentleman,
who stooped somewhat and was dressed
in black, ambled and paced In front of a
child of four or five years old. The wintry
sunlight which fell in cold bars -on the
floor proved his progress to be more
I showy than real; nevertheless the child
i shrieked in its joy, and dancing, jerked
! the ribbons and waved a tiny whip. In
i answer the gentleman, whose long curled
â¢ periwig bobbed oddly on his shouldersâ
j he had his back to usâ pranced more and
; more stoutly, though on legs a little thin
and bent."
Quite a pretty picture of royal relaxa
tion, illustrating the human side of kingly
i life. It is the more remarkable when con
! trusted with the following description of
I William's personal appearance: "He had
! a long sallow face, which seemed the sal
lower for the dark heavy wig that fell
I round it; a large hooked nose and full,
| peevish lips, with eyes both bright and
j morose. I am told that he seldom smiled
j and never laughed."
Later on in the volume the hero, an
Insignificant individual of the name of
Price, is again brought into personal con
! tact with his monarch and this lime we
j get an outline of the sterner side of Wil
i liam's character. The state council is in
| quiring into the abortive assassination
j plot and one of its prime instigators. Sir
' John Fenwick, is under examination. The
! King enters unannounced and very quiet
ly. "His entrance and words, abrupt, if
not awkward, lacked alike the grace which
all remembered in Charles and the gloomy
majesty which the second James had at
his command. And men felt the lack.
Yet as he took his stand, one hand lightly
resting on the back of the Lord Steward's
chair, the stooping, somber figure and
sallow, withered face staring out of its
great peruque had a dignity of their own.
For it could not be forgotten that he was
that which no Stuart King of England
had ever beenâ a soldier and commander
from boyhoodâ at home, in all the camps
of Flanders and the Rhine, familiar with
every peril of battle and breach; at his
ease anywhere, where other men
blanched and drew back."
These quotations illustrate Mr. Wey
man's facile gift of character delineation.
The Duke of Shrewsbury, Sir John Fen
wick and various other notables of the
time are pictured with equal strength.
But It is upon that mysterious personage
known as Ferguson the Kingmaker that
our author lavishes most of his talent.
This master of backstairs intrigue plays
a prominent part in the story, though it
is impossible within the limits of a brief
notice to unravel all the complications of
plot and counterplot which crowd the
pages of the book. Here is Ferguson as

A NOVEL SCHOOL BUILDING.
New York is to have what it is hoped will be a model school building,
which is to be erected on One Hundred and Fourth street, running through
to One Hundred and Fifth street, west of First avenue. It will be built in
the form of a letter H, thus making room for large open playgrounds on
either side. It will be five stories high and built with a steel skeleton.
The first story includes boys' and girls' play rooms, wainscoted with
glazed brick and floored with asphalt, and furnished with abundant facilities
for obtaining drinking water. In one of the wings two kindergarten rooms
have been Jaid out, with direct communication with the courtyard. The main
entrance has a tiled floor. Offices for the medical inspector and janitor ad
join the vestibule. These also have tiled floors and are furnished with all ne
cessary conveniences.
The second, third and fourth stories are divided into sixteen class rooms
each, a total of forty-eight. The wardrobes are outside the class rooms and
are so arranged as to be easily accessible. They are als<? thoroughly venti
late i and each has a coil of steam pipe to dry clothing when damp and to
maintain a circulation of air. The fifth story is designed to provide for man
ual and physical training and to supply room for a library and reading room.
This building will be heated by a system which provides for each child
thirty cubic feet of warm, fresh air per minute, and which also provides for
the removal of foul air. The furniture will be of the most mode .1, adjustable
type, while the sanitary appliances will also be of the most approved and
modern style.
reduction of the proportion of census
children to each teacher from seventy to
sixty, and also demanded the abolition of
the State text books.

J was the man I saw before me: on whose
i face, as if heaven purposed to warn his
fellows against him. malignant passion
and an insane vanity were so plainly
stamped that party spirit must have gone
! to lengths Indeed before it : rendered men
1 blind to his quality.' His shambling gait
seemed a fitting conveyance for a. gaunt,
stooping figure, so awkward and uncouth
i that when he gave way to gesticulation it
' seemed to be moved by wires; yet once
i he looked askance at you face and figure
; were forgotten in the gleam of the eyes
i that treacherous and cruej. leered at you
I from the penthouse of his huge, ill-fitting
wig.**
For the hero of the novel, : Richard
I Price, we must confess an utter lack or
1 sympathy. His pusillanimity and weak
ness excite repulsion, and it looks as if
: Mr. Weymnn had only Introduced him as
j a convenient vehicle for the presentment
I of the more manly and picturesque per-
I sonages of the time. Beginning as an
! usher in a country school. Price is hope-
I lessly befooled In a love affair with a
country wench and flees to London. There
: he serves his apprenticeship to the trade
; of news letter writing, a business which
! the development of minting facilities had
' not yet destroyed. Then he becomes the
â tool of Ferguson and other plotters for
! the destruction of the monarchy, and is
i induced to personate the Duke of Shrews
; bury, to whom he bears a most marked
i resemblance. !In all these doings he is
j purely subjective, he moves through va
j rious kinds of excitement and danger
i like a mere quaking automaton, and lr
i he escapes hanging many times as a spy
! and a rebel it is more by reason of good
luck than merit.- Why Mr. Weyman
j should take the trouble to bring such a
| nondescript creature through all these
I hair-breadth escapes and marry him hap-
I pily In the end passes our comprehension.
Possibly the hero's weakness is purposely
exaggerated in order to accentuate the
strength of the other actors in the drama.
And leaving Price, as narrator, out of
! the question, Mr. Weyman has certainly
given us a very vivid presentation of
London life and character at the close of
I the seventeenth century.
LITERARY NOTES.
Leon Daudet Is at work upon a biog
raphy of his father.
"The Londoners" Is the title of Robert
Hlchens' new satirical novel, to be out
this spring with Herbert S. Stone & Co.
of Chicago.
Rumors that H. Rider Haggard was at
work on a new novel are now confirmed.
The book is to be a historical romance
with the scene laid in Holland at the
time of William of Orange.
Copeland & Day will shortly bring out
a vojume of poems by Ambrose Blerce.
O. P. Putnam's Sons have just published
Mr. Blerce's "In the Midst of Life," in
cluding "Tales of Soldiers and Civil
ians."
Professor Robert Herrick, who occupies
the chair of English literature in the Uni
versity of Chicago, has written a novel
which is to bte published shortly by tho
Macmillan Company under the title ot
"The Gospel of Freedom."
Bernard Shaw, who is called the clever
est dramatic critic and playwright in
England, is about to bring out an edition
of his dramatic works. He calls them
"Plays Pleasant and Unpleasant." Two
volumes will be issued late in February
by Herbert S. Stone & Co. of Chicago.
Mr. Shaw has written a preface, "mainly
about myself" he adds.
During the last three years William
Black has been engaged upon a novel
which is now near completion. The title
will be "Wild Eelin; otherwise called
Eelin of the Eyes Like the Sea-Wave:
Her Escapades, Adventures and Bitter
Sorrows." The serial publication of this
work is to begin this month. Harper &
Brothers will publish in the spring a new
volume of his short stories.

Office at Independence. For this reason
Mr. Austin will probably resign his pres
ent position at the coming meeting of the
Hoard of Supervisors.

finished at Tamalpais Station, Maria

The students of the Visalia High School
save a very creditable presentation of the
four-act comedy, "Dot, the Miners
Daughter," last Saturday evening In the
assembly hall of the Locust-street School.AN APPRECIATION
OF THE MELODRAMA AND THE ACTING
AT MOROSCO'S.
The other night I crossed the equator
to Morosco's and saw every one of the
five acts and the scenes of "Hands<
Across the Sea." It is a representa
tive Adelphi melodrama by Pittit and
Sims, and the performance of it was a
very decent one. Morosco'a is a good
place to visitâ not too often, but just
and then of a dull night in a dull
week. There you find a performance
that is characteristic ncting that is
sometimes delightfully and memorably
â  :. ; sometimes amazingly good, al-
S!i;;ke?peareari in its resonance
and elaboration; and above all you
t'.iid atmosphere. MoroÃOo'a is the one
theater in San Francisco that *has an
atmosphere distinctly its own, as it is
ihe one theater that can boast an ab
solute clientele, a special following,
which is ever faithful and entirely its
ov. n. The Morosco audience shares im
portance with the Morosco play and
actor in making: the Morosco atmos
phere. Th-* audience may vary in size,
but night by night, week by week, it is
thÂ« ?nmf in appearance and in tempw,
always dependable, - nexactine and dr
termined to be entertained. Even the
oppopir.gr element, the infinitely smaller
crowd that goes to laugh and flatter its
cynicism in being unmoved by ready
made sentiment and sensation, is al
ways the same, and in its minority and
lneffectualness a very emphasis to the
characteristic atmosphere of the house.
The people who go seriously to Moros
co'? knuw what they want: their de
sires are modest and unchanging; they
pive the mnnn cement a. standing order
f. >r life, and the management has the
good sense to till it.
Think of it! They put on flfty-two
melodramas a year at Morosco's! And
all alike! Sometimes I wonder how it
is they can keep from petting some
thing different. Suppose a play should
.. some night ami brazenly refuse
to employ the dark Aside, the subtle
Soliloquy and the Marvelous Coinci
dence; and Biippose in addition to this
it should insolently scorn to portion off
the virtue, suffering, comicality and
crime in the sacred old wayâ then what
would happen, do you think? But of
course there Is no danger and no use
Thinking. Morosco never trifles with
the emotions of his audience. He pre
to surprise them and they pre
â¢ be surprised, but there to a nice
ling between them that is
Inviolable.
Everything at Morosco's is on the
largest possible scaleâ the play, the act-
Ing, the theater, all conspire to produce
:Tect of hugeness. Nothing Is done
simply that can as well be accomplish
. d with elaboration. Nothing, not even
the simplest fact, is left unexplained.
How tritely erroneous is the statement
that the deed, not the word, counts in
; . Irama! I would wager there is
â¢ leisurely conversation in the ay-
Adelphl piece than in the draw
ing-room polemics of Pinero. If there
place where action does not
ler than words, it is In mcl
â '. here every deed is forecast
ne speech and commemorated in
of the same. The villain would
rob, kill, ruinâ must you wait till his
dastard work is done before knowing
all about it? Never: His gnarled
"nance alone would tell the tale,
but that is not enough; in ominous
tones he plans it over to himself, or,
5, he may even tell his victim.
There is a sort of assistant villain in
"Hands Across the Sea," a French
count of mean morals, who breaks into
thÂ»? hero's house, intending no good to
the hero's wife, who is alone and un
protected. Already you have heard
him plan to get the hero away from
home at this hour, and you know his
evil purpose. So, once in the house
and face to face with the woman, docs
he behave as the mere count of smooth
c- very-day humanity would behave?
Not on your life. He tells her all about
it, too. He would tell her his whole
grimy past and future as well if the
hero did not return punctually several
hours earlier than he had been ex
pected, deliver a few verbal knock
outs and finally fit the action to the
words. There is nothing so prodigious
ly careful, confidential and explana
tory as melodrama.
Taken all round "Hands Across the
Sea" Is easily the best production I
have ever seen at Morosco's. The ex
terior scenes, especially the one of the
steamer's dfÂ»ck with the moving French
man-o'-war ok In the distance, are
fitted to the big stage with a fine sense
of space, and the acting is remarkably
forceful and even. A pood scene or two
is quite an e very-week occurrence at
Sforpsoo's, but ti.is time the acting
ptruck me aa a special effort. The cast
called for twenty-tl.ree parts, out of
which fourteen were important and
. i '1 in ever â¢ instance without dis-
The stage management, which
!p usually forgiven because of the
lightning change of bill from week to
â week, was much more prompt and in
vb than usual, and even the or
â  i thai supplied the diseriptive
was moderately subdued and
Ingly in tune.
Altogether it was a performance full
of character and rich with good old
melodramatic radition. Mr. Mainhall
en'] Miss Hall suffered colds that kept
th<Â» hf-r> a.r.d the heroine from their
full powers, but their acting was large,
amiable and Incessant, and never
marred by the obvious personal pose.
They seemed to work for the play. On

too, does a clever bit in the fragmen- '

venturess. Another valuable Morosco
is Landers Stevens, the villain man
(whom 1 habitually slight out of a
family modesty). He has, I believe,
the South Side record for endurance
having just completed sixty consecu
j tive weeks of steady employ lent, nine
performances to the week. His acting
is spacious and his voice wide. He has
the mannerisms of the villain business
down to a science, smoking cigarettes,
digging in his trousers pockets, toying
with his gloves and wearing a top hat
with faultless malevolence. The only
improvement I should suggest is that
he try to read his big speeches with
the same easy emphasis he gives to the
little ones and that he learn to shoot
his cuffs. Who ever heard of a really
nwell villain that didn't shoot his cuffs?
ASHTON STEVENS.
JHE OUTip WOpLD.
piays, Pleasant and Unpleasant,
by Bernard ShavA
George Bernard Shaw, tho most bril
liant, if the most erratic of all the liv
ing dramatic critics, and the author of
such dramatic satires as "Arms and
the Man" and "The Devil's Disciple,"
THE BAN" FBAISTCISCO CALL, SUKPAY, APRIL 10, 1898.
"The Devil's Disciple" would refute
thatâ but because he believes that in
the present policy of theatrical man
agement the only chance an author has
is to place his works in the hands of
the reading public. And so we shall
soon know as much about Shaw as we
do about Ibsen.
Rut, unlike the Scandinavian, Shaw
has very decided views as to the fu
tility of offering readers a mere repro
duction of the "prompt copies" pre
pared for stage use. "The dramatic
author must," he contends in one of his
prefaces, "fall back on his powers of
literary expression, as other popts and
fictionists do. What would we not give"
for the copy of Hamlet used by Shake
speare at rehearsal, with the original
'business' scrawled by the prompter's
pencil? And if we had. In addition,
the descriptive directions which the
author gave on the stageâ above all.
the character sketches, however brief,
by which he tried to convey to the ac
tor the sort of person he wished him
to incarnateâ what a light they would
shed, not only on the play, but on the
THE BAD EGG'S EASTER DREAM.
history of the sixteenth century! If
Is' for want of this process of elabora
tion that Shakespeare â unsurpassed as
poet, story-teller, character draughts
man, humorist and rhetoricianâ hae left
us no intellectually coherent drama,
and could not pursue a genuinely scien
tific method in his studies of character
and society."
In place of the familiar directions
and scenic specifications the "Plays.
Pleasant and Unpleasant" of Bernard
Shaw will be annotated with finished
descriptions, vivid character sketches,
psychologic notes and sallies of a
characteristic mordant type. The first
volume will consist of those plays
which the author is pleased to term
"unpleasant" â the unpleasantness ly
ing in the fact that they convict the
capitalist phase of modern social or
ganization, and are written from the
point of view of a socialist who regards
the basis of middle class society as
thoroughly rotten, economically and
morally. Under this heading come
"Widowers' Houses," "The Philan
derer" and "Mrs. Warren's Profes
sion." The root idea of the first
named is the rich suburban villa
standing on the rents of the foul rook
ery; of the second, a four-act topical
comedy, the fashionable cults of Ibsen
ism and "New Wornanism" on a basis
of clandestine sensualityâ the Inde
pendent Theater refused to produce it
on account of its "immorality:" while,
in the third, Mrs. Warren taxes society
with her occupation, which is that of a
procuress.
Volume llâ "Pleasant Plays"â will
comprise "Arms and the Man," the
sparkling comedy in three acts, of
youthful romance and disillusion,
' which was the despair of the critics on
â  its production in London and New
York; "The Man of Destiny," a one-act
I comedy, in which Sir Henry Irving had
! intended to appear as the youthful Xa
i poleon; "You Never Can Tell," a four
act modern comedy concerned with the
! adventures of a sparkling pair of twins,
! and "Candida," a frankly sentimental
j play, which Mr. Shaw hopes to find vn r
; derst.mded of women, if not of men.
For some reason or other his latest
and most successful piny, "The Devil's,
; Disciple," will not be among the plays
printed. The books will be published â¢
! nere by Stone & Co. of New York, and
| in London by Grant Richards.
Even the glorious Molba is not '
j above the tune of the twittering press j
! agent. This came neatly typewritten:
Long before Melba had any thought of
a public career the fame of her beautiful
voice had become known, and she was
' in frequent request to sing at charity
i concerts, in Mcl bourne, much to the dis
! pleasure of her parents, strict Scotch !
1 Presbyterians, who were greatly opposed
to her appearance in public. After
awhile it occurred to her that it would
be a good idea to give a concert on her
â¢wn account, at which she might expect
the patronage of those whom she had
Â«o frequently served. AceoruTsgly she
â¢â â¢ngaged a lia.ll, made ail her arrange
ments, and started out to sell the tick
ets. Her father, however, recognizing
with joy his opportunity to cure her of
'ier inclination to sing in public, set about
'o secure a disastrous result for the con
cert by previously calling on her friends
and pledging them, its a favor to him.
to decline to buy. The result was that
when the eventful evening came Melbu
found herself confronted by a select but
diminutive audience of two. Nothing
daunted, she gave the entire concert ac
conling to programme; and, later, when
bills for hall rent and advertising were
presented, suspecting the trick he had
nerved her, sent her creditors to her
father, who. by that time, convinced that
his brilliant scheme had failed of its
hoped-for result, and with a secret admi
ration of his daughter's plunk, paid them
willingly. It cannot be doubted that her
splendid career has long since removed
his early objection, which, had it been
successful, would have deprived the world
of song of its most shining light.
Baldwin.
The latest Hoyt farce, "A Stranger in
New York," is announced for produc
tion at the Baldwin to-morrow night.
The farce is given the credit of being
an unusually bright one, with action
swift and tireless, and not a moment
of weariness between the first and final
curtains.
The story is rather more complicated
than most of those in which Mr. Hoyt
has dealt, and tells of an old chap from
Chicago, with a letter of introduction
to a New York man about town. He
arrives in the metropolis with the ma-
tention of attending the French ball in
Madison-square Garden. He loses his
letter, which is picked up and de
livered by a stranger who has no desire
to deceive, but who is welcomed with
such cordiality as would have been
shown to the real person for
whom the communication was written,
that he has no chance to withdraw,
and finds himself all at once in the cen
ter of a brisk whirl of gayety.
The other, for whom the letter was
penned, discovers the error which has
been made and starts in brisk but
hopeless pursuit.
This portion of the action takes
place in one of the corridors of the
Hoffman House. The next chapter is
unfolded in a room in the tower of
Madison-square Garden, occupied as a
studio by one of New York's charac
ters. In the end the stranger finds an
opportunity to disclose his identity,
but he has come to be well regarded by
ll the other personages, and loses
nothing through the deception in which
he had unwittingly participated. The
locale of the piece gives opportunity
for handsome settings and the glitter
and glamour of the French ball Is re
produced. It is said, with striking ef
fect. The play is full of new music by
Richard Suihl ana A. B. Sloane.
At the head of the company cornea
Anna Boyd, of known quality, and Joe
Coyne, new to us, but with a reputa
tion in the East. Others in the cast
are: Charles Dungan, John Dudley,
W. H. Hatter, Harry Rodgers, Steve
Maley, Sam Marion. John Mitchell,
Willia Martin. Ed Worm, Willie Mar
tin, Thomas Quinn, Minnie McEvoy,
Minnie Bridges, Camille Cleveland, Liz
zie McCoy, Nellie McCoy and Amy
Muller.
The attraction to follow "A Stranger
in New York" at the Baldwin is "The
Purser." which Ferris Hartman will
bring out.
Ga!iforr\ia.
Edward Harrigan will present at the
California to-night "Old Lavender," the
most popular and surely the most
earnest of all his many plays. To the
older playgoers it will be interesting to
see how the play and player have worn,
and to the younger generation the per
formance should be uniquely entertain
ing. Mr. Harrigan is one of the pio
neer American dramatists, and in his
day enjoyed an almost unrivaled
vogue. The character of Old Lavender
is full of quiet pathos and observation,
and is remembered here as his master
piece, both in authorship and acting.
It is hardly to be expected that the
present company will come irp wUh our
recollections of the original one, but it
Is said that Mr. Harrigan has rebanded
his players with considerable tact and
preserved all the traditions of the parts.
Dave Braham will play Dick, the
Rat. the role made famous by the
late Tony Hart, and all the original
Braham songs will be sung.
Columbia.
Mr. Herne begins the second and last
1 week of "Shore Acres" at the Colum
j bia to-morrow evening. The houses
'â  have been uniformly large and the
' prospects for the closing performances
j are the brightest the play has yet en
' joyed in this city. Miss Marion Cul
i len, who has been playing Perley dur
: ing the past week, will exchange roles
I with Miss Julie A. Herne for the clos
; ing week. Miss Cullen is a protege of
i Denman Thompson and for two sea
j sons was a prominent feature in the
veteran actor's production. It is Mr.
Herne's intention to withdraw from
"Shore Acres" at the close of the pres
! ent season as he is anxious to stage
i his new work, "The Rev. Griffith Da-
I venport." This new play will be fol
lowed by "Silas Lapham," which "Wil
liam Dean Howells is having drama
tized for Mr. Herne. A second com
pany playing "Shure Acres" is headed
by Archie Boyd, and. although con
fined mostly to one-night stands, it is
meeting with financial prosperity in
the East and Middle West.
"Nancy Hanks," a comedy success of
the present season, is announced to fol
low "Shore Acres" at the Columbia
Theater on the 18th inst. At the head
of the presenting company will appear
Marie Jansen.
It is not a racing play as the title
may indicate; the "Nancy Hanks" re
ferred to is not a horse, but a gold
mine, or rather a mine that has been
"salted" by unscrupulous persons and
palmed off as a rich ore-producer upon
a speculative Frenchman, on whose
complicated adventures the plot hinges.
Alcazar.
"The Strange Adventures of Miss
Brown" will be the new bill at the Al
cazar, where at very popular prices it
should make a successful week, as it
has been played here but once before,
and that time with Eddie Foy in the
titulary part and at the Baldwin. For
those who may have forgotten this is
a sketch of the theme: A young Eng
lish officer weds a "ward in chancery"
and to rescue her from a private school
in which she is confined, disguises him
self as a young woman. In the school
he has no end of comic adventure.
There is a strong bit of subsidiary
character in a German music teacher
who is In love with the school girl.

The Tivoli's new piece, "Slnbad the
Sailor," which was produced last night,
is reviewed in another part of thia
paper.
Morosco's.
The prologue of "Pavements of
Paris," which will be the next attrac
tion at Morosco's, opens with a scene
in the province of Lorraine, at the foot
of the Alps, during the period of the
Franco-Prussian war. The wife of Jean
Le Franc is the missing heiress to the
titles and estates of a noble family.
Their union has been blessed with a
daughter. Little Marie, about whosa
subsequent adventures much of the in
terest of the plot centers. The closing
scene of the prologue, in which occur
the murder of General Peronne, the
supposed death of Jean, and the abÂ«
duction of Marie occur, has been util
ized for the introduction of a histori
cal war tableau. It will show the op
posing armies confronting each other
upon fortified heights, during the heat
of the bloody battle of Forbach. An
other important new scene will be a re
production of a view of the city of
Paris by moonlight, fourteen years
later. The moonlight flooding the
stately buildings falls upon the placid
waters of the Seine. The famous Pont
Neuf, or New Bridge, spans the river.
The "Tomb of the Rabbits," a low Par
isian groggery. where the thieves and
gamins of Paris congregate for their
nightly revels, affords a meeting place
for the villain and his tool. Little
Mary, now grown to comely girlhood,
is a fugitive f-om the persecutions of
a procuress. Che crosses the bridge,
is seen by her enemies, pursued and
thrown into the river. Her father,
who has served through the war, and
returned to Paris to pursue the voca
tion of a hackman, hears her cries for
help. He is at the foot of the bridge,
filling his water bucket, and rushes to
the rescue, forming the final tableau
with Maria's dripping body in his arms.
Mr. Mainhall's part is that of the Vl
compte de Flashon. a chevalier d'indus
trie and all-around rogue, whose re
deeming traits and droll characteris
tics rob his unscrupulous actions of
much of their repulsiveness. La Petite
Lund has been cast for little Mary
and will introduce specialties, and the
rest of the company will be prominent-
I ly represented.
Orpheum.
An entire new bill is announced at
the Orpheum this wpek, when Hyde's
comedians take the boards in place of
the present string of talent. The Hyde
show opens with to-night's perform
ance. The Hyde combination is said
to be the strongest of all the road vau
deville shows, and several acts have
been specially engaged for the coast
tour. At the head of the list is Helena
Mora, the famous female barytone, who
will appear in descriptive songs and
ballads. She will introduce one written
specially for her, entitled "For Old
Glory," which will be produced with
scenic effects. Mclntyre and Heath,
the black face comedians, have an
amusing skit, entitled "Two Georgia
Minstrels," in which the experiences
and hardships of the stranded actor
are presented. An entirely different
line of black face work is that by Wil
liams and Walker, colored boys, who
will present the idiosyncrasies of the
flash coon and his sweetheart. Thia
team scored the phenomenal run of
thirty-two weeks at Koster & Bial's.
In their act they will introduce "Lord
Barnie," the famed black mascot of the
Chicago baseball game; they are as
sisted In the cake-walk by two creole
girls.
Charles R. Sweet, known as the piano
tramp, will appear in specialties, and
Thome and Carlton will present a skit
entitled "The Substitute Husband."
The great Lafayette, who has attained
fame as an imitator of John Philip
Sousa. will appear in a turn of fantas
tic mimicry. Among other features of
the bill is Ajax, known as the flexible
marble.
Ghutes.
The animals, their intrepid trainers,
Chlquita and several new people in the
free theater will make the Chutes an
attractive place this week.
Olvjmpia.
Mandola, the clever equilibrist, who
has been the especial hit at the Or
pheum this week, will be one of several
new turns at the Olympia.
JYlusic.
At Thursday's symphony concert in
the Tivoli Mr. Seheel's orchestra will
play Schubert's C major symphony,
the Parisian Bacchanale from "Tann
hauser" and a symphonic poem by Ur
ban, entitled "The Ratcatcher."
The first of a series of concerts to be
given here by the world famous Knei
sel quartet will take place at Sherman.
& Clay Hall on the evening of May 18.

BOYS' AND GIRLS' PAGE.
THE CAPTAIN'S ADVENTURE.
DID I ever have any -adventures
in China?" repeated the old sea
captain, stretching himself com
fortably in hi? chair. "Well, yes,
a few. I r-m.-mber a pretty tick
lish one which happ-ned in '64. when
I was down on the H<>ung-ho River at
Shanghai.
"You must know that in China the
small river craft corresponding to our
rowb>>ats are called sampans. These
boats are long, narrow affairs with just
room for a passenger undi'r the hood
at one end. while opposite sits the
Chin^sA sculler.
"Well, on the nieht of which I speak,
my ship, the Dolphin, was lying "ft.
Tung Ka'lon, which was the third or
French portion of thÂ»- river. I was
making ready for sea, but had been
kept very late in the custom-house that
night gntting my bill of lading. But
everything was ready aboard ship, for
she had been well provisioned and a
Chinese crew pngaged. All the officers
\v(-rÂ«", of course, Americans. I had no
passengers, but was carrying a cargo
of tea and silk to Fuchau.
"At about 11 p. m. I finished my busi
ness at the custom-house, and then
walked down the bund, or beach, to the
French concession. Here, as I had
discharged my own private boatman,
I looked about for any sampan near by
to carry me out to my ship. I en
paered one and set off.
"The night was pitchy dark with a
drizzling rain and the only light we
had was that furnished by a small lan
tern hanging up behind me in the hood
of the sampan. As we went up stream
I noticed that my boatman kept up a
guttural conversation with other pass
ing sampan men. but thought nothing
of it at the time.
THE BOYS NEXT SUNDAY,
Xext Sunday morning the page of selected stories written by the
boys of the coast, in competition with the girls, will be published. The
girk' page will appear one week later. Two days remain for mailing
stories intended lor the pages. No selection will be made, therefore, un
til after Tuesday next. During the past week the boys have done well,
and the competition will not be one-sided. The boys will be represented
by six 'â¢torics. which will be illustrated. More stories will be used if there
is sufficient space. The girls will have the same amount of space as the
boys. The judges have not all responded to the invitations sent out to
them, but acceptances are coming in. The full list will be published at
the proper time. At the time of this writing nine judges have signified
pleasure at being able to serve fhe boys and girls. There will be fifteen in
all, and every judge will be prominently connected with education on
the Pacific Coast. Thoy are all accustomed to reading the compositions
of boys and girls and to pas_ing upon their merits. They will represent
many communities and much education and good judgmen . The list of
judges will be satisfactory and so will the stories. Watch for the Boys'
Page next Sunday. Then see the Girls' Page the succeeding Sunday. The
two pages will exemplify the story-telling ability of our young people.
THE BUMPKINS ABANDON THE CIRCUS FOR ONE DAY TO HUNT EASTER EGGS AND DISCOVER SOME QUEER SPECIMENS.
EDITED BY
DAVID H. WALKER.
BY EUGENIA B. MABURY.
"Rut when we got half way to the
Bhip mv man suddenly Btopped sculling
and at the very same nwunent a <~ouple
of strange sampans dropped along mi
either side, while two of the most
hide >us and most villainous faces I
ever had Been peered In under the h< od
at me. 1 was startled, for 1 was taken
..'â¢â t-ly off my guard. But, quick
as a flash, I grabbed my revolver and
drew bead on my boatman. Instantly
he dropped overboard, carrying his "iir
with him. and then the other two
cowardly rascals let go the edge of my
sampan and disappeared in the dark
ness.
â¢ But imagine my plight! There I
was without an oar. in the middle of
ilv stream above the friendly conces
sion, with the tide fast carrying me
down to unknown dangers. I dirt not
dare x<> cry out for help for fear of
being mobbed by the boatmen on the
rivei", who h<-.ld life cheap and regard
all foreigners as legitimate prey.
"Finally I could hear the tide rush
ing past the moorings of some ship not
far away, and presently could Bee the
phosphorus caused by the washing of
her chain in the water. Hope returned,
and pulling up the thwart, or seat of
the sampan. I managed by dint of much
patience and exertion to paddle over
to the ship and make fast my painÃ-r to
her (ham.
" "Sampan, ahoy!' sung out a voice
with a strong Norwegian accent. But
I i;i''. not answer.
" 'Sampan, ahoy!' he cried again. 'If
you don't answer I'll throw something
down at you.'
"I concluded it was time to reply, so
I told him who I was. and was then
very glad to find him the mate of the
ship, and a man with whom I was
slightly acquainted. Then I described
my condition, and learned that John,
the sampan man of the Norwegian
ship, had been telling the offic?r how an
Englishman had that night stolen a
THE SAX FRANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APRIL 10, 1898.
boat and thrown the owner overboard.
"The mate ordered John to tow me
back to my ship at once.
"< >n my arrival I ordered the cap
tured sampan to be hau!<-d aboard and
placed in full sight on top of the pilot
house. All the next day hundreds of
boatmen rowed past to view it, but
none came to claim it; and as there
was no mark upon it I had no means of
finding out to whom the boat belonged.
But early next morning, since I could
wait no longer, I set sail for Fuchau,
and took the sampan along, thinking I
would keep it for my own private use.
I also carried a special sampan man
with me.
"Now, as the river in this section
was so shallow. I had to stop at the
Pagoda anchorage, eighty miles below
Fur hau. Directly opposite me, across
the river, was the town of Fookeln.
Here there lived a class of piratical
Chinese, who made a business of rob
bing and killing all upon whom they
could lay their hands, both natives and
foreigners.
"When I arrived at the Pagoda an
chorage I started in my sampan with
the new man up the river until I
reached Fuchau. On landing I told him
to wait there for me, but on my return
was not greatly surprised to find both
him and the sampan missing. I re
ported the case to the American Consul,
who sent out a Chinese detective. Two
hours later the detective returned and
reported that my man had gone across
the river to Fookein, which was full of
lawless boatmen, and. being a stranger,
they had killed him and cut off his head
and kept the sampan. So that was the
end of my adventure."
UNCLE BILLY AND
LITTLE SUNSHINE
BY MABEL E. THOMPSON.
Uncle Billy was an old man. He
lived in San Francisco. He was very
silent, and people called him cross; but
he had a soft spot in his heart. One
night, as he was walking home, think
ing: of his little granddaughter, Nellie,
who was dead, he saw a little girl
who was sobbi r.Er. "I want mamma;
bad man take Millie."
He soothed her and took her home
with him. The next day he told the
police about her. They tried to find her
parents, but oould not. U-ele Billy
loved Sunshine, as he called her, and
was glÂ£M to keep her. Years passed by,
and no one came to claim her.
A lady once heard her sing, and per
suaded Uncle Billy to give Sunny sing
ing iessons. Sunny had a gold locket
on her neck when Uncle Billy found
her, and he often showed it to her and
talked about it.
One day, when they were at the park
looking at the swans, Sunny said: "Un
cle Billy, I seem to remember a pretty
place with swans like this." Sunny
became a beautiful girl and a very
sweet singer. Every one loved her, for
she was always kind.
One Saturday Uncle Billy came home
â while Sunny was away and got every
thing ready for an early lunch, so they
could go to the park.
Just as he had finished there was a
rap at the door, and, opening it, he saw
a pretty lady and a gentleman.
As they came forward, the lady
asked: "Are you Uncle Billy, and have
you a little girl named Mildred?"
"I have," said Uncle Billy, "but what
do you know of her?"
"I will tell "you," said the gentleman.
"My name Is Perry and fifteen years
ago to-day we had a little girl born
whom we named Mildred. She grew
to be a pretty child. TVhen she was
about two years old I discharged a
man who was dishonest. He threat
ened to be revenged.
"One day, when Millie and her nurse
were out walking, the nurse stopped
to talk with some friends and Millie
wandered on. She was f-pt\ no more.
"Two weeks ago we received a let
ter from this man, saying that he was
Aery sick and wanted t'> see us. "We
went to him at once and he told us
that he stole Millie and took her to
San Francisco and saw you take her
home. He found out your name and
told us where to go.
"Now. Uncle T-silly, you see we are
her parents. Have you the locket that
was on her neck?"
"Yes." said Uncle Billy, "and I must
lose my Sunshine."
AN EASTER MORNING SONG.
Within a California bower
Of roÂ«*s stood a matron sweet.
Around her, in a fragrant shower.
Fell the rare rose leaves at her feet.
"Dear God," she said, 'â from out of the clear
Blue sky we ask Thy sign of love
This Easter day, thy children hear
The pinions of the Heavenly Dove
Which in far old Tudea descended
And Jesus in i.ie wave attended."'
Hark! Children's voices, faint and fine
Sang a glad Easter morn refrain.
'Dear Lord," they sang, *'the world is thine.
Earth praises thee with flowers and grain.
Far spread the landscape â hill and dale.
Mountains with orange groves beneath,
Whose blossoms sweetened every galeâ"
Earth's fairest, richest, bridal wreath!
"God," said the matron. "God above
In these sweet children pledges love."
"Oh, no," said Mrs. Perry. "We will
take you home with us."
Just then Millie came in. "Well,
Funny," said Uncle Billy, "this is your
birthday. These are your parents."
With a cry of joy Millie sprang to
them.
They took Millie and Uncle Billy
home with them to Chicago. Uncle
Billy loved Millie's little brother and
spent his time with him.
Millie was always called "Uncle
Billy's Sunshine." She now saw the
swan she so instinctively remembered
and was very happy with those she
loved.
THE SUN AND MOON.
BY JUDITH GUSLEAN.
The sun and the moon had a fight,
It was a comical sight.
The moon fought the best,
And the sun sank to rest
In the radiant west.
And it sulkily slept all the night.
BEANSTALK JACK'S VOYAGE.
JACK O1O 1 THE BEANSTALK sat
talking with his mother one even
ing by the fireside, when two queer
happenings made Jack open his
eyes wide. The harp that he stole
from the Giant began to talk: the hen
that lays eggs of solid gold began to
lay, and at such a rate that the floor
was soon covered with gold.
"Jack o' the Beanstalk," said the
harp, "do not sit here idly and selfishly.
There are those in trouble who need
your help. Having told you this, I will
ask you to pick up the golden eggs and
place them in a leather raddle-bag.
Rise before the sun to-morrow morning.
When you hear the first crowing in the
barnyard go out and mount a horse
which you will lind standing by the
door. Do not take the reins, but go
â where the horse wills, and be brave and
true. So will you do good."
"Do not go, Jack," said his mother.
"I am old, and need you at home."
"No, mother, do not stop me," said
Jack. "Good fortune has come to us
by daring. Let us not be selfish."
The next morni.g. early. Jack awoke,
kisseu' his mother good-by, took her
blessing and rode off upon the horse he
found in waiting. Once he turned in his
saddle to look back. His mother stood
by her cottage door, waving her hand
kerchief in fond adieu.
What a wonderful horse that was
that Jack had! Jack minded what the
harp had said, and never touched the
bridle once. He had no need to urge
his beast. He raced up hills and down
hills; swam broad and brawling riv.-rs
with ease, galloped through mountain
dt-files and over deserts, and never
tired. This went on for three days,
the horse never pausing, by day or by
Jack luckily had enough provisions
to last him. He was a perfect horse
man and could sleep in his saddle. He
was dozing when a strange noise
roused him. Looking ahead he saw
an ocean. Toward this the horse was
galloping. Before Jack had a chance
to think much the horse had galloped
boldly into the surf. A great billow,
topped with salt foam, took the horse
away from the shore, which soon be
came a dim, dark line far behind.
Bold as Jack was he was really
alarmed. Around him, on all sides,
were only huge, roaring waves the
spray from which kept him constantly
drenched. The wonderful horse found
no difficulty in swimming through and
over the highest waves. Often he raised
l>av and nipht passed several times,
â¢ â¢ IT 1 Vv Cf\
used to it that he slept in his saddle
as easily as when the horse had carried
him over solid land. And now Jack
BOW smoke <>n the horizon. A few hours
later he drew near enough to see that
th<* smoke came from a volcano, which,
like a wonderful torch, seemed to tower
up to the very sky with its flaming
On and on! And now the horse was
on a beach strewn with jagped stones,
and now he had floundered alon^ to a
place above the reach of the waves â
and there his wonderful strength left
him and he lay down and died. But
before his valiant life C parted or his
unconquerable will failed, he spoke
those words to Jack:
"This, dear Jack, is the dreadful home
of the brother of that Giant whom you
saw and, whose land you visited by
means of the wonderful beanstalk.
That Giant being dead, his brother has
brought to this island the farmer who
bought your mother's cow; and here,
also, his family are held as prisoners.
"The reason is that the Giant knew
that the beans which the farmer gave
you enabled you to reach him and to
take away his hen and his harp. This
he told his brother. The brother can
not be hurt by fire; nor by water. You
must find some way to reach the sum
mit of the volcano. I cannot tell you
how. When I am dead take off my
iron shoes. These are charms to help
you. They are filled with magic. They
alone enabled me to travel so far and
to swim so far."
The next instant the horse was dead
and Jack was alone. He took off the
horse's shoes and carefully saved every
nail. He dug a trench by the shore
and buried the horse and, on the board
placed the words, "A brave and faith.
ful friend." Then he pushed on until
he came near the .foot of the volcano.
That was a dangerous place; for the
red hot stones that were thrown from
the volcano rattled on the ground all
about him. He received many a wound,
but struggled onward and upward un
til he found some little shelter in a
grove of iron-wood trees. There, bleed-
Ing and bruised, he rested.
High above him the volcano roared
and the ground shook terribly under
his feet. From the earth came groan
ings and rumblings, as if the wrath of
the volcano would tear up the land and
throw it far out into the waves. Once,
looking upward, Jack fancied that he
saw the Giant gazing ferociously at
him. Jack was much puzzled. How
should he get up on the mountain and
what should he do there? For adown
its scarred sides flowed wide rivers of
red hot lava and the air was filled with
scorching and choking ashes.
Jack's lot seemed sad. He knew, af
ter thinking a little, that he would
never be able to climb to the top
of the volcano without help. Any mo
ment a river of molten lava might flow
toward the grove of iron-wood trees
and drive him from his present shelter.
He fondled the horseshoes taken from
his brave charger's feet. As he did
this a thrill passed through him. His
courage rose.
One of the horseshoes fell to the
ground. Instantly, by the magio with
in, it was turned into a shield of steel.
Seeing this. Jack placed the other shoes
upon the ground. Two of them were
changed into great wheels. One turned
into the body of a chariot. The wheels
and chariot body fastened themselves
THE BABY'S GOOD-NIGHT.
BY CHARLES A. KEELER.
Little eyes close in the dim evening- light;
Wave your hand, little maiden, good-night, good-night.
Wave your hand to the doggie â he's wagging his tail,
And wave to the muley cow down in the dale.
Hark! Hark! She is ringing good-night with her bell;
Now wave to the kitties a sweet farewell.
The birds in the branches above are asleep,
And see the stars shine through the night's distant deep.
Now, little one, wavte a good-night to the moon,
For the owl is singing his sad, sleepy tune.
together. But what was to draw this
chariot? Jack counted the horseshoe
nails out, one by one.
Some turned into double-edged
Bwords and lances and Jack saw that
the lances were to be used with the
shield and that the" swords were to be
fastened to his chariot wheels. Jack
perfected his chariot with these swords,
took up his shield of steel and tried
the points of the lances, which were
sharp as needles, and so strong that
they could not be bent.
So far Jack was satisfied with the
help given him by the magic of the
hm-seshoes, but still the question was
how to get to the top of the volcano,
which was raging more fiercely every
minute.
Suddenly Jack stamped one foot and
laughed outright. In one of his
pockets he had found one bean, just
such a one as the wonderful beanstalk
had sprouted from. He lost not a
second, but planted this bean, hoping
that it would bring him good luck. In
stantly it sprouted. In an hour the
vine was ten feet long, as large round
as Jack's thumb, and as strong as a
rope of steel. Without pause it began
to climb the mountain. Jack took the
hint: fastened the chariot to the vine;
buckled on his shield; took up the
strongest and sharpest lance; and
stepped into the chariot.
His hope was not disappointed. The
beanstalk climbed steadily and rapid
ly. AVonderful to say it did not turn
aside for the streams of lava, but leap
ed over them. Jack stood upright upon
Uie chariot, with eyes bravely turned
toward the mountain top. Passing
through volleys of red hot stones,
breathing the fumes of sulphur and
lava, scorched, bruised, bleeding and
half blinded, but never for one moment
thinking of turning back, up went Jack,
drawn by this wonderful beanstalk.
How was this?
The supposed farmer who first gave
Jack the magic beans was a magician,
although Jack had never guessed it.
This v ,s the country of which the
magic beanstalk as a native. When
Jack bcr.t over to pick up the horse
shoe nails, he, without knowing it,
picked up a magic bean. The beanstalk
w;is sure to grow toward the Giant.
So it happened, after his rough ride
up the steep luountain side, Jack found
himself, in his chariot, ju-. a the full
moon rose above the ocean, on a small
shelf around the volcano's blazing cra
ter. In the crater was this awful
Giant's home. There he h.-d his forge
and made strange shapes of iron â long
swords and spears with jagged edges;
horrible images of men and unknown
beasts, that came, fiery red, from his
worksho-- strange trumpets, through
which the Giant made the most dread
ful sounds; and braeen cymbals, the
noise of which, when they were clashed
together, was like thunder or the roar
and din of a great battle where many
cannons are fired.
Jack shuddered as he looked into the
seemingly bottomless crater and its un
dying fires. He had no time to spend
idly, >for the Giant saw him and, with
one bound, was out of the crater, blaz
ing: in his red-hot armor likeafiery star,
for, it will be recalled, neither fire nor
water could har. him. Upon his head
was a red-hot helmet In his hands
were huge rods of red-hot iron, from
which âks darted in streams as if
the rods were beaten by ham lers In a
smithy. His anger was terrible toÂ»
"\t last!" he screamed, in a -voice
that shook the f(UI \ d ' T "' a n, la mm t ake you
you 'n my power and I * H - mm * ke hp y _Â° r 1 }
help me toil in the volcano s Sen heart
forever and forever!" .
"Not so fast. Mr. Giant,' said Jack
"you have to catch a hare before you
can cook it!" _ Â . , f
"Villain, you escaped my brother, Dut
you shall not escape me!"
The Giant laid about him with the
iron rods as he strode rapidly toward
Jack. One blow would have crushed
Jack lifeless. The magic in the Dean
stalk had gone into the chariot arm
now Jack rode around and around tne
edge of the crater, the sharp swords on
the chariot wheels flashing blood red
in the glare of the volcano's light ana
threatening destruction to anything m
striking distance.
The Giant raced after him, but could
not quite catch Jack.
"Ho! Ho!" laughed Jack, "first catctt
your hare."
But Jack's laughter did not last long.
One nf the chariot wheels struck
against a bank of lava and Jack was
thrown out. Striding close behind, the
Giant had the brave boy in his grasp
in an Instant.
High the Giant held Jack above the
burning crater; loudly he shouted with
fierce glee.
"A warm bath you'll have to-night.
Jack! See how the volcano Is hungry
for you!"
But in his moment of seeming tri-
umph the magic chariot, making the
round of the crater's fiery run, hurried
with lightning-like speed toward the
Giant. He tried to escape, but could
not. He saw that he would soon ba
under the wheels and their cruel
swords unless he could beat the chariot.
Jack's weight was but as a feather to
him. But when he found that tha
chariot gained upon him the Giant
stood a moment, looking like an im
mense statue, and the glare of the vol
cano threw his shadow far over tha
ocean.
"Good-by, Jack," he Bhouted, and
then, with a cruel and mocking laugh,
threw Jack into the awful crater.
At that very instant the chariot
struck the monster, and the wheels cut
him into mincemeat with their two
edged swords.
Jack fell far into the crater. From
his saddle-bag dropped the golden egga
that he had brought from his home. A
fiery monster leaped from the flames
and seized the eggs.
"Gold! Gold!" he fairly shrieked
with glee. Seeing the gold, he forgot
to feed the volcano's fires, and the
Giant's magic having died with him. the
flames went out. Whatever the eggs
bounded against in their fall turned
into gold. So the fiery monster forgot
all about everything but gold and Jack.
The whole crater was solid gold now.
The monster reached out his hands and
caught Jack, so that the lad was not
hurt.
But the quick-witted boy took an egg
and handed it to the monster, who
taking it, immediately turned into a
statue of gold. Jack, now climbed up
the crater, making stepping places in
the gold with his knife. He reached
home after many days and found the
hen dead that lay the golden eggs; but
he did not mind that. He told his
mother of his adventure, and he is to
this day the King of the Island of the
Pure Gold Crater, and his mother is tha
Queen. D. H. W.

SENSIBLE FLOWERS.
BY VERA CHISHOLM.
In an open meadow
Down by the little lane,
Some flowers wish for sunshine.
Some flowers wish for rain.
"Ah." said a tall, fair lily,
"I'm dying now of thirst.
Oh, come to me, dear raindrop.
My heart will surely burst."
"I love to hear the raindrops,"
Said the red rose one day,
"But, oh, where is sweet summer!
She's gone so far away."
"Ha! ha!" laughed the blue violet,
"I am so very glad.
The gentle rain has come to mo,
Althouh it makes you sad!"
Then spoke the velvet pansy,
"The grass grows tall and green,
'Twill give us all some shelter
When winds are cold and keen."
They clapped their handsâ "You're right,
you're right !"'
They all cried out together;
"The winter gives us half our liteâ
The gentle rainy weather."CHARTER

ARTICLE I.
Boundaries, Rights and Liabilities.
SECTION 1. The municipal corpora
tion known as the City and County of
Fan Francisco shall remain and con
tinue a body politic and corporate, in
name and in fact, by the name of the
City and County of San Francisco, and
by that name shall have perpetual suc
cession; may sue md defend in all
courts and places and In all matters
and proceedings; may have an 1 use a
common seal and alter the same at
pleasure: may purchase, receive, hold
and enjoy real and personal property;
receive bequests, gifts and donations of
all kinds of property, in fee simple, or
in trust for charitable and other pur
poses, and do all acts necessary to
carry out thi purposes of tuch gifts,
. =te and donations, .vith power to
r.^anage, sell, lease or otherwise dispose
of the same in accordance with the
terms of the. gift, bequest or trust.
Sec. 2. The boundaries of the City
and County of Can Francisco are here
by declared to be those set forth in
Section Thirty-nine Hundred and Fifty
of the Political Code of California.
Bee. 3. The City and County of San
Francisco shall continue, under this
Charter, to have, hold and enjoy all
property, rights of property, rights of
action of every nature and description
of the existing municipality and is
hereby declared to be the successor of
the same.
Sec. 4. Suits, actions and proceedings
may be brought in the name of the City
and County for the recover: of any
property, money or thinr belong
ing thereto, in law or eqult:\ or dedi
cated to public use therein, or for the
enforcement of any rights cf, or con
tracts with, the City and County,
whether made or arising or accruing
before or after the adoption of this
Charter. All existing suits, actions and
proceedings In the courts or elsewhere.
to which the City and County is a party,
shall continue to be carried on by or
against the City and County.
Sec. 6. No recourse shall be had
against the City and County for dam
age or loss to person or property suf
fered or sustained by reason of the de
fective condition of any sidewalk
ptreet, avenue, lane, alley, court or
place, or by reason of the defective
condition of any sewer, or by reason of
any defective drainage, whether any of
said defects originally existed, or
whether they were occasioned by con
struction, excavation or embankment.
nor shall there be any recourse against
the City and County for want of re
pair of any sidewalk, street, avenue,
lane, alley, court or place or by want
of repair of any sewer; or shall there
be any recourse against the City and
County for damage to. person or prop
erty suffered or sustained by reason of
accident on any sidewalk, street, avenue, 1
lane, alley, court or place, or by falling
from any embankment thereon or Into
any excavation therein: but in anysuch
case the person or persons on whom
the law may have Imposed the obli
gation to repair such defect In ' the
sidewalk, street or public highway, or
in the sewer, and also the officer or
â¢â â â¦floors through whose official negli
gence such defect remains unrepaired
shall be jointly and severally liable to
the party injured for the damage sus
tained.

of the City and County of San Francis
co shall be vested in a legislative body.
Which shall be designated the Board of

Supervisors. Such body is also desig
nated in" this Charter, the Supervisors.
tiec. 2. The Board of Supervisors
thai! consist of eighteen members, all
of whom shall hold office for two years,
and shall be elected from the City and
County at large. Each one must be at
the time of his election an elector of
the City and County, and must have
been such for at least five years next
preceding his election. Each Supervis
or shall receive an annual salary of '
twelve hundred dollr -s.
Every person who has served as I
Mayor of the City and County, so long
as he remains a resident thereof, shall
be entitled to a seat in the Board of
Supervisors and to participate in its
debates, but shall not be entitled to a
vote nor to any compensation.
Sec. 3. A majority of all the members
of the Board shall constitute a quorum,
but a less number may adjourn from
day to day and compel the attendance
of absent members in such manner and
under such penalties as the Board may
prescribe.
Sec. 4. The Board shall:
1. Appoint a clerk, sergeant-at-arms
and, when authorized to do so by ordi- :
nance, such additional clerks and other '.
assistants as may be deemed necessary, j
2. Establish rules for its proceedings, i
3. Keep of its proceedings, |
and allow the same to be published.
The ayes and noes shall on demand of
any member be taken and entered
therein.
4. Have authority to punish its mem
ben for disorderly or contemptuous
behavior in its presence.
Sec. 5. The Mayor shall be the pre-
Biding officer of the Board of Supervis
ore. In the absence of the Mayor the j
Board shall appoint a presiding officer
pro tempore from its own members, ,
who shall have the same right to vote
as other members.
Sec. 6. The Beard shall meet on !
Monday of each week, or if that day be a
legal holiday, then on the next day.
The Board shall not adjourn to any
other place than to its r 'ar place of
meeting, except in case of great neces- :
sity or emergency. The meetings of
I the Board shall be public.
Sec. 7. The clerk, of the Board. :
when requested to do so, shall admin- !
ister oaths and affirmations, without ,
charge, in all matters pertaining to ]
the affairs of his office, and shall per
form such services as may be pre
scribed by the Board. He shall have
the custody of the seal, and of all
leases, grants and other documents,
records and papers of the City and
County. His signature shall be neces
sary to all leases, grants and convey
ances of the City and County.
Sec. S. Every legislative act of the
City and County shall be by ordinance.
The enacting clause of every ordinance
shall be in these words: "Be it or
dained by the People of the City and
County of San Francisco as follows."
No ordinance shall be passed except by
bill, and no bill shall be so amended as
to change its original purpose.
Sec. 9. No bill shall become an ordi
nance nor resolution be adopted, un
less finally passed by a majority of all
the members of the Board and the vote
be taken by ayes and noes and the
names of the members voting for and
1 against the same be entered in the
Journal. -
Sec. 10. No ordinance shall be re
vised, re-enacted or amended by refer
ence to its title: but the ordinance to
be revised or re-enacted, or the section
thereof amended, shall be re-enacted
| at length as revised and amended.
Sec. 11. An ordinance shall embrace
but one subject, which subject shall be
expressed in its title. If any subject
' be embraced in an ordinance and not
i expressed in its title, such ordinance
shall be void only as to so much there
of as is net expressed in its title.
Sec. 12. When a bill Is put upon Its

final passage In the Board and fails to i
pass, and a motion is made to recon- i
sider, the vote upon such motion shall
not be acted upon before the expira
tion of twenty-four hours after ad
journment. No bill for the grant of
any franchise shall be put upon its '
final passage within ninety days after
It* introduction, and no franchise shall ;
be renewed before one year prior to its i
expiration. Every ordinance shall, af- !
ter amendment, be laid over for one ;
week before its final passage.
Sec. 13. Every bill or resolution pro
viding for any specific improvement, ;
or the granting of any franchise or |
privilege, or involving the lease, ap
propri&tioa or disposition of public i
property or the expenditure of public
money, except sums less than two
h" Tdred dollars, or levying any tax
or assessment, and every ordinance
providing for the imposition of a new ,
duty or penalty, shall, after Its intro-
Auction, be published in the official j
newspaper, with the ayes and noes, ,
for at least five successive days (Sun- I
days and legal holidays excepted) be- j
fore final action upon the same. If I
such bill be amended, the bill as
amended shall be advertised for a like ;
period before final action thereon. Bui
in cases of great necessity the officers
and heads of departments may, with
the consent of the Mayor, expend such
sums of money, not to exceed two hun
dred dollars, as shall be necessary to
meet the requirements of such neces
sity.
Sec. 14. If any bill be presented to
the Mayor containing several items ap
propriating money or fixing a tax levy,
he may object to one or more items |
separately, while approving other por- j
tions of the bill. In such case he shall
append to the bill at the time of slgn-
I ing it a statement of the item or items
!to which he objects and the reasons
I therefor, and the item or it^ms so ob-
I jected to shall not take effect unless
' passed notwithstanding the Mayor's
objection. Each item so objected to
: shall be separately reconsidered by the
i Board in the same manner as bills
which have been disapproved by the
Mfyor.
Sec. 15. No ordinance shall take ef
] feet until ten days after its passage
! unless otherwise provided in such or-
dinance.
Sec. 16. Every bill and every resolu
tion as hereinbefore provided, which
shall have passed the Board and shall
have been duly authenticated, shall be
presented to the Mayor for his appro
val. The Mayor shall return such bill
or resolution to the Board within ten
days after receiving It. If he approve
It he shall sign it and it shall then be
come an ordinance. If he disapprove
it he shall specify his objections there
to in writing. If he does not return
it with such disapproval within the
time above specified, it shall take ef
fect as if he had approved It. The ob
jections of the Mayor shall be entered
at large in the Journal of the Board,
and the Board shall, after five and
within thirty daya after such bill or
; resolution shall have been so returned,
i reconsider and vote upon the same. If
j the same shall, upon reconsideration.
: be again passed by the affirmative vote
of not less than fourteen members of
the Board, the presiding officer shall
certify that fact on the bill or resolu
| tion. and when so certified, the bill
shall become an ordinance with like ef
fect as if it had been nnnroved by th ft
; Mayor. If the bill or resolution shall fail
to receive the vote of fourteen members
of the Board it shall be deemed finally
lost. The vote on such reconsideration
shall be tak^n by ayes and noes and
, the names of the members voting for
i and against the same shall be entered
! in the Journal.
Sec. 17. All ordinances and resolu
| tiops shall be deposited with the Clerk
j of the Board who shall record the same
at leneth in a suitable book.
Sec. IS. No ordinance shall be re
j pealed except by ordinance adopted in
i the manner hereinbefore set out. and
such ordinance shall be presented to
; the Mayor for his approval as hereln
1 before provided.
Sec. 19. Except as provided in Chap
ter 111 of Article 111 of this Charter, all
demands payable out of the Treasury

i the Auditor or paid by the Treasurer,
